One day, one of the ghosts opens up to you about how they died. Now, all you want to do is seek revenge on their behalf.
results.81-81: You were the son of an Ottoman padishah. When your father passed away, your brother assumed the throne, and according to tradition, he was meant to eliminate you to ensure there would be no one else with a claim to the throne. However, you managed to escape before he could carry out his intentions.
results.82-82: You had a profound purpose in life and were willing to go to any length to attain it. You came remarkably close to achieving your goal. However, right as you were on the verge of obtaining what you desired, you had an epiphany and recognized that you were, in fact, the antagonist. Overwhelmed by this realization, you chose to abandon everything in order to seek redemption for your wrongdoings.
results.83-83: You are a very accomplished cartographer, and your life’s goal is to create an accurate map of the inner chambers of the Dome of the Rock.
results.84-84: You are a famous bard. Someone has stolen your name and is using your reputation. Their songs are not as good, but because of your fame, they are making great money even though their performances are subpar. You have decided to catch them in the act. You follow them around, going to their last known locations, but you always seem to be one step behind.
results.85-85: You have lost all your memory, and you don't even remember who you are. Your last bits of memories are returning to you in flashes. In your last memory you are sitting in a hut, sipping tea, while a great church looms in the distance with a very distinct bell.
results.86-86: Your biggest desire was to join the Crusades and prove yourself, but you were deemed unfit. After months of training, you will show all who doubted you that you have what it takes.
results.87-87: Your mother believed you to be a messiah and protected you your whole life, preparing you for your eternal duty. After her death you have set out for Jerusalem to fulfill your destiny.
results.88-88: The love of your life ran off on the night of your wedding with another person. They were last seen headed to Jerusalem. Your revenge awaits you in the city.
results.89-89: A traveling merchant announced themselves as a servant of Baldwin IV to you. They convinced you that you made the best potato soup in all the realms and should be awarded for it. He told you that word was sent to the king and he awaits you to give you riches and a medal for your marvelous work. At first you didn’t believe it, but after being hyped by the entire village you set out for Jerusalem to collect your rewards.
results.90-90: After years of non-communication, your estranged father sent you a letter. He was locked up in Jerusalem because of a misdemeanor and pleads with you to come save him.
results.91-91: On a drunken night you found yourself in bed with the Lord’s wife. You ran off to Jerusalem, both to save your head and to repent.
results.92-92: The last few months have been lost to you, as if your brain was under command of someone else. You woke up in a caravan, not knowing why you’re there or where you’re headed.
results.93-93: You have been running away from someone your whole life. A long life…you have run so long that you forgot who you were running from. But run you must. That’s all you’ve known.
results.94-94: For the past year, an incredibly vivid dream has been haunting you. You see yourself looking down on Jerusalem, holding the hands of your future partner. You know this is where your happiness lies.
results.95-95: You have been bought off of your parents by some Bedouin soldiers. During one night of debauchery, they loosened their watch over you, and you ran off until you snuck into a caravan that’s headed towards God knows where.
results.96-96: You have been possessed by a fairy but you eventually became good friends, because it made your life better and eventually stopped possessing you. All along, it was feeling sorry for you and decided to help you to improve the quality of your life.
results.97-97: You made a bargain with a local seer to use his powers for gain, but on one of the darkest nights, you approached his house and heard him talking to some weird crystal ball and a vicious voice answering. You ran away and have not looked back since.
results.98-98: Your ship sailing through the Mediterranean wrecked on a small and probably uncharted island. You spent months there, and you were sure there were other people who tried to hurt you but you never met one of them. Eventually, a ship passing by saved you but you never shook the feeling of being watched.
results.99-99: You found an interesting compass from a stranger in the market. The compass led you to a tree-house, and you found a lamp in it. There was a creature in the lamp that declared that it could grant you a wish. You accidentally wished for some nonsense, a very simple thing; it actually happened, but you never heard of the creature again.
results.100-100: You defeated gods, slain dragons, fought off ancient krakens at sea, and wrestled giants at the top of the clouds. Or so you thought until you were put in a mental institution proper to the area you live. You were eventually healthy enough to be released, or did you imagine that as well?

results.1-1: Pharaonic Visage: You always have a goatee resembling the old pharaohs or a snake tattoo appears on your face if you can’t grow a beard.
results.2-2: Desert Touch: When you rub your hands together or someone caresses your skin, sand pours down.
results.3-3: Hieroglyphic Whispers: Faint, ever-shifting hieroglyphs appear on your skin, vanishing as quickly as they appear.
results.4-4: Osirian Veins: Veins on your arms and legs take on a greenish tint, like the fertile banks of the Nile, especially when you use your sorcerous powers.
results.5-5: Desert Mirage: Onlookers occasionally see heat waves emanating from your body, as if you were standing under the desert sun.
results.6-6: Anubis' Shadow: Your shadow occasionally takes on the silhouette of a jackal when cast under moonlight.

results.1-1: Serenity of a Believer: Any believer who takes a long rest in the area is under the effects of the sanctuary spell during the rest.
results.2-2: Temple’s Protection: Any believer who finishes a long rest in the area receives the effects of the aid spell.
results.3-3: Days of War: Any believer who finishes a long rest in the area is under the effects of the divine favor spell.
results.4-4: Mounted for War: Mounts that finish a long rest in the area gain 2d4 + 5 temporary hit points and have resistance against extreme weather conditions.
results.5-5: Custodians of the Wall: Even a bite of food a believer eats in the area has the effects of a goodberry spell, and members of the order have advantage on Constitution saving throws.
results.6-6: March of the Cross: Any believer who finishes a long rest in the area receives a +10 ft. bonus to their walking speed.
results.7-7: Hearts of the Brave: Any believer who finishes a long rest in the area is immune to being charmed or frightened.
results.8-8: Iron Will: Any believer who finishes a long rest in the area has advantage on Wisdom and Charisma saving throws.

results.1-1: Troubled Mind: Supernatural toxins begin to leach into the mind of the caster, slowly pushing them towards amnesia, paranoia or psychopathy. It starts with small things in their life and slowly gets more serious. Triggering spell rebound effects accelerates the process.
results.2-2: Speechless: The caster loses the ability to speak.
results.3-3: Staring at the Sun: The caster is blinded and its cornea is scorched.
results.4-4: Deep in the Sea: The caster is deafened. Each dawn its ears bleed.
results.5-5: Useless Limb: One of the caster’s limbs becomes numb and useless.
results.6-6: Rotting Body: The rot starts as just a dot on the caster’s body. It slowly grows (timing determined by the GM). If it covers a whole limb, it will make it useless. If the rot manages to cover the whole head or chest, the caster dies and cannot be resurrected. The only exception may be the wish spell.
results.7-7: Eye for an Eye: The caster loses one eye. It slowly rots away.
results.8-8: Plagued: Each morning the caster must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or be poisoned for the rest of the day.
results.9-9: Poisonous Water: Whenever the caster drinks water, it takes 2d8 acid damage. It can’t benefit from drinking water.
results.10-10: Arcane Drain: The caster slowly loses its spellcasting ability, starting from highest level spell slots. If the caster has access to multiple sources of magic (such as multiclass), all wither slowly without exception.
results.11-11: Aura: The caster has an aura determined by the GM. The aura may be visible, such as the caster may seem darker among the shadows, the light sources may grow weaker within 20 ft. of it, or similar. The aura may be an invisible one and affect creatures in a mental way, such as making people angrier, sadder, or the like.
results.12-12: Eyes among the Shadow: The caster’s eyes become sensitive to the sunlight. While in sunlight, the caster has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.
results.13-13: No Reflection: The caster casts no reflection in mirrors and other reflective surfaces.
results.14-14: Forbiddance: The caster can’t enter a residence without an invitation from one of its occupants.
results.15-15: Wither and Bloom: The caster, by touch, can accelerate or reverse an object’s rot/decay. For example a sword rusts away, a piece of bread sprouts mold, and so on.
results.16-16: Crimson Touch: When the caster touches an object, it can be ignited if it is flammable. In addition, the object may illuminate light (10 ft. bright, 10 ft. dim) until dispelled.
results.17-17: Wild Presence: The caster slowly resembles an entity from the wilds and the heart of the world. Its looks may resemble a wild beast, a tremendous monstrosity, or a vicious predator. Its hair may become green, it could smell of soil after rain, or its speech raises listeners' hackles as surely as a wolf's howl. Its nails could grow out to claws or its teeth may curve into fangs.
results.18-18: Abyssal Being. The caster slowly resembles an abyssal being, a fiendish creature. Its eyes may glow a sinister red or orange, it may give out a sulfuric stench, its skin may resemble a reddish color, or a similar effect.
results.19-19: Divine Presence: The caster slowly resembles an angelic being, a celestial creature. Its body may shine dimly in the darkness, its eyes may shine like an angel, its limbs may resemble beams of light, or a similar effect.
results.20-20: Arcane Ark: The caster has advantage on saving throws against spells and magical effects.

results.1-1: Indifferent: There may be individuals that are aware of the arcane, but the organization does not have a specific opinion on the matter, and most high-ranking members aren’t aware of it.
results.2-2: Adversarial: The organization strictly forbids spellcasting and is actively against it.
results.3-3: Negative: Spellcasting isn’t something that is well regarded. Most members are advised not to use it due to its wild nature.
results.4-4: Neutral: A more pragmatic approach to magic. The organization members may use magic and magical items and punish only those that harm the organization or its members. The rules do not interfere with members who are spellcasters.
results.5-5: Positive: The organization uses and advises practicing magic, thus having some spellcasters in their ranks, especially in higher ranks. They also have many magical items.
results.6-6: Pro-magic: The organization is based on spellcasters and has magical guild tendencies. They teach and use arcane matters in every possible way.
results.7-7: Collectors: The organization is aware of the magical nature of the world and actively collects artifacts to hide and guard them. Their primary goal can be considered thus, as they do not want these items to reach villainous hands.
results.8-8: Scholarly: The organization uses magic for scholarly means and conducts research for scholarly purposes.

Each whisper, collected from the bustling streets of Cairo at dawn, is preserved with a magic that silences them forever. They say Khalil captured them to keep the city's secrets safe, or some fairies may have collected them in the jar ´ who knows?
results.2-2:
Invisible ink quills

Crafted from the feathers of mythical birds, these quills are perfect for writing secrets that you never intend to share. The ink permanently disappears as soon as it touches any surface. Only a specially made light (with at least a 2nd-level spell) reveals the ink.
results.3-3:
A clock that only tells time in dreams

This ornate clock, adorned with symbols only visible in the dream world, refuses to move its hands in the waking world. It´s said to work perfectly in dreams, aligning with the realm´s elusive time.
results.4-4:
A compass that points to yesterday

A curious navigational device that doesn´t direct you North but to where you were exactly at dawn. It´s beautifully useless, as it leads you to a past that´s already gone. The compass realigns itself each dawn.
results.5-5:
A Mirror of Future

A mirror that lets you see what you will look like in your sixties. However, sometimes the mirror looks blank and the viewer can´t see themselves. It is said to be a bad omen: that the viewer will never grow old.
results.6-6:
A teapot that brews fog

When heated, this delicate porcelain teapot whistles quietly, filling cups not with tea but with the soft, thick fog of early Cairo mornings. It´s perfect for those who wish to sip on the essence of a cloudy day.
results.7-7:
A book of unwritten poems

Bound in leather, this book contains pages that seem to always turn blank no matter how many times they´re flipped. It´s said that the poems appear only to those whose hearts are ready to understand their meaning or the poems that are left unfinished by their poets.
results.8-8:
A set of keys to doors long vanished

These keys, each unique and intricately designed, open doors to buildings and homes that no longer exist in Cairo. Holding them, you can almost hear the echoes of doorways opening to places that time has forgotten.

The College of the Doomsayer.name: The College of the Doomsayer
The College of the Doomsayer.text:
Bard

@UUID[Item.am91fhyMoRdnlRDj]{The College of} the Doomsayer

“The end is nigh!” cries a shrouded figure - the shriek cuts through the hustle of the street. Her words burn the hearts of men who listen, her prophetic verses sprout madness in all. Death, apocalypse, and judgment are surely inevitable.

Doomsayers are an infamous cadre of bards that despoils the hearts of their enemies within and beyond combat. Just as their proficiency with foretelling cataclysmic events through prophetic verses is legendary, so too are the instruments of their choice: brutalistic grand horns, quarterstaffs with brutish religious iconography, and overbearing prayer beads with gothic trinkets.

CCCCCCC

Level 3: Impending Doom

You receive signs of danger around you due to your eldritch affinity for foresight. By spending a Bardic Inspiration die, you gain one these abilities:

  • You choose one of the following spells and cast it without expending a spell slot: augury, detect magic, detect evil and good, or divine favor. This lasts for 10 minutes.
  • Your voice is infused with magic. You can awaken the feeling of impending doom in a creature you can see within 60 ft. of you as an action. The creature must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be frightened of you for the next minute. It can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. This feature works as if you are concentrating on a spell, and it lasts for 1 minute. It doesn’t work on undead or constructs.
  • You can inspire your allies at the brink of twilight. With a bonus action, you can give +1d4 bonus to ability checks, saving throws, or the attack rolls of the allies within 60 ft. of you. They must be able to hear or see you. They can use this +1d4 only one time in the next 10 minutes and must add it before making the roll. This bonus becomes 1d6 when you reach 6th level, and it becomes 1d8 when you reach 11th level.

In addition, you have advantage on Initiative rolls.

Level 3: Tale of the End

When you reach the 3rd level, your consciousness starts overflowing with visions of the End. Aspects of these visions have taken root in your speech, music, and art. Using your action, you can start a performance and choose one of the aspects of doom below, and you can use each feature once per long rest.

Destruction

A deep voice inflicts the minds around. Creatures within 60 ft. of you that can hear you must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC or become paralyzed and have visions about the end of the world until the end of your next turn. Moreover, you can expend a Bardic Inspiration dice and roll it. You can spare people from this effect equal to the result, and they gain temporary hit points equal to your Charisma modifier. This feature does not work on constructs.

Conflict

A mix of loud and chaotic melodies invade the room. You choose up to five creatures other than you that hear you within 60 ft. and grant them either +2 bonus to their Armor Class, or they can add your Charisma modifier to their damage rolls for the next 3 rounds (limited to once per turn for each creature). You can’t choose differently: all chosen creatures are granted the same benefit. You can extend this duration by rolling one of your Bardic Inspiration dice. The extended number of rounds equals the result.

Judgment

A strong and short burst of a deep violin ranks with the sky. Every fey, fiend, celestial, and undead creature within 60 feet of you must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a fail, you know their type and location precisely.

Salvation

The hopeful voice of a beautiful woman is heard in the distance. One creature you choose within 60 feet of you regains hit points equal to 2d8 + your Charisma modifier. You can increase this amount by rolling one of your Bardic Inspiration dice. The number of hit points gained equals the result.

Level 6: Imposing Prophecy

At 6th level, the way you foretell impending doom is so powerful that you can manipulate the battlefield by using your words, dark melodies, and imposing rhythm. Using your bonus action, you can unleash a powerful melody and choose one of the effects from below:

Repelling Melody.

Each enemy within 15 feet of you must make a Strength saving throw against your spell save DC. On a fail, they are pushed 15 feet away from you. If they hit a solid object like a wall or a person during this process, they take 1d6 bludgeoning damage.

Towing Rhythm.

Each creature in a 60-foot cone must make a Strength saving throw. On a fail, they are pulled 15 feet towards you.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier and regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

Level 14: Fear of Doom

Starting from 14th level, your mere presence can reek of doom and despair whenever you wish to have it do so. Every enemy within 30 feet of you gains vulnerability to every damage type as long as they are frightened.

Path of the Otherworldly Might.name: Path of the Otherworldly Might
Path of the Otherworldly Might.text:
Barbarian

Path of the @UUID[Item.9tuLsBZQcMaqZ8DE]{ Otherworldly Might}

“What do you see behind the veil?” asks an elderly man with a faint but stern whisper in a pitch dark room. A warrior embraces the darkness around her, sharpening her senses to accommodate the darkness within, and without. She senses where the fabric of reality is torn, and with her mind’s eye, catches glimpses of eldritch entities and worldbending powers peeking from the burst stitches that connect the weave of two worlds.

With her iron will, she plucks the essence of the immaterial world beyond the veil and imbues her weapon with its power. A lethal course of action for all but a select few - herself included.

Exposure to torn reality can change people, almost always in dreadful ways, but there are warriors who use these changes to pull strength from the void, the Al-Ghaib. Path of the Otherworldly Might is a warrior’s discipline passed down through lines of warriors who were marked by an arcane disaster, or a scarring spell rebound. This discipline allows the wielders to be aware of the reality rifts around them and use these rifts to draw upon martial aspects to enhance their combat abilities.

CCCCCCC

Level 3: Otherworldly Aspect

Exposure to magic and tears in reality make you aware of the differing arcane aspects that inhabit the edge of this reality. Through mental discipline, meditation, and careful experimentation, you open your body to one of these aspects.

When you reach level 3, you can embrace one of the arcane aspects and gain unnatural powers through it. Each aspect makes you resistant to fear effects. You have advantage on saving throws against spells or other features that may frighten you.

Any saving throw required by these features or future abilities will be determined by your Aspect DC. Which is equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Strength modifier.

Aspect of the Fiend:

Darkness and madness reign in your blood. You overcame the eldritch corruption of Al-Ghaib and bent this influence to your will.

You gain darkvision to a range of 30 ft. If you have darkvision from another source, this effect stacks on top of it, increasing the range.

Additionally, while raging you have resistance to fire damage and deal 1d4 extra fire damage with your melee attacks based on Strength.

Aspect of the Celestial

Not all that the Al-Ghaib touches is corrupted with evil. You invite the power of belief and pure conviction into your body.

You can use your action to touch a creature and bless it. The blessed creature adds 1d4 to its attack rolls or saving throws for the next minute. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your maximum Rage (Also 6 at 20th level). You regain expended uses after you finish a long rest.

Additionally, while raging you see if there are other otherworldly creatures within 30 ft. of you. They have a faint aura around them that is related to their origin – for example, black for fiends, green for feys, purple for aberrations, red for dragons, etc. You also deal 1d4 extra radiant damage with your melee weapon attacks based on Strength.

Aspect of the Fey

The trickery, the overflowing essence, and the way of the eerie. Your body is now home to the secrets of the Green Gate.

You have resistance to being charmed.

Additionally, while raging you deal extra 1d4 psychic damage with your melee attacks based on Strength. If you forgo your rage after a landed strike (no action required), the target makes a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it believes to be in a situation determined by you and looks awed, and it is stunned until the end of your next turn.

Aspect of the Undead

Some sought immortality in the world beyond - most found death and despair. But you are not most - your body is infused with the essence of undeath.

You have resistance to necrotic damage and you no longer need food, drink, and air.

Additionally, while raging, you deal extra 1d4 necrotic damage with your melee attacks based on Strength, and if you die while raging, you can’t be turned into an undead.

Level 6: Otherworldly Aspect Improvement

Your body is a gateway through which the essence of arcane flows into this world. Being present in both ends of the bridge you see through the veil and sense the otherworld better than most.

Starting at 6th level, you have advantage on Intelligence checks to remember lore about arcane aspects, other worlds, and such matters.

In addition, you can choose one of the aspects below. You can take your early choice again or choose another, as your understanding and mastery over the aspects have improved.

Fiend

While raging and after you deal damage, you can end your rage early (no action required) and deal fire damage to a 20 feet radius. You deal 6d8 fire damage. Anyone caught in the area must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw. Any flammable objects catch fire in the area.

Celestial

You can use your action and your primal instincts become sharper than ever. You can discern lies for 1 minute and gain true sight for 1 round. Your damage die for your extra damage becomes 1d6 (if you chose another aspect earlier, its damage die increases, but does not become radiant).

Fey

When your rage ends (you can also end it early to use this feature with a bonus action), your fey aspect unleashes its illusory powers. It works as if you have cast a mirror image spell but requires no concentration.

Undead

While raging undead have disadvantage if they attack creatures than you (or other creatures with this feature) if you are within their line of sight.

Level 10: Otherworldly Communication

Starting at 10th level, you start to hear and understand beyond the veil, as if you have ears there. You learn the contact other plane spell. You can only cast it as a ritual and you roll a Constitution saving throw instead of Intelligence saving throw as stated in the spell. You choose one of your aspects directly, and an appropriate creature answers you.

Level 14: Ultimate Aspect

Starting at 14th level, the veil has shrouded you and you reach your ultimate understanding. You choose one of the aspects below and reach the epitome of your understanding of aspects. In addition, you can cast the detect evil and good spell without needing any material and as an innate spell once a day.

Fiend

You have Devil’s Sight (120 ft. darkvision and can discern colors in it, as well as see in magical darkness). Receiving fire damage while raging heals you 1d6, but you must use your reaction in order to do this. You may use it a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain expended uses after you finish a long rest.

If one of your allies within 30 ft. of you drops to 0 hit points while you are raging, you can use your reaction to end your rage early and save your fallen ally. The ally drops to 1 hit point instead and gains 4d8 temporary hit points. You can’t use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

Celestial

If one of your allies within 30 ft. of you drops to 0 hit points while you are raging, you can use your reaction to end your rage early and save your fallen ally. The ally drops to 1 hit point instead and gains 4d8 temporary hit points. You can’t use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

Fey

While raging you can attempt to affect your foes with great might. You can choose to end your rage early and choose up to three creatures within 20 ft. of you and force them to make a Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, they are transformed into a creature of your choice that is no more than CR 2 and stay that way until the end of your next turn. You can use this feature 3 times and gain expended uses after you finish a long rest.

Undead

While raging whenever you hit a creature with a melee weapon attack based on Strength, you gain 1d4 hit points. You can use this feature a number of times to equal to double of your proficiency bonus. In addition, if you kill a creature while you are raging, the target rises as an undead of your choice no more than 2 CR. The creature follows your orders. There can be only one creature at a time under your control (except other ways, such as multiclassing into a class with necromancer abilities).

The Flagellant Domain.name: The Flagellant Domain
The Flagellant Domain.text:
Cleric

@UUID[Item.6kM404yKcsXQ2O82]{The Flagellant Domain}

“A whip for the horse, a bridle for the donkey, and a rod for the backs of fools!”

-Proverbs 26:3

A sharp sound slices through the ungodly stagnation of the night. A follower, a believer, strikes herself repeatedly while quoting the Holy Scripture. Her blood is spilt all over the place. Her face is reminded of the ultimate serenity, and pain only flashes in the moments of the strike. Her faith prevails, and her sins are taken away with each stroke. She knows that her back is full of scars and with the memories of pain. She knows, however, that her Lord suffered more, and she finds power and might with each strike.

CCCCCCC

Flagellent Spells

At each indicated cleric level, you add the listed spells to your spells prepared.

cleric Level

Spells

1st

sacred retribution, inflict wounds

3rd

flagellant’s aid, celestial force of attraction

5th

protection from energy, vampiric touch

7th

healing litany, blight

9th

Omar’s justice, divine agony

Level 1: Wounds of Faith

From 1st level, your faith commands you to repent for your sins and remember martyrs and their pain. As a bonus action on your turns, you can strike yourself with a weapon and damage yourself. It is called “Atoned Damage”: you take normal damage from the weapon but don’t add your ability score modifier to the damage roll.

If you make a melee weapon attack on the same turn that you take Atoned Damage, it delivers your sins and the rot that corrupts your wounds to the opponent. If you hit a creature with a melee attack, you can choose one of the following:

  • You force the target to make a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, it deducts the Atoned Damage on its next attack roll or saving throw until the end of your next turn. You can use this ability a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier and regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.
  • You force the target to make a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, it takes poison damage equal to the Atoned Damage.
  • You gain a bonus to your Armor Class until the end of your next turn. It is equal to half of the Atoned Damage you took (rounded up).

In addition, due to constant fighting with infections on your body from the cuts of your flagellant rituals, you are resistant to poison damage and have advantage on saving throws against being poisoned.

Level 1: Repenting the Sins

By spending an entire long rest dedicated to your flagellant rituals and forgoing recovering hit points, you gain the following benefits:

  • In case of restoring hit points, you are counted as if you have taken a short rest. You roll your hit dice according to the rules of short rest, but all the hit points you restore through this process are counted as temporary hit points and your hit dice remain unspent.
  • You recover your Spell Slots as you would in a regular long rest. Also, if you have other features from feats, multiclasses or other sources that replenish when you finish a long rest, they also replenish your such abilities.
  • You gain +2 bonus to your Armor Class.
  • You gain advantage on Wisdom (Perception) and Wisdom (Insight) checks.
  • You have resistance against Atoned Damage.

All features last until you finish a long rest.

Level 2: Channel Divinity: Redemption from the Lord

With a divine gaze, you tear into the very minds of your enemies, making them endure the torment of every wound you bear. Your pain becomes their undoing, meted out in cruel, psychic reprisals. The more you've suffered, the more they will.

As an action on your turn, you choose up to six creatures within 60 ft. of you and force them to make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. You deal psychic damage to the ones who failed the saving throw. The damage is coming from a pool which is equal to your missing hit points. For example, if you have 50 maximum hit points and currently have 10 hit points, the pool is 40. You can divide the number between the failed creatures.

Designer’s Note:This feature is intended to work together with the Level 1 feature Repenting the Sins. Temporary hit points do not count. For example, if you have 10 current hit points and 30 temporary hit points and your hit point maximum is 40, the damage pool is 30.

Level 6: Faith is My Shield

By the time you become 6th level, your unwavering faith has forged an ironclad bond with the divine. At the very moment you carve penance into your own flesh, you can channel this divine might, turning the pain into a testament of your unyielding devotion.

When you strike yourself to take Atoned Damage, you can choose to deal full damage. By doing so, you can use your reaction to expend a spell slot to nullify the damage you took.

Level 8: Punishing Strike

At 8th level, the holy rage within you starts infusing your strikes with searing divine wrath; each blow bathes foes in sanctified agony.

When a creature takes damage from one of your cantrips or weapon attacks, you can also deal 1d8 radiant damage to that creature. Once you deal this damage, you can't use this feature again until the start of your next turn.

Level 17: The Ultimate Sacrifice

When your zeal itself threatens to usher you to oblivion's door, the divine essence intervenes, granting you a shred of their holy might and leaving you teetering on the precipice between life and death, a place where your faith shines the brightest.

If the Atoned Damage you took reduces you to 0 hit points, you regain a use of your Channel Divinity, and instead of falling unconscious, you are reduced to 1 hit point.

In addition, you are immune to poison damage and the poisoned condition.

If the Atoned Damage you took reduces you to 0 hit points, you regain a use of your Channel Divinity, and instead of falling unconscious, you are reduced to 1 hit point.

Circle of the Sun.name: Circle of the Sun
Circle of the Sun.text:
Druid

@UUID[Item.3HcovaJyHY2vSSbZ]{Circle of the Sun}

From dawn's first light, mankind revered the sun's boundless blaze; it was their deity, compass, and ensign. Those who truly understood would dare to meet its gaze, finding solace in its brilliance. Recognizing its hand in the flourishing of both tender sprouts and towering titans, they hungered for such might, forging sacred circles.

Within these radiant conclaves, a chosen few began to commune more deeply, their souls intertwining with the very essence of the sun. They became the keepers of its secrets, the whisperers of its ancient tales, and the bearers of its untamed energy, sometimes leading whole civilizations with banners beholding the sun’s golden visage, sometimes with whispers within temple complexes and catacombs. The land responded to their call, the beasts heeded their song, and from their hands, golden, blazing magic flowed. It was whispered among the shadows and sung atop the mountains that these chosen were not mere druids but the very embodiment of the sun's benevolence: The Circle of the Sun Druids, guardians of nature's most hallowed luminescence.

CCCCCCC

Level 2: Sun’s Embrace

When you reach 2nd level, you bind your soul more intimately to the sun's relentless power than any mere mortal caressed by its rays. As an action, by spending one of your Wild Shape uses, you choose one of the benefits below for 10 minutes:

Eyes of the Sun

Your eyes shine like the sun and they shed bright light in a 5 ft. cone and dim light for an additional 5 ft. Any creature within 10 ft. of you is considered under the sunlight. You can ignite flammable objects within 30 ft. of you. Any damaging spell you cast deals an additional 1d6 fire damage. This damage becomes 1d8 at 6th level, 1d10 at 11th level and 1d12 at 16th level.

Solar Touch

Your hands seem as if they are aflame with golden radiance. Whenever you heal a creature within 30 ft. of you with a spell (including yourself), you heal the creature an additional amount equal to your Wisdom modifier. In addition, your unarmed strikes are empowered, or you can imbue non-metal weapons or ammunitions with the power of sun. You can use your bonus action to conjure the flames on your hands or a non-metal weapon of your choice (or 2 pieces of ammunition). Until the end of your next turn, if you score a hit with the chosen weapon or your unarmed strikes, you deal an extra 1d6 fire damage (any ammunition used like this loses its fiery power). This damage becomes 1d8 when you reach 6th level as a druid, 1d10 at 11th level, and 1d12 at 16th level.

Molten Will

The ground you call upon ignites with your eldritch might, and the heat obeys your command. You gain resistance to fire and cold damage. You can use your bonus action to make a 5 ft. square floor a fiery ground that damages whomever that enters. The square stays on fire for the next minute or until a spell of 1st level or higher extinguishes it. You can choose creatures up to a number equal to your Wisdom modifier (including yourself) to be unaffected by the flames. Anyone other than the designated characters take 2d6 fire damage when they enter the area for the first time or start their turn there. You can have 2 such squares active at the same time. This number increases by 1 each time your proficiency bonus increases.

In addition, your movements do not provoke opportunity attacks while the Molten Will is active in at least one square.

Level 6: Might of the Golden Visage

Basking in the sun's unyielding radiance, your form becomes nigh impervious, its golden armor deflecting blows.

While under direct sunlight or while using your Sun’s Embrace ability, you gain +2 bonus to your Armor Class, and each time you cast a spell of 1st level or higher, you roll 1d8 and gain temporary hit points equal to the total.

Level 10: The Solar Form

The sun's fierce ardor and your unyielding allegiance to the circle meld, forging you into a being of transcendent resilience. The inferno's wrath leaves you untouched, and the sanctified luminance finds it hard to scald your now-hallowed essence.

When you reach 10th level, your connection to the sun and your devotion to your circle empower you greatly. You are immune to the fire damage and gain resistance to radiant damage.

In addition, when you enter one of the Sun’s Embrace forms, you can use your bonus action to change your form. You can do so a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier and regain expended uses when you finish a short or long rest.

Level 14: Scorched Eyes

The sun's blazing majesty, which once might have seared the sight of mere mortals, becomes a mesmerizing dance for your eyes. Bathed in its pure luminance, you are shielded from all radiant harm and your scorched eyes are gifted with a sight beyond sight.

When you reach 14th level, you are immune to radiant damage and gain Blindsight (30 ft.).

In addition, when you take fire damage (you take no damage due to your immunity), you can use your reaction to embrace the damage. Until the end of your next turn, as an action you can direct the damage total to a creature within 30 ft. of you that you can see with a ranged spell attack. For example, if you are caught in the middle of a fireball spell that deals 33 fire damage, you can use this feature to deal a creature (within 30 ft. of you) 33 fire damage if you score a hit. You can’t use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

The Mamluk.name: The Mamluk
The Mamluk.text:
Fighter

@UUID[Item.3t01TAmhVREV2E8H]{The Mamluk}

Upon the sun-baked sands where ancient pharaohs once reigned supreme, a lone warrior casts a shadow, his lineage tracing back to the untamed wilderness and nomadic tribes. His martial prowess, a fusion of wandering skirmishes and the disciplined techniques of Egypt, is unparalleled, turning each weapon into an exquisite instrument of warfare. In this theater of blood and brutality, they paint masterpieces of violence, elevating war to the sublime art of carnage.

Enter the mamluk, a nomadic warrior bred from the vast deserts, whose very name evokes dread. Their martial brilliance, a blend of their roving heritage and the sophisticated arts of Egypt, outshines all, turning battlefields into grand stages of their deadly ballet. Unleashed, they are tempests of steel and fury, delivering punishing blows that decimate foes. Beside them, allies draw strength, inspired by the relentless dance of the mamluks, whose every move is a testament to their dual legacy and spells doom for their adversaries.

CCCCCCC

Level 3: The Art of War

From 1st level, your faith commands you to repent for your Amidst the endless dunes and ancient ruins, your dedication to martial arts as a Mamluk has carved a path of mastery that mere aspirants can only gaze upon in envious reverie.

You gain a pool of dice that is called “Mamluk Dice,” which currently is a d8. The number of times you can use the Mamluk Dice is equal to your proficiency bonus and you regain expended uses after you finish a long rest. You can expend the die in some conditions that is mentioned here and in later levels and gain benefits from it:

  • When you are forced to make a saving throw that puts you in a condition, you can roll one of your Mamluk Dice and add it to your result. You must choose to do so after seeing the roll but before the outcome is announced.
  • When you fail a Strength or Dexterity check, you can roll one of your Mamluk Dice and add it to your result, potentially turning a failure into a success.
  • When you score a critical hit, you can roll one of your Mamluk Dice and add it to the damage.
  • When you roll for Initiative, you can roll one of your Mamluk Dice and add it to the result.
  • When an attack roll hits you, you can roll one of your Mamluk Dice as a reaction and decrease the number from the attacker’s attack roll, potentially causing it to miss.

Level 7: Battlefield Command

When you reach Level 7, your Mamluk discipline and the blood-soaked tapestry of the martial cultures you draw inspiration from have made you a beacon of command that others rally behind.

Your Mamluk Dice is now a d10. You can now use the following effects for your Mamluk Dice:

  • If an ally within 15 ft. of you fulfills the conditions mentioned in Mamluk Dice effects unlocked in Level 3, you can use your reaction to give one of Mamluk Dice uses to that ally. That ally can use the die for that fulfilled condition. If the ally fails to use the die at that moment, the die is lost.
  • When a creature has an advantage on an attack roll against you or an ally within 15 ft. of you, you can expend one of your Mamluk Dice to cancel the advantage.
  • You can spend 5 ft. of movement to escape a nonmagical restraint by expending one of your Mamluk Dice.

Level 10: Grizzled Veteran

Sharpened by the relentless desert skirmishes, your agility and force of presence becomes nigh unbreakable, defying threats that would daunt others.

You gain proficiency in Dexterity or Charisma saving throws. In addition, your Mamluk Dice becomes d12.

Level 15: Death Herself Trembles

With a rallying cry that resonates with the spirit of battles past, you summon fallen allies to rise once more. Such is the gravity of your command that even in the face of death, they heed your call and rejoin the fray.

When a creature within 60 ft. of you drops to 0 hit points, you can use your reaction to expend one of your Mamluk Dice. You roll the die, if the result is higher than 6, it is dropped to 1 hit point instead. A creature must be able to hear or see you to be able to gain this benefit, it can’t be an undead or a construct, and you must not be incapacitated. This feature does not work if the damage kills the creature outright. You can’t use this feature again until you finish a long rest even if you have Mamluk Dice uses left.

Level 18: Custodian of the Sands

In moments when your unyielding spirit defies fate, your ancient heritage compels you to surge once more, standing proud, fighting with unmatched discipline.

Whenever you use your Indomitable feature, you regain one of your Mamluk Dice.

Way of the Pilgrim.name: Way of the Pilgrim
Way of the Pilgrim.text:
Monk

@UUID[Item.YJnCNuw85qF8XJko]{Way of the Pilgrim}

In the midst of a desolate expanse, a woman, sun-kissed and garbed in simple attire, stands unyielding before the marauders that encircle her. The trials she's faced under the relentless sun have forged in her an unwavering spirit, a deep acceptance of the world's truths, and an indomitable strength. She will not be swayed by darkness. A sudden flash of light follows her movements and ethereal strings forge a mighty eagle above her arms. Within seconds, she and the eagle fly out of the danger.

Pilgrims, unlike mere travelers, tread the paths of the world driven by a purpose transcending mere destinations or whimsical wanderings. In the dance of dust and footsteps, the enlightened discover not just the world's vast expanse but its intricate heartbeats, choosing to embrace the grand tapestry of life rather than retreat to solitary introspection stop distant peaks.

Level 3: Essence of the Long Road

Tempered by endless horizons and the silent wisdom of the road, the journey bestows upon you an enlightened mind.

Starting at 3rd level, you gain these benefits:

  • You gain proficiency in the Survival skill and Navigator’s Tools.
  • You can’t be lost except by magical means.
  • While traveling, you have advantage on saving throws that force you to take exhaustion.
  • By spending 1 Ki Point, you can cast the misty step spell.
  • You can spend 3 Ki Points and 10 minutes meditating to decrease your exhaustion level by 1.

Level 6: Share the Bread

The shared hardships and camaraderie of the road have etched deeper lessons into your soul. Your presence alone steels the composure of your allies.

By the time you reach 6th level, you learned to share the roads and its perils with your companions. Whenever you spend a Ki Point near an ally that is within 5 ft. of you, you choose one of the benefits below:

  • Both of you gain +2 bonus to your Armor Classes for a number of turns equal to your Martial Arts die while you are within 30 ft. of each other. If another Ki Point is spent while this bonus is active, this AC bonus does not stack.
  • You and your ally gain temporary hit points equal to your Martial Arts die + your Wisdom modifier.
  • If you cast the misty step spell until the end of your next turn, you can include a willing ally that is within 5 feet of you. When you cast the spell, the target appears within 5 ft. of you in an unoccupied space. If no such place is available for the character, it fails to come with you.
  • You and your ally gain resistance to one type of damage for a number of turns equal to your Martial Arts die while you are within 15 ft. of each other. The damage type can be: bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing.

In addition, you can spend 4 Ki Points to cast the dimension door spell. Once a day, you can cast it without expending Ki Points or spell slots but can’t do so again until you finish a long rest.

Level 11: Hard Roads Stridden

The roads, once mere pathways, now bend to your profound mastery. Such is the depth of your expertise that you can now invoke the arcane arts to bridge vast distances with but a thought.

At 11th level, you can cast the teleportation circle and tree stride spells once (each), without expending a spell slot. You can’t do so again until you finish a long rest.

In addition, you can spend 3 Ki Points and 1 minute meditating to decrease your exhaustion level by 1.

Level 17: Pilgrim of the Promised Lands

You are now a whispered legend among seekers of sacred sanctuaries. With an ethereal presence, you materialize in moments of dire need and fade away, leaving naught but awe in your wake.

At 17th level, you can cast the teleport spell once a day without expending a spell slot. You can’t do so again until you finish a long rest.

Oath of Crusade.name: Oath of Crusade
Oath of Crusade.text:
Paladin

@UUID[Item.o9qqQiVsLdQi6Fde]{Oath of Crusade}

"God wills it!" echoes a voice, dark and haunting, over the scorched battlefields of the Holy Lands. Each word carries an omen, a reminder of the cyclical nature of existence and the mortality of men. Amidst the blood and sand, these warriors emerge, bearing symbols not just of faith, but of relentless resurgence.

They are more than just holy warriors; they are the harbingers of resurgence. Their armor, marred with the scars of countless battles, is adorned with emblems of a holy war. With blades that seem to shimmer with the promise of dawn and shields etched with tales of divine retribution, they stand as a beacon in the darkest of wars.

In the midst of clashing steel and fading faith, their presence is a chilling reminder: even in the throes of death, the Crusader fights on.

CCCCCCC

Tenets of Crusade

Unyielding Faith.

A Crusader's heart must burn with the unwavering flame of their belief. Doubt is the gateway to defeat. In every decision, in every conflict, the Crusader must let their faith guide them, defending the truth of their convictions even when faced with insurmountable odds.

Resurgence in Defeat.

To fall in battle in their darkest moments, they find the strength to stand once more.

Guardian of the Holy.

Sacred places, artifacts, and truths are entrusted to the Crusader's protection. It is their duty to ensure these remain untarnished and out of the hands of those who would use them for nefarious purposes. To desecrate the holy is to invoke the full wrath of the Crusader, who will stop at nothing to restore sanctity and deliver retribution.

Oath Spell

Paladin Level

Spells

3rd

heroism, shield of faith

5th

find steed, magic weapon

9th

beacon of hope, spirit guardians

13th

death ward, freedom of movement

17th

dispel evil and good, hold monster

Level 3: Channel Divinity: Reclaim the Lost

Your oath steels your soul against the onslaught of horrors, you stand resolute, unflinching, unyielding.

As an action, you use your Channel Divinity to renew your oath to regain what is lost to you and a divine help surrounds your soul. You are resistant to slashing, piercing and bludgeoning damage and one type of elemental damage of your choice (fire, cold, acid, lightning, thunder). It lasts for 1 minute.

Level 3: Channel Divinity: Holy Will

Empowered by your unwavering faith, you let loose a divine warcry, emboldening your resolve and shattering the hearts of enemies around you.

As an action, you can force each creature within 20 ft. of to make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC or take radiant damage equal to your highest possible divine smite.

Level 7: Divine Retribution

Your belief alone allows you to bring retribution to those who oppose you, by summoning holy flames from the aether.

Whenever an ally within 60 ft. of you that you can see or hear takes damage, you can use your reaction to expend a spell slot and make a ranged spell attack against the enemy, if it is within 90 ft. of you. If you hit, the creature takes damage as if it were hit by divine smite. In addition, if your ally did not drop to 0 hit points it gains temporary hit points equal to your Charisma modifier + the level of the spell slot you have expended.

Level 15: Unyielding Bulwark

Death is but a distant possibility for a warrior of your grit and faith - you heed its call no more, and its unholy grasp is weak upon your body.

When you take a damage and not killed outright, you can expend a spell slot as a reaction and reduce the damage taken equal to 2d8 + your Charisma modifier. The damage neglected increases by 1d8 for each spell slot used above 1st level to a maximum of 5d8.

Level 20: Sword of the Divine

Your divine essence grows so powerful that even the arms you bear are now infused with your radiant faith. They act as if they are not merely inanimate objects, but comrades in arms under the same oath, bringing divine retribution to your enemies.

As a bonus action, you can imbue one melee weapon you are holding with multiple benefits for 1 minute:

  • It deals an extra 1d8 radiant damage.
  • It ignores resistances.
  • You can score a critical hit with a roll between 18-20.
  • You can only willingly drop the weapon; external interventions can’t make you drop it.
  • Whenever you expend a spell slot to cast divine smite or a smite spell, you regain a spell slot. The slot you regain must be of a level lower than the spell slot you used to cast the divine smite or the smite spell and can't be higher than 5th level.

You can’t use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

The Sentry.name: The Sentry
The Sentry.text:
Ranger

@UUID[Item.NUWZ332fq2f2TuoS]{The Sentry}

Perched high upon the crafted stones of civilization, a vigilant sentinel casts her gaze, an ever-watchful eye amidst the urban sprawl. Though her soul resonates with the wild, the enigma and enchantment of the city anchor her. No shadow eludes her sight; no prey evades her bow's deadly embrace.

A Sentry, unlike the common ranger, is drawn to the heartbeats of settlements. Whether guarding the city's denizens from lurking dangers or lured by its manifold secrets, they tread the cobbled pathways more than the untamed trails, bound by a sense of higher purpose or captivated by the urban tapestry's intricate dance.

CCCCCCC

Level 3: Watchful Eyes

In the labyrinthine alleys of the city as in the wilds, you are at home. The urban jungle yields its secrets to you.

At 3rd level, you have advantage on Survival and Investigation checks made to find your way and follow a target and you have a climbing speed equal to your walking speed.

In addition, once per turn, when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you deal an additional 1d6 force damage. This damage increases to 1d8 when you reach 11th level.

Level 3: Sentinel’s Tricks

The city's arcane rhythms have awakened within you unique mystical abilities and arcane tricks

Starting at 3rd level, you learn an additional spell when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Sentry Spells table. The spell counts as a ranger spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of ranger spells you know

Sentry Spells

RANGER Level

Spells

3rd

find familiar

5th

locate object

9th

clairvoyance

13th

locate creature

17th

teleportation circle

Level 3: Ultimate Ambush

Harnessing the cityscape as your weapon, you command the battlefield with unerring precision. No foe can dodge your gaze, and your aim remains unchallenged, as even the shadows become allies in your relentless pursuit.

When you have advantage on an attack roll with a weapon, you have these benefits:

  • You ignore half cover and three quarters cover.
  • You can force the creature to make a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the creature gains a condition of your choice: prone, blinded or deafened. The condition stays for 1 minute and the creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns to free itself on a success. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier and regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.
  • If you score a critical hit, you roll one additional damage die of the weapon.

Level 7: Warhawk’s Flurry

With a tempestuous fury, you unleash a maelstrom of strikes, targeting a single adversary with a deadly barrage.

At 7th level, when you score two successive hits on the same target in the same turn, as a reaction you can apply one of the options:

Crippling Strike.

You cause the target to lose its balance. The target’s movement speed is halved for 1 minute.

Bleeding Strike.

You open a wound in the target. The target loses 1 hit point per turn, and for each hit it takes if its proficiency bonus is equal to +3 or below. Otherwise it loses 1d4 damage per turn and for each hit it takes. This lasts for 1 minute and works as if concentrating on a spell. If the target receives some healing or an action is spent to make a Wisdom (Medicine) check against your spell save DC, the condition ends early. It doesn’t work on creatures that don't have blood, such as constructs or some celestials.

Assisting Strike.

You distract the target. Until the end of your next turn, attack rolls against this enemy add your Wisdom modifier.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus and regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

Level 11: Vanishing in Daylight

Melding your intimate knowledge of the urban terrain with arcane subtlety, you've mastered the art of becoming a shadow, disappearing seamlessly amidst the city's labyrinthine embrace.

You learn the invisibility spell; it does not count against the Ranger spells you know, and it is a Ranger spell for you. You can cast it without expending a slot and you can do so 2 times a day. You regain expended uses when you finish a short rest

Level 15: Sundering Blows

With a profound understanding of your foes' vulnerabilities, your strikes now shatter their defenses, paving the way for subsequent blows that are even more lethal and unrelenting.

At 15th level, When you score a hit against a creature, you can cause it to have vulnerability against a type of damage of your choice. It lasts for 1 minute.

You can’t use this feature again until you finish a long rest.

The Veil Warden.name: The Veil Warden
The Veil Warden.text:
Rogue

@UUID[Item.vX5jpZ1nqzjPQ5nk]{The Veil Warden}

“He that keepeth his mouth and his tongue, keepeth his soul from distress.”

-Proverbs 21:23

In the oppressive shadows of the city's underbelly, silence is the currency of the powerful. Those who harbor the world's darkest truths wield a power far beyond mere knowledge, bearing burdens that could shatter weaker souls. Behind grimy facades and in the echoing chambers of forgotten crypts, initiates of time-forgotten orders, whispered cults, and clandestine sorcerers either stand as the last bulwark against these eldritch truths or scheme to thrust their malevolence upon the unsuspecting world.

CCCCCCC

Level 3: Power of Mystery

Within the prison of your psyche lies a secret, both wondrous and malevolent, whispered into your being by ancient voices. Mastering its weight, you wield it as a weapon or a boon, ready to unleash its torrent upon friend or foe at your merest whim.

Its power is represented by Secret dice, which is a d6. You have a number of Secret dice that is equal to your Dexterity modifier + your Intelligence modifier.

Some of your powers expend the Secret die they use, as specified in a power's description, and you can't use a power if it requires you to use a die when your dice are all expended. You regain all your expended Secret dice when you finish a long rest. In addition, using your bonus action, you can regain one expended Secret die, but you can't do so again until you finish a short or long rest.

When you reach certain levels in this class, the size of your Secret die increases: at 5th level (d8), 11th level (d10), and 17th level (d12).

Secrets’ Power

With a chilling murmur, you unveil a sliver of the dread secret you harbor. When you make an attack and don’t have advantage on it, you can expend one of your dice to give yourself a bonus on the attack roll equal to the roll of your Secret die. If you don’t qualify for Sneak Attack, you can use Sneak Attack nonetheless.

Secrets Remembered

With iron resolve, you shield both your thoughts and those of your comrades from malevolent intrusions.

You can use your bonus action to expend one of your Secret dice and choose a number of creatures equal to your Intelligence modifier (including you). You roll your Secret die and until the end of the next minute, the creatures can add the total to their attack rolls or saving throws, they can do that once with one expended die.

Secrets from the Depths

Uttering a cryptic word steeped in personal significance, you channel its arcane might.

As a bonus action, you can reach into other minds by expending one of your Secret dice. The target must be within 15 ft. of you and its Intelligence score must be 5 or higher. On a failed save, you can read its surface thoughts for a number of rounds equal to your Secret die roll. If you wish, when the reading ends you can deal damage equal to your Secret die as a reaction. The damage is psychic. If a creature is immune to psychic damage, this feature doesn't work on them and if it has resistance, the saving throw is made with advantage.

Secrets Shared

With caution, you bestow upon your allies a fragment of the forbidden knowledge you bear.

You expend one of your Secret dice and choose a number of creatures equal to your Intelligence modifier within 30 ft. of you. These creatures gain temporary hit points equal to the number rolled and gain resistance to a type of damage until the end of the next minute. The damage type can be psychic, force, or necrotic.

Secrets Unleashed

With a mere whisper, you awaken the deepest terrors within a soul.

When you hit a creature with an attack, you can expend one of your Secret dice to force the target to make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, you can use your bonus action to whisper one word. The creature is considered frightened of that word. For example, you can say sword, hat, wall, ground, even your own name. The creature is frightened by a number of rounds equal to the result of your expended Secret dice. If the creature succeeds the saving throw, you deal psychic damage equal to half the total rolled.

Level 9: The Eldritch Retribution

Bound within your very essence, the concealed truth not only fortifies your thoughts but manifests as a dark arcane force against foes.

By the time you reach 9th level, you have learned to cast these spells without expending a spell slot or a material component. You can cast each of them once a day: bane, detect thoughts, and fear.

In addition, you gain resistance to psychic damage, and your mind can’t be read by magical means.

Level 13: Gateway of the Mind

Harnessing forbidden utterances, you breach the sanctum of minds, bending creatures to your malevolent will.

When you reach 13th level, you can expend 3 of your Secret dice, roll each of them and add the results together. You have two choices:

Infiltrate the Mind

As the part of the action you make to hit a creature, you force the creature to make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, you enter its mind for a number of rounds equal to the total of your rolled Secret dice earlier. You can probe deep in its mind and learn its emotional state, goals, dreams, and secrets. The creature knows that you are in its mind. On each of its turns it can use its action to make an Intelligence contest with you. On a success, the effect ends.

Crush the Mind

When you score a hit against a creature and roll for Sneak Attack damage, you can turn the damage type into psychic damage by expending one of your Secret dice and add it to the result. All Sneak Attack damage becomes psychic. When you do so, you can also force the creature to make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, you can issue a one sentence command to it. It must obey it until the end of its next turn. The command must not be directly harmful to it or its companions – for example to walk into a chasm or a similar command. The GM has the final say on the legitimacy of the command.

Level 17: Occult Arcana

Your psyche is now an impenetrable fortress, resistant to the darkest of intrusions.

You are always under the effects of the mind blank spell.

Soul of Maat.name: Soul of Maat
Soul of Maat.text:
Sorcerer

@UUID[Item.28LSWRrd3B7CNFFs]{Soul of Maat}

In the silent annals of time, where the tapestry of fate is woven, a resonant whisper emerges – the heartbeat of cosmic balance. This is the echo of Maat, the ancient Egyptian essence of truth, order, and harmony. From this primordial concept, the Sorcerers of the Soul of Maat draw their profound power, their magic intertwined with the timeless scales of justice and morality.

These sorcerers are not mere conjurers of spells: they are living vessels of Maat, guardians of equilibrium in a chaotic universe. Their presence oscillates between shadow and light, their very souls a testament to the age-old dance of truth and balance. Every incantation they invoke is touched by the divine essence of harmony, and their gaze, penetrating and wise, reflects the eternal quest for order.

Clad in robes woven from threads of destiny and bearing staffs carved from ancient trees, these sorcerers carry a subtle yet powerful symbol – the ostrich feather, the emblem of Maat. It serves as a reminder of the universe's enduring search for balance: just as the hearts of the departed are weighed against this feather in age-old rites, so too do these sorcerers weigh their every action against the eternal scales of truth. In a world teetering on the precipice of imbalance, the Sorcerers of the Soul of Maat stand as unwavering sentinels of cosmic harmony.

CCCCCCC

Level 1: Aspects of the Sands

With ancient energy coursing through you, you call forth a primordial form, a titan of old, echoing an era when the world was young and wild.

At 1st level, by expending a 1st level spell slot as a bonus action, you embrace the form of a creature below. The form lasts for 1 minute. You gain the feature granted by it for the minute. Each time you spend a sorcery point (creating a spell slot, using a metamagic option, etc.), you can activate its effect.

Starting at 2nd level, you can use 1 sorcery point instead of spell slots.

Sphinx

You assume the form of a mighty sphinx. Feature: You are under the effects of the detect evil and good spell. Effect: You gain flying speed, equal to half your walking speed, until the end of your next turn. If you end your turn in the air, you don’t take fall damage if the fall is no more than 30 ft., and you land on your feet if you don’t take damage.

Serpopard

You resemble the legendary creatures that are half serpents, half lions. Feature: You have resistance to poison damage and have advantage on saving throws about being poisoned. Effect: Your Armor Class increases by 2 until the end of your next turn.

Sha

You resemble the beast from the underground, the blessed of Set.

Feature: You gain darkvision with a range of 30 ft. and you can see in magical darkness.

Effect: You gain resistance to bludgeoning, slashing, and piercing damage until the end of your next turn, but you are vulnerable to radiant damage.

The assumption of the forms can vary, but must have some physical representations about the form. For example, if you assume the form of the sphinx only your head can change or only your arms. The choice is up to you.

Thanks to the power that resides in you, there are some permanent effects that have stayed with you. Determine these with your GM or roll from the table below:

Maat Quirks

Level 6: Maat’s Legacy

The aspects of the Sands have grown more powerful, rendering your forms into monstrous paragons of dread and might.

By the time you are 6th level, whenever you activate a form, they gain heightened powers:

Sphinx the Mighty:

Its effect now lets you have a flying speed equal to your walking speed.

Serpopard the Mighty:

Its effect also gives temporary hit points equal to your Charisma modifier.

Sha the Mighty:

With its effect, you are no longer vulnerable to radiant damage.

Level 6: Book of the Dead

Bound in unholy matrimony to the very soul of Maat, you tread the blurred line between life and death, summoning power from both ends of the existence, in the form of an ancient grimoire.

At 6th level, you learn the spare the dying cantrip; it doesn’t count against the cantrips you know, and it is a sorcerer cantrip for you.

As a bonus action on your turn, you can spend 3 sorcery points to summon a black book or a golden scroll to your hand, and it remains there for 1 minute. With it you have resistance to necrotic damage and advantage on death saving throws. You can store your own life’s energy in it to unleash its powers:

Resonating Chaos

You can summon @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.PuPo4H4Dcxigf0fY]{specters}j within 10 ft. of you. For each specter you summon, you take 1d6 psychic damage. The maximum number of specters you can summon is equal to your proficiency bonus. When you reach 11th level, you can summon poltergeistsj (1d10 damage for each), and when you reach 16th level, you can summon @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.qoFEjfrANBdrCP6m]{ghosts}j (2d10 damage for each). This damage can’t be prevented by any means.

Echo of the Underworld

You can cast revivify without expending a spell slot and materials; then the book vanishes, and you take 2d10 psychic damage. Once you do so, you can’t cast spells of 2nd level or higher until you finish a long rest.

Doors of Death

You choose a number of creatures equal to your Charisma modifier. The chosen creatures have advantage on death saving throws.

Level 14: Power of the Sands

In the cruel embrace of the desert, you meld and contort, until the very grains of sand course through your veins, forging you into an unyielding specter of the ancient lands.

When you reach 14th level, your forms’ duration increases to 10 minutes.

Level 18: The Immortal Pharaohs

With the fury of ancient pharaohs pulsing within, death itself quivers at your feet, for you now possess the eldritch choice to tread beyond its grasp.

At 18th level, you can use your bonus action to change between aspects of the sands without expending sorcery points. While your aspect is active, when you are dropped to 0 hit points, you can use your reaction and spend 4 sorcery points to drop to 1 hit point instead. When you do so, you gain temporary hit points equal to your sorcerer level + your Charisma modifier. Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

The Weaver Patron.name: The Weaver Patron
The Weaver Patron.text:
Warlock

@UUID[Item.EbAawOR4FFoI3WhW]{The Weaver Patron}

Her hands moved with purpose, weaving a silent spell that bound a king's speech. Her smile, a subtle blend of triumph and secret delight, seemed to twist fate itself. Around her, the threads of destiny responded, bending gracefully to her silent command, making her the unseen weaver of a kingdom's fate in the heart of shadow.

Under the same dark stars, an elderly elf saw the threads of the future in mirrors, gently separating each one, delving into the mysteries of time behind the misty mirrors of fate. His raven black hair fell over his black robe covered in magical runes, perfectly complementing the hands that wove fate in the darkness.

In the heart of the void between cosmic horror and stars, the masters of predestination work the stretched strings. Legends like the Fates sisters, Norns, Shai, and Kala swirl around in this space. Some follow these legends, while others encounter a weaver in their search for power and answers. Through their pact, they aim to take the threads of their fate into their own hands. The real question, however, is whether they are merely serving a fate already written, or can they truly rebel against a fate written with their own free will?
