Level 1: Fate’s Twist

Bound to the timeless weavers, your soul resonates with the very threads of fate and the inexorable march of time, making you a living conduit of the universe's most enigmatic designs.

Starting at 1st level, you can twist the threads of fate around you, and you can do that a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier and regain expended uses when you finish a long rest.

Bound Fate

As a bonus action, you bind your fate with a willing creature within 30 ft. of you for 1 minute. During that minute, you can magically swap places or share damage. To swap places you must use your action, and the creature must be able to hear you. After you swap places, the bond between you and the creature ends.

If either of you takes damage, you can use your reaction to split the damage in half (rounded up) and divide them amongst two of you, if the creature is willing. When you do so, the one that originally did not take the damage reduces the damage by half and your bond ends.

At 6th level, your range for this feature becomes 40 ft. At 11th level, it becomes 60 ft.

Bound Time

As an action you can rewind time for a brief moment whenever you or an ally that you can see within 30 ft. of you is endangered. If you or a creature you can see fails an ability check or takes a hit, you can use your reaction to reroll the dice. If the target is hostile to you, it can avoid the reroll by succeeding on a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC.

At 6th level, you can also rewind saving throws.

Level 6: Threads Intertwined

The cryptic tapestries of destiny unfurl before your gaze, as your grasp over the intricate weaves of fate tightens, plunging you deeper into the world's shadowed secrets.

When you reach 6th level, you can magically control another humanoid’s fate within 15 ft. of you. As an action, you can force the humanoid to make a Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, you decide on its fate:

Bound. It is stunned until the end of your next turn.

Speechless. It can’t talk for 1 minute. It can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns to end the effect.

Ill-Fated. It has disadvantage on attack rolls and saving throws until the end of your next turn.

You can’t use this feature again until you finish a long rest or you can expend a spell slot to refresh it. If you expend a spell slot in this way, it can’t be restored until you finish a long rest.

Level 10: Threads Past and Future

With the arcane rites whispered in forbidden tongues, you summon the audacity to beckon fate to your circle, demanding answers from the very cosmos that dares to weave destinies in its silent loom.

At 10th level, you can spend 10 minutes and 150 gd worth of special herbs that are collected under the blood moon to make a sacred ritual known to the weavers. You name a specific event, person, war, or place that existed in the past and ask up to five questions about it. Your patron or another entity related to that name answers the questions with one sentence. The answer’s accuracy depends on the nature of the creature.

Level 14: Foretold Life

Bound to the very sinews of time, your communion with fate elevates you to an omnipotent apex, where you deftly pull and twist the strings of destiny, reshaping the world's narrative in your dark design.

A 14th level, you learn the foresight spell and it doesn’t count against the warlock spells you know or Mystic Arcanum that is available to you. Until you reach 17th level, it works differently for you. You can cast it using an action, without expending a spell slot and its duration is 1 minute. When you reach 17th level, if you choose the foresight spell for your Mystic Arcanum, you can use this feature to cast it without expending a use of Mystic Arcanum, but the spell’s duration is 1 hour for you.

School of Inventors.name: School of Inventors
School of Inventors.text:
Wızard

@UUID[Item.aqeEUyUZrDOOoSEg]{School of Inventors}

In the grand tapestry of existence, where the arcane dances with the tangible, a distinct path emerges, marrying the mystic with the mechanical. Wise and inventive arcanists from the cradle of civilization emerge, an enclave of scholars and artisans who weave together the ethereal mysteries of the cosmos with the tangible intricacies of metallurgy, engineering, and precise mathematics.

These are not mere blacksmiths or scholars but visionaries who see the universe as a grand machine, its gears propelled by spells and equations. Their forges glow with both fire and arcane energy, crafting artifacts that bridge the chasm between science and sorcery. Every creation is an embodiment of precise calculations, underpinned by age-old enchantments.

In their workshops, star charts lay beside intricate blueprints, and equations meld seamlessly with incantations. For a member of this conclave and one that follows the footsteps of minds from all corners, the universe is both a vast expanse to be explored and a complex mechanism to be understood. Their craft is not just about melding metal or channeling magic but about understanding the harmonious dance of existence, where stars align with gears and where the boundaries of artifice and arcane blur into one.

CCCCCCC

Level 2: Arcane Contraptions

You learn how to craft eldritch machines and soulless automata, forged in arcane fire, to serve as silent sentinels and inexorable allies in your quests.

When you reach 2nd level, you learn several inventions and similar useful items and record them into your spellbook, as they contain arcane power. You can prepare 2 of the inventions when you finish a long rest and use them during the day.

Inventions

You can use your action to invoke the arcane ways from your spellbook into reality and create the inventions. You must expend a spell slot to create them. Additionally, if they have a Ritual (-R) tag, you can prepare them beforehand without expending a spell slot but still must spend the cost on necessary materials. You can only prepare two objects at the same time with a ritual.

You can work with your GM for additional devices to be available for you. The GM may add some blueprints during your adventure or enables some merchants, shops, or dealers to have plans for such devices to increase your arsenal.

Wondrous Compass (-R)

This compass has interesting carvings and some personal runes carved by Al-Jazari himself. When you expend a spell slot as a bonus action while holding this compass, you can whisper a location’s name to it, and it will magically point to that location until the end of your long rest. The location must be specific and one of a kind – for example, the city of Samarkand, House of Wisdom in Baghdad, Forbidden City in Beijing, or Mahmud al-Isfahani’s Blacksmith Shop. Personal residence and similar locations do not work (for example, Farhad bin Abu Bakr’s House won’t work); the location must be a public place or at least must be known to many people. In addition, whoever holds this compass has advantage on Survival checks.

Primitive Automaton (-R)

All Automatons are in the Primitive Automatons folder in the Era of the Crusades actors

This robotic design resembles a metallic human or another creature of your choice. It can only be tiny in size, but when built from different materials, give out different benefits at different prices. You can use the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.ZQTCZfTV9ZoTjNCU]{homunculus}j statblock (Speed 30 ft., no flying speed and no Telepathic Bond) for the created automata, any changes will be mentioned below.

  • Flesh:Price 10 gd. It can turn invisible as an action and can stay like that for 1 hour. If it attacks or takes damage, it reverts to normal.
  • Wooden: Price 50 gd. Its Armor Class is 14 and has +1d4 hit points. It deals 1 extra damage. While Wooden Automaton is within 15 ft., you can cast speak with animals without expending a spell slot. Once you do it, you can’t cast it again until you finish a long rest this way.
  • Stone:Price 75 gd. Its Armor Class is 15 and has +2d4 hit points. It deals 2 extra damage. While Stone Automaton is within 15 ft., you can cast mage armor without expending a spell slot. Once you do it, you can’t cast it again until you finish a long rest this way.
  • Steel:Price 100 gd. Its Armor Class is 16 and +3d4 hit points. It deals 3 extra damage. While within 5 ft. of an ally, the ally deals additional damage equal to your proficiency bonus when dealing slashing, piercing or bludgeoning damage.
  • Gold:Price 200 gd. Its Armor Class is 15 and has +2d4 hit points. It deals 2 extra damage. While within 5 ft. of you, you have advantage on Constitution saving throws.

Firestarter

This tiny device creates fire and easily ignites flammable objects. You can use it to strike foes within 5 ft. of you. You make a melee spell attack. On a hit, the creature takes 1d4 fire damage.

When you reach 6th level, the firestarter can be used to produce other elements: acid, poison, lightning, cold.

Magical Mirror (-R)

This mirror costs you 100 gd. It works and functions like a normal mirror and has other magical properties. Whenever you activate its magical powers, shapechangers, aberrations, fiends, feys, celestials and the undead shine with an aura in the mirror (if it can’t have reflections, only an aura is seen). The activation lasts for 10 minutes and can’t be used again until the next dawn.

When you reach 6th level, when such a creature’s reflection is caught in the mirror, you can expend a spell slot of 3rd level or higher as a reaction and force the creature to make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it takes 4d6 psychic damage.

Wondrous Hook

This hook works as a normal grappling hook with some magical properties. If a silk rope is bound to the hook, its magic prevents the silk from being ripped due to weight. It still can be torn by taking damage. Also, you can use its command word for it to cling to any surface you like or summon it back to your hand.

Level 2: Aspirant Inventor

You learn how to properly focus your arcane essence to mend the broken by deconstructing the broken objects' intricacies.

You learn the mending cantrip. It doesn’t count against the wizard cantrips you know, and it has different uses for you. You can repair twice the normal size and you can do it using an action.

Level 6: Machines of War

You improve upon your arcane designs and material techniques, creating advanced automata and war engines, their cold steel and clockwork hearts ready to unleash havoc upon a world unprepared for your innovations.

When you reach Level 6, your Automata can be of medium size now and add your Intelligence modifier to their hit points when you first create them.

In addition, you can invoke your magic on inanimate objects. By spending 30 gd and 10 minutes you can give an object a walking speed of 20 feet and ability to obey one command from you (Chosen when you first use this benefit). These commands can be from prestidigitation spell or another command that would suit the object’s nature. You can issue the command as a bonus action. The object has 10 AC and 20 HP. Additionally, it can record a voice up to ten seconds and can repeat it one time. The voice recording takes 1 action and if not repeated in the next 8 hours, it is deleted immediately. You can have only three such items at the same time.

Additionally, you can use your Search action as a bonus action and when you do so, you can identify substances and materials of objects and items easily.

Level 10: Spirit of Everything

Your feats of engineering are unparalleled, and you learned how to infuse your creations with an essence of your psyche. Your machines are yours and yours alone, ready to obey your orders.

By the time you are 10th level, your Automata can be of large size now and add your wizard level to their hit points when you first create them. In addition, they gain the Telepathic Bond feature of the homunculus, but it is limited to 1 mile in range.

You have a bond with handmade objects as well. When you expend a spell slot of 3rd level or higher as an action while touching an object, you must succeed on a Charisma saving throw. The DC equals to 8 + the owner’s proficiency bonus + the owner’s Charisma modifier. The DC can’t be lower than 13. On a success, you learn the owner’s alignment and the last thought since it held the object.

Level 14: Miraculous Invention

You need but wish to craft the most powerful creatures and automate, as you now control your arcane potential with incredible ease.

When you reach 14th level, you learn the creation spell and can cast it without expending a spell slot. You can’t do so again until you finish a long rest.

Level 14: Animus

You have learned to control all inanimate objects around you and instill faint and obedient consciousness upon even the most basic of materials.

You learn the telekinesis and animate objects spells and have them always prepared, they do not count against the spells you can prepare each day. You can cast each of them without expending a spell slot but can’t cast them in this way again until you finish a long rest. If you have spell slots, you can cast them as normal.

Foreword.name: Foreword
Foreword.text:
Foreword

Dear Friends,

As we sit down to share our thoughts on the journey to “Era of the Crusades,” it’s hard not to feel a rush of emotions. We’re Sarp and Doğa from Metis Creative, and if there’s one thing we’ve learned from our adventures in creating worlds to explore, it’s that stories have the power to bridge worlds.

When we first dreamed up this project, the idea of Historica Arcanum, the idea of running a Tabletop RPG Studio, we couldn’t help but worry about being left out of the global community. We were culturally, and geographically far away - and the dread of not being able to get our voices heard was overbearing. Yet, this was one of the instances that we couldn’t be happier to be proven definitively wrong.

The love, passion, and unwavering support you’ve shown us have not just filled us with an insatiable hunger to create; they have truly made us feel that we were a part of the global Tabletop community. And for that, we are grateful. Honestly, we’re still pinching ourselves to make sure it’s real.

“Era of the Crusades” is a project that’s close to all of our hearts at the office. It was a setting that we really wanted to make since we released the first Historica Arcanum - City of Crescent. Everyone in the team, from writers to artists, poured their hearts and souls into this book, making sure every page, every illustration, and every line of text captured the essence of the story and world we wanted to bring to life. It’s with this setting, where we’ve started to really nail the dark, mysterious, and slightly eerie tone we’ve always wanted the World of Historica Arcanum to have. This book marks a significant step in developing our universe, laying down even more pieces of the lore that will grow and evolve with time and new entries to the setting.

Sharing this creation with you feels like sharing a piece from our souls. The late nights, the brainstorming sessions, the occasional frustrations, and the breakthrough moments—it’s all been a labor of love, a testament to what we can achieve together, as a team and as a community. Your enthusiasm and support light the way for us, encouraging us to keep dreaming, creating, exploring, and sharing new worlds that resonate with the depth and diversity of the human experience.

Thank you for joing this incredible journey with us. As you turn the pages of Era of the Crusades, know that you’re stepping into a world crafted with love, dedication, and a little bit of magic from everyone at Metis Creative.

With all our gratitude and love,

Sarp and Doğa

Metis Creative

Welcome to the Holy Lands.name: Welcome to the Holy Lands
Welcome to the Holy Lands.text:
The Era of the Crusades is a setting that is based on late 12th century Jerusalem and Cairo, which serve as the core of the Crusades and the war for the Holy Lands. Before diving into the setting and its magical concepts, it is important to examine the political situation and main actors of the era.

War for the Holy Lands

Since 1071 CE, the Seljuk Empire had grown into one of the most influential and powerful empires of its time, captured most of Anatolia, and threatened the very heart of the Byzantine Empire: Constantinople. Twenty years later, in 1095 CE Byzantine emperor Alexios I Komnenos reached out to Europe and asked for help from Pope Urban II to fight against the advancing threat of the Turkish Empire. Urban II was organizing the councils of Piacenza and Clermont, and the emperor’s call for help resulted in Urban II taking action. He declared a holy war against the Turks, and the crowd raised their voices high, shouting “Deus vult!” “God wills it!”

After countless years of turmoil and hundreds of thousand deaths, The First Crusade was successful; the crusader armies reached their goal of taking Jerusalem in 1099 CE from Muslim rule, establishing the Kingdom of Jerusalem. The first king was crowned as “Advocatus Sancti Sepulchri,” the Defender of the Holy Sepulchre. The shores of The Levant were carved to be the home of the Crusader states, such as the County of Tripoli and of Edessa.

For decades, the Muslim states struggled to unite against the Armies of the Crusaders, until the Zengid dynasty’s rule came to power, first as the vassals of the Seljuk Empire and ruling the western frontier of the empire on behalf of them. The Zengid Emirs succeeded in taking down the County of Edessa, which ignited the fires of the Second Crusade that eventually failed to restore the fallen County.

Zengi’s rise to power did not stop until they succeeded in taking Egypt under their control during the reign of Nur ad-Din Zengi, a celebrated hero in the Muslim world in 1169 CE. Shirkuh, a General serving the Zengis, seized the political power in Cairo, only to leave this position after his death to his prodigious nephew Yusuf Ibn Ayyub, a talented commander of the Zengis Cavalry Corps, better known as Salah ad-Din, the “Salvation of the Faith.” who is better known as Saladin in the West.

Saladin’s personal talents in both warfare and diplomacy eventually saw him rising to be the sole ruler of Syria and Egypt, uniting all the Muslim forces of the Levant under one rule.

By the year 1185 CE, the Crusaders were trapped between the Muslim powers of Egypt and Syria - commanded by the legendary Saladin. With their attempts to expand into Egypt thwarted by the Zengis and combined efforts of the Muslim atabegs, the Crusader states now faced mortal peril. Yet a new hope was found in the ascendant King Baldwin IV - though the young King’s reign would prove to be significantly short, for his body was decaying under the effects of leprosy.

The Historical Context.name: The Historical Context
The Historical Context.text:
Peace of God is under siege. The one who united a hundred thousand warriors under the banner of the Holy Crescent, Saladin, has set his eyes on the jewel of the Holy Lands, the city that represents everything: Jerusalem, Al Quds. Facing the Grand Commander is the young king Baldwin IV, valiantly defying odds for God’s Kingdom and the Holy Sepulchre.

Jerusalem

A city of great importance, Jerusalem is a sacred city for all Abrahamic religions and has been the center of turmoil, war and intrigue. It is the reason the Crusades started, and it has been held by the Crusader forces since 1099 CE. Now, the Kingdom of Jerusalem is restless, as its greatest enemy encircles the holy lands.

The king, Baldwin IV, secured a victory against Saladin a few years ago at the Battle of Montgisard and showed the sultan that the Kingdom of Jerusalem will not surrender easily. However, in the following years, the king’s sickness, leprosy, advanced greatly and left him unable to lead his forces from horseback. His condition is known to be very poor, and this greatly affects the city’s morale.

Guy of Lusignan, a powerful and proud noble of the kingdom, is a prominent figure and has loyal followers in the city. He is married to the heir to the throne: Princess Sybilla, sister of the king.

Raynald of Chatillon is the Lord of Oultrejordain and a prominent knight in the Kingdom of Jerusalem. He is usually known for his raids at the borders and breaking the truce with Saladin.

Balian of Ibelin is a courageous knight and a crusader known for his loyalty to the king and the city. He is renowned for his skills in battle and his marriage to the king’s stepmother.

There are rumors about distress in the high court. Princess Sybilla had a child from her earlier marriage, named Baldwin after the king. It is said that the king wants him as his heir and powerful lords like Guy and Raynald oppose this decision. It may create a rift between the king and some nobles.

Cairo

Where the civilization breathes, a shift in power resonates in the Holy Lands and beyond. One of the most capable leaders the Muslim world has ever seen, Salah ad-Din, seized the opportunity and united the Muslim banners under his command. He is on the cusp of fulfilling the ongoing dream of the late Zengis, the late Seljuk Sultan Muhammad Tapar, and other visionary leaders of the Muslim world.. His capital, Cairo, while a shining center of knowledge, art, trade and wealth, now prepares for a war of vengeance on a grand scale!

Saladin is the sultan of both Syria and Egypt. He is a well educated leader, a capable governor and a renowned commander. He is skillful in both art of war and the intrigues at high courts, as he proved to be when he took control of Egypt.

Ismail al-Jazari is a renowned scientist, engineer and a philosopher in the court of Saladin. He is known for his works based on robotics and engineering, as early as the 12th century.

Imad ad-Din al-Isfahani is a historian and a scholar of Persian origin. He is a close advisor to Saladin and accompanies him on his campaigns and records events.

Due to earlier failures in battles against Baldwin IV, Saladin faces pressure and criticism from the nobles and other commanders. If he fails to capture Jerusalem, it is likely that he will face strong opposition and rebellions against his rule.

Culture.name: Culture
Culture.text:
During the reign of King Baldwin IV, known as the Leper King, Jerusalem was a center of faith and a mixture of cultures. People from many different cultures lived inside the mighty walls of the city, representing the various shades under the golden sunlight of the Holy Lands. All hearts filled with belief share a deep love and connection to the city, contributing its spiritual power throughout the thousand generations.

The streets echoed with the melodies of a dozen languages; scholars debated in the shade of grim olive trees while children played games passed down through generations, mixed with other games of different cultures. Despite his ailment, King Baldwin IV was a beacon of hope and tolerance, the last light in the face of darkness. His court was as diverse as the city itself, with advisers from both East and West.

At every corner, a different scene unfolded: solemn soldiers sharpening their swords, poets quietly reciting their latest compositions, artisans crafting with meticulous care, and travelers exchanging war stories or news from all corners of the Holy Lands. Celebrations were a blend of sacred and profane, with feasts honoring both the heavens and the harvest. A banquet of flavors that mingled local staples with exotic delicacies, ensuring that every meal was a culinary crusade in its own right. Cooks were the unsung alchemists of the time, turning simple ingredients into gold with their spices and herbs.

Jerusalem under Baldwin IV was a city of contrasts, where solemn prayers were whispered in the shadow of resplendent churches, mosques, and synagogues, and where laughter could be heard spilling out from taverns and inns.

This was Jerusalem, the City of God, where all hearts of believers reside.

The People of Jerusalem

The main difference between the populations of the city is explained in the @UUID[JournalEntry.i02FgpKAFAt5qbM8]{Running a Story in the Holy Lands} section.

The Roman Catholics of the city are the core of the city, as the ruling class and most of the population follow the Pope in Rome. However, there are many individuals and groups frequently coming to join the Crusades, especially after the rise of Saladin, the most formidable enemy of the Kingdom of Jerusalem since Nur ad-Din and Kilij Arslan. Their way of life and culture has become very distinct over the last century, since the start of the First Crusade.

Western Crusaders

Eastern Crusaders

Most of them are here to join the armed conflict as warriors and advisers. Some seek gold and glory, some are sincere in their devotion to the Kingdom of God, while some of them are true warmongers.

Most of them seek peace and security of the land over victories and glory. Some of them want to seek ways that involve communication, peaceful co-existence, and more. However, they are not afraid to take up arms if it comes to defend their god, city, and country.

Most of them see Muslims as the ultimate enemy and want European kings and lords to help this cause and do not trust the local Christians.

Most of them wish to include Eastern Christians and local people to unite under the banner of the Kingdom of Jerusalem.

They are very much Europeans, and they are not used to the customs of the city.

They adapted to the culture of the East and are accustomed to local cultures and languages.

Jerusalem The City of God.name: Jerusalem The City of God
Jerusalem The City of God.text:
“Wonder,

A garden among the flames!

My heart can take on any form:

A meadow for gazelles,

A cloister for monks,

For the idols, sacred ground,

Ka’ba for the circling pilgrim,

The tables of the Torah,

The scrolls of the Quran.

My creed is Love;

Wherever its caravan turns along the way,

That is my belief,

My faith.”

-Ibn Arabi

You feel as though you can hear the cries rising to the sky from the crowd gathered in Rome, demanding to know, “Where is the Cross?” The Pope addresses the masses with all his holiness and gravitas, turning southeast with his hands and stretching his finger toward the holy lands, across the Mediterranean Sea as if you could see it before your eyes. You sense the power of a community united for a single, grand purpose. Together, you cross a path covered with fire, blood, smoke, and ashes.

The path brings you to Jerusalem.

You are between the Dead Sea and the Mediterranean. The world’s most powerful religions are here. You can see their roots, the rising trunks, and the branches that cover the world. He who died for the sins of all humanity was crucified in these lands. Moses parted the Red Sea to reach this place. David raised his kingdom here, built his temple. Heraclius, when Syria was lost, wept for this place and his heart bled with grief when he said:

“Peace unto thee, O Syria, and what an excellent country this is for the enemy!”

Omar, while praying on the stairs overlooking Golgotha, listened to the breaths the city took and felt its pulse as he bowed in prostration. When Godfrey was reclaiming the holy city and assaulting the walls with all the faith in his heart, his soldiers behind him cried out one thing: “Deus Vult!”

Now Jerusalem stands strong and powerful, hiding its fragile spirit. The city is restless. Looking from the city gates, you encounter brave soldiers, devout clergy, anxious citizens, and stone walls whose hearts beat restlessly. The Dome of the Rock is filled with tormented souls, weeping for their past lives and for the potential future of the city. In the streets washed with tears, only an ominous breeze greets you. It fills your heart with an uneasy feeling. You know the journey ends here. One way or another.

This is Jerusalem. The City of God.

Cathedral of St. James.name: Cathedral of St. James
Cathedral of St. James.text:
You almost hear a soft laughter, a sound that radiates joy and serenity. The building in front of you does its job well: a feeling of holiness and purity surrounds you. You want to smile and laugh with the rest of the cathedral walls because you are sure they are at peace and with joy. Legends may indeed be true, the queen that built this cathedral surely wanted to embrace the whole city with love.

The Cathedral of St. James stands in serenity in the city’s ambience, an important place for the Eastern Christians, especially for Armenians living in the Holy Lands. The cathedral has seen a fair share of the city’s history and was dedicated to the memory of two revered figures named James: Saint James the Greater and Saint James the Less.

The Cathedral of St. James has been transformed into a spiritual sanctuary. It reflects the religious heritage of the Armenian people and the Eastern churches. Its interiors, adorned with exquisite icons and intricate mosaics, exude a sense of ancient devotion. This sacred ground serves not only as a place of worship but also as a place for the ones that look for serenity, peace, and oneness of the heart.

The cathedral’s compound, with its cloistered courtyards and tranquil gardens, adds to the serene and sanctified ambiance. It stands as a place where history and spirituality merge, housing relics, and artifacts that span centuries. It saw many destructions and rebuilds, the latest one being under the guidance of Queen Melisende, the late queen of the City of God.

The leader of the church is a woman called Emma (Local Priest), and the cathedral serves as an important center of learning throughout the city thanks to her. Emma collects books, parchments, and similar things, and she usually teaches kids and other residents of the church how to read, usually doing this in secret. She invites scholars to lecture in the halls, and almost everyone keeps quiet about the situation. Balian of Ibelin is aware of the cathedral’s role as a place of learning, and he helps Emma personally as much as he can. Due to Balian’s help, the priests and nuns freely learn and lecture in the cathedral.

Emma has a library which, although small in size, contains very useful sources in Ancient Greek and Arabic regarding science, mathematics, astronomy and similar topics. She also has a section for urban legends and the lives of former kings and queens of Jerusalem.

Mechanical Effects of the Cathedral

Melisende’s Blessing:It is believed that Queen Melisende herself blessed the cathedral and its believers. Each member of the church has a 1d8 bonus to saving throws, and when they join the order, their Wisdom score becomes 15 if it is not higher already.

House of Learning: Members of the church, after praying in the area on Friday, Saturday or a Sunday, add a 1d6 bonus to their Intelligence and Wisdom checks for 24 hours.

Celestial Wind:It is believed that Queen Melisende stood on the highest point of the cathedral and summoned the soothing winds to heal the wounds of fate. It is believed that, at the top balconies, one could hear the Celestial Wind.

The winds are actually alive. An elemental creature lives among the high places of the cathedral and was summoned here by the queen herself. She wanted to soothe people’s hearts and ward off evil from the cathedral. The air elemental is named by the queen as Celestial Wind and uses the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.banHjKDMCegbUwYE]{air elemental}jstat block with the following additional feature:

Celestial Breath. When a creature drops to 0 hit points within 60 ft. of the celestial wind, it is stabilized and gains consciousness after 1 minute by restoring 2d10 hit points as the Celestial Wind pours its lungs with pure and healing air.

Local legends hold that the Celestial Wind is the breath of the Holy Spirit and his way of blessing the believers. There is a pinwheel at the highest point of the church, and it constantly spins. The locals believe the Celestial Wind is responsible for its spinning. There is usually at least one person watching its spin, and there has never been a report of its halt.

Check out the Quests - @UUID[.reC8jYISwpPNQvbt]{The Stolen Fire} section below for the quest that takes place in the cathedral.

Church of Flagellation.name: Church of Flagellation
Church of Flagellation.text:
“Eli, eli lema sabachthani?”

You can almost hear those words. They are around you as a whisper. Even if you don’t know the language, you know its meaning: “My God, my God, why hast Thou forsaken me?” An echo throughout the generations, first voiced by Jesus of Nazareth. It is believed in the building you face, Jesus was flogged here before Roman soldiers took him to Golgotha.

While you approach, you feel agony and pain; you experience it in your soul and on your flesh. It is very subtle, but for you, it is real. Your sins are coming together in your head and animate in front of your eyes. You remember all the vile things you have done, however small they might be. With every step you take, you embrace them all. All can be forgiven, after all.

The church is a place for redemption, repentance, forgiveness, and rebirth. The master of the church, Gabriel (@UUID[Actor.hyc7JlRpp4jTTNdg]{Crusader Priest}), has a 3rd level Flagellation Domain Cleric’s abilities and can cast the sense the sinner spell three times a day without expending a spell slot. He is one of the most interesting people in the city, as he does not believe confession is a way to repent for sins. Only one’s own flesh can repent for one’s sin. His devotion is limitless, and he punishes himself even for the smallest of crimes; thus, he has many scars. He has resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.

Sense the Sinner is a spell from Historica Arcanum: The City of Crescent.

@UUID[Item.A3fGmLyIn4QnTZVw]{Sense the Sinner}

5th level divination (ritual)

Casting Time: 1 action

Range: Self

Components: V, S

Duration: Concentration, up to 10 minutes

Choose a creature within 30 ft. That creature must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, you learn about its past sinful actions. The GM will decide what a sin entails depending on your character’s own beliefs. You learn the sins as a vision where you see through the eyes of the sinner. The most recent sin is the most vivid one; however, as you delve deeper, the visions will get hazy, requiring a further casting of the spell. The creature is not aware of the spell the first time.

If you cast this spell on the same creature again, you can probe deep into the older sins. The creature will realize someone has reached into their minds with magic in the second casting of the spell. On the third time, they will know who is probing into their minds, but you will be able to choose a direct sin from the creature’s mind (You can ask questions, like “What is your biggest sin?” “What is the sin you regret the most?” “What does your heart yearn for that you regret the most?” and similar questions.).

Class Lists: Bard, Cleric, Warlock, Wizard

He constantly seeks out sinners in the city and calls them out to repent. If someone does not join the repenting ceremony, he reports them to authorities. His dark secret is that there are sinners he does not report: the ones he believes beyond redemption. He and his followers ambush the sinner and take them below the church for their repenting ceremony without the consent of the sinner. The sinner usually dies after the ceremony due to wounds from whips and the “expulsion of his sins.”

Gabriel has many followers and people who come to him frequently to be free of their sins. Gabriel mostly teaches them his way, the way of Flagellation, and lets them repent for their own sins. However, some people come to Gabriel for redemption and Gabriel himself bleeds them, and preaches them during the ceremony. Gabriel is usually near the Temple Mount and the royal family, believing that their sins are the most destructive among all. Their sins could hurt the entire kingdom. Gabriel invests time to be around the nobles, constantly sees them on religious occasions and tries to find the sinners among them. When he finds one, he acts: Captures them without warning, plots their downfall, or reveals their sins to other great houses or the royalty.

Four of Gabriel’s followers – Rene, Alain, Marcel, and Damien (all Warrior Priests) – are constantly roaming the streets and looking for sinners. Rene is the youngest among the group and the most devoted of them. He visits local temples and especially looks for the sinners who work as priests and chaplains. He believes that those who lead the people spiritually must be purged from sins first.

Alain is the strongest among them and roams around soldiers, levies, knights, and other warriors who defend the city. He believes that the defenders must be free of sin if the city is to be protected by the Lord.

Marcel roams around the noble quarters, and he is of noble birth himself. He abandoned his roots; however, he still knows their ways and traditions. He visits castles, manors, and similar places to find sinners.

Damien is out on the streets, observing ordinary people, and believes that they are the core of the city, and if they are corrupted, the city is doomed. He also looks for false preachers, corrupt street leaders, thieves, and beggar kings most of the time, believing they are at the root of corruption.

Sacred Blaze: During Queen Melisende’s reign, a devoted Christian knight entered the church, which was only a shrine back then, and started to punish himself with the act of flagellation as a punishment for not being able to protect his comrades in battle. He punished himself so hard, he came close to death and the local priests and doctors were unable to save him. Queen Melisende became aware of the situation, and she found a way to help the injured Crusader. She found an Odparvar named Alaz(Turkish word for flame, brightness), an elemental entity, and summoned the dead comrades. When the Crusader heard the voice of his fallen friends, he woke up and the treatments started to work. He forgave himself.

The queen made an agreement with the Odparvar and asked the creature to ensure innocent souls were not too harsh on themselves. Odparvar agreed and stayed in the church. It rarely uses its powers and even the masters of the church are unaware of its presence. If a master of the church goes beyond redemption, Odparvar either exposes them or kills them in their sleep.

Odparvar’s existence and soul are bound to the church and the area, and there is a continual flame at the altar of the church called Sacred Blaze which represents its presence. Local legends and myths believe that the flame is eternal and symbolizes the birth of Jesus.

Check out the Quests - @UUID[.reC8jYISwpPNQvbt]{The Stolen Fire} section below for the quest that takes place in the cathedral.

Mechanical Effects of the Church

Blood Spilt for Sins: Inside the church, all believers have resistance to all damage.

True Alignments: Inside the church, the believers’ mind is protected. All are immune to effects that force an alignment change. Natural changes may still happen.

Ceremonial Protection: When believers conduct a ceremony or a religious ritual inside the church, they gain +2 bonus to their Armor Class and 2d6 temporary hit points for the next hour.

Tower of David.name: Tower of David
Tower of David.text:
The strongest walls of Jerusalem stand as a monumental signature to might, strength, and endurance, towering high into the sky with pride and defiance. This citadel, a symbol of resilience, remains impregnable, succumbing only when its steadfast defenders are weakened by starvation, never due to any structural failure. Its imposing presence is a mighty sight, instilling courage in the hearts of those who stand within its shadow. The walls, steeped in history, resonate with the tales of countless sieges withstood, serving as a silent guardian over the ages. Its very essence breathes a spirit of indomitable will and unyielding fortitude, inspiring awe and reverence in all who behold it.

Fifty armed knights (@UUID[Actor.LPLMyzMDoA42Euek]{Crusader Knights}) guard the Tower of David, led by their commander Bartholomew of Naples (@UUID[Actor.f9pF02mwxzLilXDl]{Crusader Veteran}, LG). He is a descendant of the first commander of the citadel and proudly conducts his duty. He and his fifty men are known as “The Custodians” by the city’s people, and their name invokes respect and authority among the people. Bartholomew can directly punish those who refuse to honor their duty among the city guards and uses the dungeons in the citadel as a place of punishment.

The Tower of David is a symbol of the city’s defense and strong walls. Every resident of the city knows that the Tower of David and the circling citadel never fell due to an attack, only surrendered by the commanders when the food ran out. Thus, most of the men constantly fast during the day and only eat small amounts of food at night. They train themselves to fight hunger and thirst.

The fasting of the knights in the Tower of David can be represented in their stablocks with the following feature.

Custodian of the Citadel. A knight of the Tower of David can withstand hunger and thirst better than most. Their faith and sense of duty fulfill their earthly needs. They need only a quarter of the water and food that a normal person requires, and they can reroll a Constitution saving throw that they failed three times a day. If they have enough water, they are immune to exhaustion and other negative effects of not having food.

Holy Thunder: The Tower of David became a place of weird stories during the reign of Queen Melisende. It was said that some soldiers could hear their dead comrades sometimes, and the place was deemed haunted. Many confirmed the story, and soldiers started to refuse to be posted at the citadel. Only one knight never left his post, and he kept watch more than he should have.

The word reached the queen eventually, and she disguised herself as a commoner and went to see the soldier. She realized the soldier had heard the voice of his mentor and didn’t want to leave his mentor all alone, believing his spirit still endured. Queen Melisende was a wise queen and knowledgeable in these matters, so she located the actual creature: it was a Viran-dahl-Asude, Voiceless One. It was not a spirit, only an elemental, and this one was harmless. It became a part of the Tower of David and always encouraged whoever fought for the defense of the tower during wars.

The queen arranged a pact with the voiceless one and named it David. Since that day, a small bell hanging from the highest tower is a symbol of courage and strength for the soldiers that defend the citadel. Whenever a defender hears the bell, they receive 1d4 temporary hit points and +1 bonus to their Armor Class for 24 hours.

Check out Quests - @UUID[.reC8jYISwpPNQvbt]{The Stolen Fire} section below to find the quest related to the Holy Thunder.

Church of the Holy Sepulchre.name: Church of the Holy Sepulchre
Church of the Holy Sepulchre.text: Check out The Sigil of Jerusalem - Act One: Rebehold the Stars section for details on one of the most iconic sacred sites in the city: the presumed location that Jesus of Nazareth was crucified and is under reconstruction by the orders of the King of Jerusalem –Baldwin the Leper King. The Church of Holy Sepulchre is one of the locations that captures most of the focus in our adventure module, and for this reason, it occupies a significant place in the book in great detail.

Byzantine Cardo.name: Byzantine Cardo
Byzantine Cardo.text:
Beneath the lengthy thoroughfare above, the expansive street of the Cardo buzzes with activity. The sound of horses and camels can be heard moving overhead. Renowned for its exceptional shops, the Cardo attracts shoppers from every corner of the city, drawn to its bustling marketplace. Shop owners find respite under the shade provided by ceilings supported by ancient Byzantine columns

The heart of the city, the Byzantine Cardo, runs through the very center, stretching from the Church of the Holy Sepulchre all the way to the Damascus Gate. This extensive street is one of the oldest in Jerusalem. Five hundred years after its construction, the Cardo was transformed into a bazaar, brimming with shops built by the Crusaders. It is a unique place where non-humans feel at home above ground, as their ancestors had inhabited the Cardo for ages before retreating underground. Most of the shops there still remain in the hands of these non-human residents of Jerusalem.

Temple Mount.name: Temple Mount
Temple Mount.text:
Temple Mount

The Temple Mount in Jerusalem stands as a monumental religious complex, central to the spiritual and daily life of the city. Dominated by the Al-Aqsa Mosque and the Dome of the Rock, this sacred area is a focal point for pilgrims and scholars alike. At this time, the Christian Crusaders control Jerusalem, and the Temple Mount holds significant religious and strategic importance. The complex is surrounded by imposing walls, and access is regulated through various gates, each with its own history and significance.

The Temple Mount was transformed into the royal palace for the Crusader kings, serving as both a fortification and a regal residence. The Al-Aqsa Mosque has been repurposed into the palatial complex, where the Crusader monarchy administers their kingdom and holds court. This adaptation of the site symbolizes the Crusaders’ dominion over Jerusalem, intertwining the religious sanctity of the area with the temporal power of the Crusader state. The presence of the Crusaders brings a European architectural influence to the complex, blending with the existing Islamic structures to create a unique cultural and architectural amalgam. The Temple Mount, as the Crusader royal palace, becomes a center of political power and a symbol of the Crusader kingdom’s authority in the Holy Land, reflecting the tumultuous and often contested history of Jerusalem during this period.

The landscape of the Temple Mount is dotted with ancient structures, gardens, and water reservoirs, contributing to its serene and sacred atmosphere. It is a place where the past and present converge, with the remnants of the Second Temple and the newer Islamic edifices standing side by side, embodying the complex history of Jerusalem and the intertwining of different cultural and religious legacies.

Most of the time, civilians are not allowed on the Temple Mount. Fifty @UUID[Actor.E0CgpeW5IWLIHZ18]{Crusader Infantry}, twenty Crusader Warriors, five @UUID[Actor.LPLMyzMDoA42Euek]{Crusader Knights}, three @UUID[Actor.f9pF02mwxzLilXDl]{Crusader Veterans}, and two @UUID[Actor.oCV22rd7effi8QlD]{Crusader Champions} guard the Temple Mount and the walls. These numbers exclude the personal guards of the royal family. For the royal family and prominent knights of the city, check out The Sigil of Jerusalem’s Characters section.

Holy Findings

As the center of faith and Abrahamic religions, many locations in the city are highly esteemed by the believers and designated as holy places. Cathedrals, temples, churches, shrines and mosques may contain some items that are touched by magic and can be encountered at such locations. You can check out the table below such items.
