Knights’ Lounge.name: Knights’ Lounge
Knights’ Lounge.text:
Knights’ Lounge

As you enter the Knights’ Lounge, a distinguished butler - as distinguished as one can be in this Era of Jerusalem - greets you with utmost poise, donning a refined uniform befitting the elegant surroundings. “Hello, dear sirs. Might I ask which Knightly Order you are associated with?” he politely inquires, ensuring a sense of exclusivity and security in this opulent establishment. As the guests state their preferences for which area they wish to visit, the butler promptly relays the information to the respective waiters in charge. The lounge poses a great distinction between the streets of Jerusalem. This is the one place knights can feel like kings. They are served and tended to. The whole place feels like a big salon of a castle.

Guided by their attentive waiters, the guests are led to their designated areas, each one carefully separated from the others to ensure ultimate privacy and seclusion for the different knight orders. In every section, the air is filled with the alluring fragrance of burning musk.

The lounge is an oasis of luxury and comfort that the most privileged clientele can find in this war-torn city, with aides and squires moving gracefully among the patron knights. Not a single tankard remains empty for long, for all hands fear a knight furious at the lack of mead, wine, or something stronger.

The knights within each section are seen deeply engrossed in spirited discussions, sharing tales of their latest noble and ignoble pursuits.

This establishment distinguishes itself from other taverns in town, as it is for the highest-ranking knights of the City. It is the brainchild of a former squire who, with the assistance of his former employer, has brought to life this opulent gathering place tailored to cater to Crusader Knights. This exclusive establishment serves as a meeting place for esteemed individuals, where one can find the presence of notable personalities.

The lounge is divided into distinct sections, each catering to the preferences of different orders. These sections are deliberately kept separate from one another to maintain a peaceful atmosphere and prevent any potential conflicts. Each section is staffed with dedicated waiters who possess an intimate understanding of each knight’s preferences and are responsible for ensuring their esteemed guests feel cherished and well-attended to.

This establishment attracts the attention of government officials and palace dignitaries, who frequent the premises to luxuriate in its offerings and engage in discussions pertaining to matters of state with the knight orders. It serves as an esteemed venue where both indulgence and business converge, providing a refined ambiance for important individuals to convene and exchange ideas.

Alaric (Commonerj): Alaric, the devoted butler of the lounge, holds the position of being the very first face any guest shall encounter. As the son and heir of the proprietor, Bernard, he has grown up in the company of knights, cultivating a profound understanding of their ways.

Now in his late 20s, Alaric has shouldered the responsibilities of demanding business ventures that necessitate long hours and personal interactions. He oversees the waiters with precision and ensures that every visitor to their lounge is treated with the utmost care, leaving them feeling cherished and extraordinary.

Hidden beneath his composed exterior, lies a passionate love for Alice, the daughter of Raynald de Chattilon. Alaric’s affection for her is profound and unwavering, and their connection remains alive through correspondence carried out by a close knight friend in whom Alaric places unwavering trust.

Talea (Commonerj): Talea, an unassuming maid in the lounge, possesses a demure appearance with short, raven-black hair, a petite figure, and captivating green eyes. Her unremarkable looks render her easily overlooked, allowing her to navigate unnoticed through the lounge’s daily chores. Yet behind her unassuming façade lies a remarkable talent that sets her apart from others – the ability to glean valuable information by stealthily eavesdropping on the knights’ conversations. This unique skill has made her one of the most knowledgeable individuals not only within the lounge but perhaps even across the entire country, for she holds within her grasp the whispers and secrets of those around her.

Talea’s lineage is entwined with the intrigue of nobility, as she is the illegitimate daughter of Ferdinand, the right-hand man to the esteemed Tiberius. Ferdinand’s devotion to Talea’s late mother, whom he deeply loved, led him to care for her even in her absence. Though unable to take her under his wing as his own, Ferdinand ensured that she received the utmost care and placed her in the trustworthy hands of Bernard, a close friend.

Talea’s bond with her father figure, Ferdinand, remains strong, and it is through this connection that she wields such unparalleled insight. The secrets she uncovers, often shared among the knights, flow back to Ferdinand, granting him the most discerning ear in all of Jerusalem.

The Archbishop (Tavern).name: The Archbishop (Tavern)
The Archbishop (Tavern).text:
The Archbishop (Tavern)

As you step inside the Archbishop, a sense of tranquility washes over you, enveloping you in a soothing embrace. The lively atmosphere is filled with the cheerful chatter of guests, creating a warm ambiance that immediately puts you at ease.

To your surprise, you notice some children, clad in inn attire, diligently assisting guests with their luggage. Their youthful enthusiasm and helpfulness add a charming touch to the already welcoming scene.

A man dressed like a priest comes bustling towards you, extending a warm greeting. “Welcome to our humble abode. You can call me Slade. How may we help you today?” His demeanor exudes hospitality as he guides you towards a cluttered desk adorned with a messy box of keys. With a slightly flustered air, he delves into the box, recounting the available rooms and their unique features. Despite his earnest effort, finding the right keys proves to be a challenge.

From behind him, his wife, Eden, pops out, wiping her hands on a dirty apron. “There you go.” She immediately finds the keys he has been looking for. “I hope you enjoy your stay here. And if you ever need something, and these three buffoons that are supposed to run this place can’t manage to get it done, I’ll be in the kitchen,” she chuckles.

As she retreats back into the kitchen, the door opening only for a moment, the most mouthwatering aroma fills the air, leaving you eager to experience the culinary delights that await.

The Archbishop holds a special place in the Christian quarter, attracting visitors for its exceptional ambiance. It was established by a group of former priests who made the personal decision to leave the priesthood. Their reasons varied: one fell in love and chose to pursue marriage, another experienced a shift in their beliefs and no longer held faith in God, while another simply had an unwavering love for alcohol. United by their shared experiences, they came together to create an inn that emulated the atmosphere of a monastery, maintaining the customs and even donning familiar uniforms that brought them comfort.

The Archbishop offers standard rooms to accommodate their guests, with the charges varying based on the owners’ affinity for each individual visitor. If the owners take a liking to a guest and learn of their need for accommodation despite limited finances, they may offer a considerable discount or even a complimentary stay. These rooms comfortably house 2-4 people and provide a cozy and welcoming environment.

The Archbishop’s reputation is further bolstered by the delectable meals prepared by one of the owners’ wives. With three courses of delicious cuisine, guests are treated to a memorable dining experience that adds to the overall charm of the establishment.

It is worth mentioning that the inn carries a distinct aroma due to the presence of a makeshift brewery located in the basement. This brewing operation contributes to the unique character of the place, creating an atmosphere that is both intriguing and aromatic.

Blake (@UUID[Actor.kDX72EozbFjhaiYT]{Local Priest}): Blake spent the initial four decades of his life as a priest in a quaint village situated just outside Jerusalem. Being the son of a priest, it seemed only natural for him to follow in his father’s footsteps. Until the age of 20, he resided in a monastery, and thereafter, he returned to his village to assume the role of a priest in the church, taking over from his retiring father. Their relationship was a complex yet deeply close bond. Blake held his father in utmost respect and adoration, but also couldn’t shake the fear that arose from his father’s stern and austere demeanor.

Unfortunately, after a few peaceful years, tragedy struck as Blake’s father passed away from an unidentified ailment. The swift and unexpected nature of his father’s death left Blake grappling to come to terms with it. Haunted by memories, he felt as if his father’s presence lingered, haunting him, questioning his worth just as he had during Blake’s childhood. Seeking solace, Blake turned to alcohol, finding temporary relief from his distress when he was intoxicated enough not to see the haunting visions. Regrettably, this coping mechanism eventually spiraled into a serious issue, leading to him falling asleep during masses and even behaving aggressively towards his own community.

In recognition of the deep respect he held for his community and the importance of his role as a priest, Blake voluntarily stepped down from his position. He couldn’t bear the thought of tarnishing the sacred space with his drunken state. Subsequently, he encountered others who, like him, had left the priesthood due to personal reasons. These kindred spirits provided Blake with a place where he could find respite from the burdens of social responsibilities and expectations.

Oswald (@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.PVD5wRdyO7iCJPs1]{Priest}j): When Oswald was a child, he experienced something inexplicable. He fell from a cliff, and just as he was certain he would meet his demise, he began to float miraculously. He floated all the way to the bottom, where he encountered a woman. Curious about this extraordinary event, he asked her for an explanation. The woman seemed panicked and attributed it to the work of God. Despite facing skepticism from others, Oswald remained devoted to the God he believed had saved him. As time passed, he pursued the path of becoming a priest in his quest to comprehend this divine occurrence. However, even religion could not provide an adequate explanation for the phenomenon.

Driven by an insatiable desire for answers, Oswald delved into more arcane readings. Through his studies, he gradually came to realize that the inexplicable event had nothing to do with God; it was magic! As his knowledge of magic expanded, his belief in God dwindled.

Eventually, Oswald reached a critical juncture where he recognized that since he no longer believed in God, his priestly work had lost its meaning. With deep remorse, he apologized to his community and decided to step away from his religious calling. Returning to his family home, he sought solace, and it was then that his uncle shared news of a house he owned in Jerusalem. Generously, his uncle offered him the property, suggesting that Oswald try his luck and see what he could make of it.

Taking a leap of faith, Oswald embarked on a journey to Jerusalem. Along the way, fate brought him into the company of Slade and Blake, both ex-priests like himself, who shared similar customs they had acquired during their time in the monastery. They, too, were looking for a new purpose in life, and they all found it in The Archbishop.

Slade (@UUID[Actor.kDX72EozbFjhaiYT]{Local Priest}): Slade had spent his entire life within the walls of a monastery, having been left there as a baby. Raised and nurtured by the compassionate nurses, he led a life of unwavering devotion to his beliefs, never once questioning them. At the tender age of 13, he solemnly took a vow of celibacy, embracing a path of spiritual dedication. However, destiny had other plans when he encountered Eden.

It was in the bustling marketplace where Eden showcased the bounties of her garden that their paths intertwined. Slade found himself drawn to her presence and the connection they shared during their fruit transactions. Each visit to the market brought an increasing sense of excitement, and their conversations grew longer and more intimate. Initially convincing himself that theirs was to be a wonderful friendship, Slade’s heart couldn’t deny the blossoming love he felt for Eden. As their bond deepened, he yearned to marry her.

But the rigid rules of his monastery came crashing down on him, confronting him with the ultimatum: his sacred priesthood or the love of Eden. Unable to bear the thought of losing her, Slade reluctantly severed ties with Eden, heartbroken and conflicted. The weeks turned into months, and the ache in his soul grew unbearable. Finally, on one fateful night, unable to suppress his feelings any longer, he composed a heartfelt letter renouncing his priesthood and gathered his belongings. Determined to forge a new life with Eden, he took her hand, and together, they journeyed to Jerusalem, seeking a fresh beginning.

During their travels, fate brought them in contact with Oswald, a fellow soul who had also abandoned the priesthood. In the warm ambiance of an inn, Slade and Oswald exchanged stories of their journeys and aspirations. Oswald spoke of an abandoned house, left behind by his uncle in Jerusalem, and his dreams of transforming it into a thriving inn. Engrossed in dreams of what could be, they contemplated the possibilities of this hypothetical inn and whether their dreams could indeed become a reality.

Eden (@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.SqZRuJ8lt2KGJBbq]{Commoner}): Eden, a farmer’s daughter, spent the majority of her life toiling in her bountiful garden and selling its delicious fruits. It was during this routine existence that she crossed paths with Slade. Despite hailing from a halfling family, Eden stood as the tallest among them all, leading Slade to mistakenly perceive her as a short woman due to his towering height in comparison.

Within the confines of the kitchen, Eden’s prowess was truly exceptional. With just a hint of magic, she would enhance the flavors of her culinary creations, leaving patrons of The Archbishop utterly enchanted and flocking in large numbers. Her skills in the culinary arts were rivaled only by her talent in creating a warm and welcoming home, effectively assuming the role of the inn’s heart and soul. As the three men responsible for the inn’s operations proved woefully inadequate, she single-handedly shouldered the responsibilities, ensuring its smooth running.

The Knight Nurse.name: The Knight Nurse
The Knight Nurse.text:
The Knight Nurse

Upon stepping into the Knight Nurse, the first thing to capture your attention is a tall woman, vigorously hammering away at a sword with astonishing strength. Her lustrous blond hair cascades down her shoulders, some strands clinging to her forehead with perspiration, creating a radiant glow in the golden light of the molten iron.

The walls of the shop are decorated with an awe-inspiring display of incredible weapons, each boasting intricate craftsmanship that commands admiration. Hanging on the back wall is a portrait of the woman and, presumably, her father, both smiling warmly at the arrival of a new customer.

As she becomes aware of your entrance, her demeanor transforms unexpectedly from imposing to effervescent. Despite her striking presence, she exudes a certain charm that captivates. “Hello there. How may I be of assistance? Please feel free to explore; many of the pieces on the walls are available for purchase.”

The owner of the Knight Nurse, Sylvia (@UUID[Actor.1JK80RxGJvsa6UG4]{Artisan}), has gained considerable renown for her exceptional craftsmanship and durable creations. As the daughter of a skilled blacksmith, she began her apprenticeship at a young age, learning the trade under her father’s guidance. When her father eventually became unable to continue due to age, she assumed responsibility for the business.

Driven by a thirst for knowledge and a desire to expand her skills, the blacksmith embarked on journeys throughout the region, seeking out mages to learn arcane secrets. Through these encounters, she acquired a deep understanding of magic and its applications. This newfound knowledge allowed her to infuse magic into select weapons she crafted, creating extraordinary pieces imbued with additional properties and abilities.

The blacksmith is discerning in the distribution of these magical creations, reserving them exclusively for a select group of trusted customers. Word of mouth serves as the primary means of attracting clients to her forge, as those fortunate enough to have used her enchanted weapons recognize the unparalleled quality they possess. Any weapon bought from or reinforced here is infused with magic and grants an additional 1d4 radiant damage for the next 24 hours. Every infusion costs 25 gold dinars.

Steeds of the Cross Farrier & Stables.name: Steeds of the Cross Farrier & Stables
Steeds of the Cross Farrier & Stables.text:
Steeds of the Cross Farrier & Stables

As you step into the Steeds of the Cross Farrier & Stables, the sounds of horses contentedly munching on wheat and moving about greet your ears. Surprisingly, the air carries a pleasant aroma despite the presence of horse stalls. This unexpected fragrance is a result of incense burning in every corner, thoughtfully used to purify the air and create a calming atmosphere. The farrier, who appears to be the one responsible for this ingenious idea, notices your interest in the incense and shares, “It calms the horses down. This place used to be an abandoned pagan temple. I discovered a good stock of these in one of the chambers, and to be honest, I could barely tolerate the stable’s natural scent before.”

With a warm and welcoming smile, he approaches you and inquires, “How do you do? How may I be of service? We have some robust and reliable steeds available for purchase or rent. Additionally, I am skilled as a farrier, so if you need any horseshoes or hoof care, I am here to assist.”

As you take a step closer to the farrier’s desk, an inexplicable sensation washes over you – the feeling of being watched. Instinctively, you turn your head to scan the surroundings, searching for the source of this peculiar feeling. The stable seems tranquil, the horses continuing their peaceful activities, and the farrier focused on tending to his work.

The Steeds of the Cross Farrier & Stables hold a captivating history, once being an ancient pagan temple that lay dormant for many generations. It caught the attention of a young and ambitious farrier seeking a suitable space to establish his business. With a mix of courage and curiosity, he claimed the temple as his own, clearing out the interior and relocating the shrines and sacred scriptures to a hidden chamber beneath the ground. In their place, he constructed functional stables, transforming the once sacred space into a practical and bustling establishment.

Yet the farrier’s presence in the temple does not go unnoticed. Whenever he walks by the concealed chamber, where the pagan iconography and relics now rest, an eerie sensation of being watched washes over him.

Esmond (@UUID[Actor.XiG03vgMTRXPTmh9]{Wilderness Commoner}): Esmond had spent a decade as a dedicated farrier apprentice, learning the trade from an old friend of his father. With each passing year, his passion for the craft grew, and he developed innovative ideas to improve the business. However, his employer refused to let go of the reins and hand over the business, no matter how much Esmond insisted or how patiently he waited. After a particularly heated argument, Esmond made the tough decision to quit, leaving him unemployed and disheartened.

For a while, he wallowed in his situation, feeling lost and directionless, until his father decided it was time for Esmond to seek a new job, and pushed him to leave the comforts of home. Esmond, though, yearned to be his own boss and embarked on a journey around town, searching for a place to turn into his own shop. However, he faced repeated disappointments as he couldn’t afford any suitable locations.

In his search, fate led him to an abandoned building, which appeared to be an ancient pagan temple left to decay over time. Esmond saw potential in this forgotten structure and set to work clearing out any remnants of its past, converting it into a stable. Being naturally adept at caring for horses, word spread about his skills, and people began to flock to his establishment, aptly named “Steeds of the Cross.”

Little did Esmond know that during this transformation, he had unwittingly attracted the attention of a mystical being – Rahul (check out the Chor statblock in the Appendix), a djinni who had crossed over to our world in search of a hidden artifact. Rahul became enamored with Esmond’s presence and started watching him closely. Captivated by Esmond’s everyday life and the way he tended to horses, Rahul felt an undeniable love and decided to bind himself to Esmond to avoid being banished from the mortal realm. With unwavering determination, he pledged to shield Esmond from any who sought to cause him harm.

Despite the supernatural presence around him, Esmond remained unaware of Rahul’s existence. He could sense a strange energy at times and noticed some peculiar physical changes, like patches of his skin losing melanin, but he dismissed them as mere quirks. Oblivious to the djinni’s affectionate watchfulness, Esmond continued to pour his heart and soul into his newfound stable, focusing on building his business and establishing himself as an independent farrier, never imagining the magical companion he had gained along the way.

Quests.name: Quests
Quests.text: These quests can take place within the adventure module The Sigil of Jerusalem or can be treated as standalone stories.

The Stolen Fire.name: The Stolen Fire
The Stolen Fire.text:
The Stolen Fire

Recommended Level: 3-4

Quest Summary:A bard named Dankaran traveled all the way from Mali to steal “elements in prophecies” in Jerusalem. He managed to trap theSacred Blaze in the Church of Flagellation, and no fire can be created in the subsequent area. He must also capture the Celestial Wind and Holy Thunder from the @UUID[.K1RcDqGepPURAlt1]{Cathedral of James} and @UUID[.UQ698t8bPyvU6G8w]{David’s Tower}.

Possible Rewards: 300 gd, uncommon magic items for each party member.

The master of the Church of Flagellation, Father Gabriel, informs the city guard that the Sacred Blaze is extinguished, and it can’t be lit again. The locals find out that within a 100 meter area, no flames can be produced, not even the candles can be lit. Even the people with knowledge of arcane business can’t create flame, fire, or anything of the sort. Most of the guards and knights prove to be useless in solving the mystery, and Father Gabriel offers a good payment to anyone who solves it.

The Sacred Blaze has been stolen by Dankaran, an interesting persona and a powerful bard hailing from the lands of Mali in West Africa. He crossed the Sahara desert with a group of travelers for the sole purpose of visiting the Holy Lands. He is following a legend he heard from a Muslim merchant: The Sacred Blaze, the Celestial Wind, and the Holy Thunder are the keys to resurrect the most beautiful queen, and she will take the one that resurrected her as her king, and they will ascend to the heavens.

He will stay at the Qadim Hookah and has a room there under a false name: Bilal al-Sawt Jabbar (a character that can speak Arabic knows immediately that this name means “Strong-Voiced Bilal,” or a DC 10 Intelligence checks can also reveal this information if anyone doesn’t speak Arabic.).

Dankaran has a magic item called the Necklace of Binding. With its ability, he can bind the elementals inside it and thus come one step closer to achieving the prophecy mentioned in the legend.

@UUID[Item.p1hWqFdds1uc6I8B]{Necklace of Binding}

Wondrous item, very rare, requires attunement

The necklace has African totems and weavings made out of bone, wood, and straw. The totems symbolize the unity of air, clouds, and the hearth of the tribe.

It has three tiny skulls. They represent the bound elementals of the necklace. Using an action, you can target an elemental with a CR equal to or below 5 within 60 ft. of you that you can see. The elemental must succeed on a DC 15 Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, it is trapped within one of the skulls. You can have three elementals trapped in the skulls like this.

Once trapped, an elemental remains in the necklace until released. An elemental trapped in the necklace doesn’t need to breathe, eat, or drink and doesn’t age.

You can use an action to touch the necklace’s skulls and release the elemental it contains. The creature is friendly to you and your companions for 1 hour and obeys your commands for that duration. If you give no commands or give it a command that is likely to result in its death, it defends itself but otherwise takes no actions. At the end of the duration, the creature acts in accordance with its normal disposition and alignment.

An identify spell reveals that a creature is inside the necklace, but the only way to determine the type of creature is to activate the skull. A newly discovered necklace might already contain a creature/creatures chosen by the GM.

Dankaran arrived in Jerusalem a few weeks ago and started researching the mentioned elementals. He asked around and talked with many scholars, priests, and civilians. At Emma’s library (the priestess at the Cathedral of St. James), he found a book about Queen Melisende’s life, and he became sure the legendary queen from the prophecy was she.

He traveled to the Church of Flagellation and trapped the Odparvar in the church with his necklace by making sure to change his appearance beforehand.

@UUID[Actor.GPCzBmYzUfYywkBr]{Dankaran}

Medium humanoid (human), chaotic neutral

Armor Class 15 (Studded Leather Armor)

Hit Points 65 (10d8 + 20)

Speed 30 ft.

STR

8 (-1)

DEX

16 (+3)

CON

14 (+2)

INT

13 (+1)

WIS

11 (+0)

CHA

19 (+4)

Saving Throws Dex +6, Cha +7

Skills Deception +10, Persuasion +7, Performance +10

Senses passive Perception 10

Languages Bambara, Arabic, Turkish, French

Challenge 6 (2,300 XP)

Wonderful Illusions. When Dankaran casts an illusion spell, a creature makes the Intelligence or Wisdom checks with disadvantage, regarding whether the illusion depicts something real or not.

Spellcasting. The enchanter casts one of the following spells, using Charisma as the spellcasting ability (spell save DC 15):

At will: friends, mage hand, dancing lights, vicious mockery (3d4)

3/each day: alarm, expeditious retreat, healing word, disguise self, sleep (2nd level)

2/day each: charm person, hold person, invisibility, suggestion, tongues

Actions

Multiattack. Dankaran makes three Vicious Arcana attacks.

Vicious Arcana. Melee or Ranged Spell Attack: +7 to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 120 ft., one target. Hit: 9 (1d10 + 4) psychic damage.

Reactions

Instinctive Charm (Recharge 4–6). When a visible creature within 30 feet of Dankaran makes an attack roll against him, Dankaran forces the attacker to make a DC 14 Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the attacker redirects the attack to the creature closest to it, other than Dankaran or itself. If multiple eligible creatures are closest, the attacker chooses which one to target.

Unless interrupted, the events will unfold as follows:

  1. Due to the ongoing investigation about the stolen fire at the Church of Flagellation, Dankaran will stay low for a few days, as he does not want any unwanted attention.
  2. He will search the place where other elementals are and the place where he should bring the elementals to resurrect Queen Melisende.
  3. He will learn that Celestial Wind is in the Cathedral thanks to another visit to Emma’s library to return the book he took. He will also find out about the bell at the Tower of David from a Local Priest called Alexander.
  4. He will attempt to bind the Celestial Wind. If adventurers intervene, you can have the Celestial Wind roll for the save. If not, the roll automatically fails in the favor of Dankaran.
  5. With the Celestial Wind gone, the area (100-meter radius) around the Cathedral will see no wind.
  6. He will invite Alexander to the inn where he stays and will want to gather further information. He will kill Alexander after he becomes suspicious of the deeds Dankaran has done.
  7. He will travel to the Tower of David and will be interrupted by Bartholomew. They will fight, and Dankaran will summon any elemental forces he has. If the adventurers aren’t around, he will steal the Holy Thunder without any trouble and kill Bartholomew.
  8. With the Holy Thunder gone, people that are in the area (50-meter-radius) the moment the Voiceless One is trapped will lose the ability to speak or be deafened (GM’s choice, both effects could have an impact on different people. For example, ten civilians may be deafened while other twenty civilians may lose the ability to speak). After that, any creature who speaks really loudly or screams must succeed on a DC 10 Wisdom saving throw or lose the ability to speak or be deafened (GM’s choice for each time).
  9. He will travel to the Tomb of Virgin Mary, where he will sacrifice the three elementals and resurrect the Queen.

Note: Dankaran will use the disguise self spell or other spells at his disposal whenever it is necessary.

The resurrection part of the legend is false. The original legend was that if three elementals gather at the Tomb of Virgin Mary, Queen Melisende’s memories will guide them to a very precious magic item she found when she was young: the Crown of Shahryar (Check out the Items section). The queen, if she deems the person worthy, will let a successor use the crown for better purposes. This information can be gathered at the library from a Latin text which can be found with a DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) or Wisdom (Perception) check.

Tomb of Virgin Mary

The Tomb of Virgin Mary is a legendary place and the burial site of Queen Melisende.

Preceded by a walled courtyard to the south, the cruciform church shielding the tomb has been created in part by cutting through the rock and in part with masonry, and is entered by a wide descending staircase. The staircase is protected by two Crusader Infantry, but they will let a disguised Dankaran in. He will sacrifice and kill all three elementals at the altar of the church (a 20x50 ft. room) and will awaken the wrath of Queen Melisende.

Queen Melisende’s power will awaken and kill Dankaran immediately. Now that the elementals are gone, the effects will be permanent in the city.

Possible Resolutions

If Dankaran learns the true legend, he will stop his actions. If he committed the murder of Alexander, he would attempt to run. Otherwise, he can be convinced to let go of the elementals he stole if he is promised that he can leave the city safely. He can also be easily persuaded to pursue the Crown of Shahryar peacefully with the adventurers, if he is the one to get the item.

  • If the adventurers wish to complete the legend on their own, the elementals must demand something in return. Holy Thunder will ask for the most beautiful voice it can hear. Sacred Blaze will demand the confession from the most innocent person in the city. Celestial Wind will demand a hundred children’s laughter.

The Hunt.name: The Hunt
The Hunt.text:
The Hunt

Recommended Level: 3-4

Quest Summary: Sir Arnold, a Knight Hospitaller, searches for adequate warriors to help him hunt down a creature. He is actually looking for a new and interesting mount that he can tame in the wilderness.

Sir Arnold (who was mentioned in the Knights Hospitaller section) is an expert when it comes to mounts and desires to find one in the vast wilderness surrounding the Holy Lands. He collects tales, legends, and folklore and constantly speaks to pilgrims and other travelers for sightings of interesting creatures that can be possible mounts.

He has two leads:

  1. A mighty and silver-colored creature that is captured by bandits in a small forest nearby.
  2. A dragon lurks in a small pond that was observed by some travelers and won’t let anyone come close.

1) The silver creature

The creature is actually an @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.jLPhaBnMtAbB5dp1]{elephant}. His owner, a Ghulam from Gazne, died in a military raid to the Holy Lands months ago, and the elephant went free after this. However, the elephant was captured by bandits and used in some ambushes and operations.

The base of the thieves is located within the forest and consists of many wooden houses built upon trees. The elephant is held in a metal cage on the ground that barely fits it with a giant lock (DC 20) on the gate. The keys are in the hands of the @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.rb7OJt822wIO52qY]{Bandit Captain}j. The cage has four Bandits that protect it. Inside the houses, there are a total of eleven @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.n4TEv7inVUkyZviN]{bandits}j and two @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.O3ABqI55Ir1du1Xa]{scouts}j. Additionally, there are three captives: one @UUID[Actor.UoXXok5SHNGW7elg]{pilgrim}, one @UUID[Actor.ECOUFdkzqvyqDO4M]{Mamluk Sentinel}, and one @UUID[Actor.kDX72EozbFjhaiYT]{local priest}. If freed, all of them are willing to help against the bandits.

If freed and alive, the elephant can be tamed by Sir Arnold.

2) The dragon at the pond

The travelers observed “a dragon” in a high place. It is actually an awakened @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.9bHoR8k5D2DKHaF3]{giant eagle} named Ferazhal (The bright feather), a rare beast enlarged by the magical nature of the pond. The giant eagle was awakened ten years ago by a druid companion, the protector of the pond. The druid was a good woman named Behiye, who took care of animals and beasts in danger, especially those on the brink of extinction. The giant eagle spent a long time with Behiye and each day, Behiye spoke to the eagle as if it could understand her. In time, Behiye was able to cast the awaken spell on the eagle when she found a valuable agate (the material needed for the awaken spell), and they became good friends afterwards, and they even accumulated a small library together. Behiye was a very intelligent woman and had written many scrolls, also teaching Ferazhal how to use them if necessary (disguise self, shield, alarm, goodberry, hold person, protection from evil and good scrolls).

Behiye was killed by some hunters years ago, and many of the endangered species are now gone from Behiye’s home at the pond. Ferazhal mourned for a long time and wanted to continue the deeds of Behiye and started to adopt animals as well as infant humans; it saved at least five children from hunger and extreme weather conditions in the last year. Ferazhal is very suspicious of the incoming humans and usually drives them off by disguising itself as a dragon with the disguise self spell scrolls.

However, the so-called dragon at the pond is attracting other hunters. A group of hunters (4 @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.O3ABqI55Ir1du1Xa]{Scouts}j) led by the bounty hunter Henry (@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.13K3XK2A3wwxVKLD]{Spy}j, CN) will also try to take down this dragon. Henry is sure that the dragon is not an actual dragon and guesses the monster is actually a beast. If the adventurers save Ferazhal from Henry, Ferazhal will teach Sir Arnold how to tame giant eagles. Additionally, if the adventurers accept, it will deliver the infant children if they can be put in good hands in the city. Sir Arnold will offer protection for the children himself.

Off With Your Head.name: Off With Your Head
Off With Your Head.text:
Off With Your Head

Recommended Level: 3-4

Quest Summary:A knight in green intervenes in a knightly order’s meeting in a small keep and challenges a knight. The knight named Gwalchmei (@UUID[Actor.LPLMyzMDoA42Euek]{Crusader Knight}) beheads the knight in green, but it doesn’t die (because it is a @UUID[Actor.dhQ9S586hKkSyMaL]{Dullahan}), and it wants to return the blow the next week. Gwalchmei is afraid and asks for the help of an adventuring party.

Potential Reward: 150 gd, a blessing from Dullahan, a favor from a Knight Templar.

A few Knights Templars (@UUID[Actor.E0CgpeW5IWLIHZ18]{Crusader Infantry} and @UUID[Actor.LPLMyzMDoA42Euek]{Crusader Knights}) hosted a meeting to decide the strategy against a group of bandits active on the pilgrims’ roads. The meeting was interrupted by a strange appearance: a knight in green. The knight wanted to play a game of chivalry and courage: an exchange of blows. One champion among the knights would hit him once, and seven days later, at a hill with a broken tree, would return the blow at the same place.

Gwalchmei was feeling left behind, and he thought of this opportunity to show his courage and cunning. He volunteered to be the champion. The knights were amazed by his courage and let him step forward. Gwalchmei thought he was being clever and beheaded the knight with one swift stroke. He thought he had won, but the disembodied head started to laugh, and the body picked it up. He congratulated the knight and expressed his enthusiasm for meeting him next week.

Gwalchmei is afraid to go, but his honor and his officers in the Order deem that he must go and do it alone. However, Gwalchmei wants to recruit help: adventurers, skilled warriors, and arcane dwellers.

If the adventurers agree to the quest, they can travel to the hill with the broken tree together. On the road, there can be some challenges to test their strength and honor.

  1. A poor @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.SqZRuJ8lt2KGJBbq]{Commoner}j named Alexander will ask for a donation. He expects at least 1 gd from a knight in shining armor. (the Honorable act is to give the poor a good amount of coins, at least 1 gd) Gwalchmei has only 1 gd.
  2. They will be attacked by a @UUID[Actor.3x9eB5NzUd2eD8i6]{Fallen Crusader} (the Honorable act is to fight with courage), and Gwalchmei is terrified of the undead.
  3. A traveling circus will spend the night with the group, offering them shelter and food. During the night, a hunter (Scout) named Bertilak will want to play a game called the Hunting Game. He will hunt during the night and give whatever he finds to Gwalchmei; in exchange, Gwalchmei will give whatever he finds during the night to the hunter. After the hunter Bertilak is gone, his wife Beatrice (@UUID[Actor.nW8Aj5aNHyswBvNs]{Traveling Artist}) will attempt to seduce Gwalchmei and initiate this by kissing him. She will give him a green girdle, a magic item that will save his life. When an identity spell is cast on the girdle, this information is revealed: “When a player reaches 0 hit points, the girdle will disappear, and the user will drop to 1 hit point instead.” (the Honorable act is to stay away from Beatrice and respect her husband, but Gwalchmei is mesmerized by Beatrice).

There are some important aspects of the quest:

  • Gwalchmei does not want to die, but his honor is also very important to him. He’s torn between duty and his own preservation. If the adventurers do not intervene, he may choose dishonorable acts due to reasons stated within the challenges.
  • The knight in green actually wants to test the knight’s honor, and if he submits to the rules of the game, the knight will spare his life with only a small cut on his neck and give him a permanent blessing (the GM’s choice of a low-spell effect, such as “always under the effects of the bless spell”).
  • If the adventurers helped him stay true to his cause, they will be rewarded with temporary blessings, such as a low-level cleric spell that is extended by duration or effect.
  • Without the adventurers’ help, Gwalchmei is most likely to fail.

The knight in green is actually Godfrey de Saint-Omer, a founding member of the Knights Templar. He was beheaded by one of the grand masters wrongfully, but he protected another of his comrade’s honor: Hugues de Payens. Godfrey died in his stead and did it happily. His honor made him hold onto his life as a Dullahan, and he sometimes tests the members with different challenges. He sometimes hires some young knights to test others’ strength and devotion, just like in this case.

Resolutions:

  • If Gwalchmei puts the girdle aside and faces the challenge directly, without any games or deceptions, he will be counted successful no matter what he does with 3 challenges.
  • If he is counted successful and acted honorably (or persuaded to act honorably) in all three cases, he will receive a magic sword (longsword +1) from the Dullahan.
  • If attacked, the Dullahan will protect itself with all its might.
  • If the adventurers all acted like bad influences and persuaded the knight on all occasions toward the dishonorable acts, the Dullahan may turn hostile towards the adventurers.

If Gwalchmei is successful, the knight in green will bid farewell to him by saying: “Off with your head.”

Gravekeepers.name: Gravekeepers
Gravekeepers.text:
Gravekeepers

Recommended Level: 3-4

Quest Summary:Some people are missing. Usually, beggars and other civilians from the poorer parts of the city are never found, believed to be dead. A local priest takes notice of the situation and suspects a far worse scenario.

Possible Rewards: four @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.WPWszFTGzmdIuDRJ]{flasks of holy water}, two 1st level spell scrolls, 100 gd.

Near the Byzantine Cardo, many people have gone missing. They were seen last at night and vanished after that, nowhere to be found in the morning. A local priest named Claus takes notice of the situation and investigates the ones that are lost. They are usually beggars, the poor, homeless people, or immigrants from Outremer.

A rumor is circulating around the neighborhood that they went to the graveyard nearby and were killed by the gravekeeper there, a horrible creature belonging to nightmares. Many of the beggars noticed bloody paths and bodily remains near the graveyard, and one has never seen coming back from there.

However, a successful DC 13 Wisdom (Insight) check will reveal that the beggars are withholding information. There is also a rumor of tremendous wealth lying in the graveyard. A recently wealthy artisan named James died, and the rumor holds that he was buried with all his wealth, despite the usual burial traditions here. It is said that James had two sons, and both of them brought disgrace to him, so he left them all out of his will. A drunk @UUID[Actor.OksiTzyq7R5pinZR]{warrior priest of the Levant} named Theo let this story slip out about this situation.

In reality, James died and became an undead creature, a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.NAISFPoNNgUCsEyW]{zombie}j, due to a cursed item given to him by his wife, whom he never got along with and lived separately from for a long time. The next day, his sons, Jaime and Trystane (both @UUID[Actor.1JK80RxGJvsa6UG4]{Artisans}), found bodies near their father’s grave and bound their father to his resting place. They realized the situation, and they soon found out that each night, a zombie was rising from a grave. They created the rumor of the gravekeeper to keep the grave robbers away, as no one would believe there were no treasures in the grave, because there were indeed. Their father, out of spite against their mother, wanted to be buried with some of the most precious items he had.

The sons can’t find it in their hearts to destroy their father, but they deal with new zombies each night with the help of Theo (who is constantly intoxicated and thus counted as poisoned). If the adventurers agree to do it, they will not stand in their way.

The adventurers can find the cursed item, a necklace, if they dig up the grave. Unless destroyed by two @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.items.Item.WPWszFTGzmdIuDRJ]{flasks of holy water} under sunlight at noon, the necklace will create one @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.NAISFPoNNgUCsEyW]{zombie} each day. The flasks can be provided by Claus, who is more than happy to solve this situation. Destruction of the necklace will destroy all zombies.

After the event, the sons, if alive, can join the military ranks due to their experience with fighting the undead.

Knights Hospitaller.name: Knights Hospitaller
Knights Hospitaller.text:
Ordo Fratrum Hospitalis Sancti Ioannis Hierosolymitani

Under the shadow of an obsidian cross against the backdrop of midnight-touched fabric, as unassuming as a monk in silent prayer, you encounter a Knight Hospitaller. The air turns comforting, imbuing a sense of serenity as if the whispers of a guardian angel linger in your ear, promising solace and salvation. The blend of obsidian on black and the soothing calm are the hallmarks of these Knights of War and Healing.

If you find yourself under their care, the Knight Hospitaller’s presence signifies healing, blessing, and holiness. Their noteworthy piety is not merely harbored within but also proudly displayed upon their attire and banners, symbols of their sacred vow. With balms and bandages at the ready, they are poised to mend the wounds of the warriors of the Faith, preserving the sanctity of life with their skills. Their essence vibrates with the pledge to heal their brethren and fulfill their divine obligation.

Knights Hospitaller were founded during the First Crusade by the knights for those who tended the wounded soldiers in the Church of John the Baptist.

Church of John the Baptist

“The house of Zechariah … where the holy Virgin came to greet Elizabeth,” a voice reminds you, and continues: “small cavern, in which John the Forerunner was born.”

Built in the ancient times and repaired by the Fatimids, the church reminds you of rebirth and forgiveness. The aura is almost holy, and you feel that a blessing is about to be granted to you, just for existing. You remember each sin you committed, and instead of shame, they come to you as experiences, lessons to be learned, and…to grow!

The Church of St. John the Baptist stands as a testament to centuries of religious devotion and architectural evolution. Its structure, layered with the history of successive renovations and restorations, reflects the myriad influences that have shaped Jerusalem’s identity. The church’s façade, marked by time, reveals a blend of architectural styles that testify to the city’s diverse past.

Within its walls, the church harbors a tranquil sanctuary, offering solace and a sense of timelessness. The interior is adorned with venerable icons and frescoes that narrate the life and ministry of John the Baptist, enveloping visitors in a tapestry of sacred artistry. The dimly lit nave, with its stone arches and columns, evokes the historical depth and spiritual gravity of the site.

The Church of St. John the Baptist not only functions as a place of worship but also as a custodian of history, preserving artifacts and stories that span millennia. Its courtyards and adjoining monastic buildings provide a peaceful retreat from the bustling city, creating an oasis of contemplation and spiritual renewal.

Roger de Moulins (@UUID[Actor.hyc7JlRpp4jTTNdg]{Crusader Priest}, LN) is the Grand Master of the Order, William Borrel (@UUID[Actor.oCV22rd7effi8QlD]{Crusader Champion}, N) who is the Marshall of the Order, and a legendary warrior (who will become one of the most notable commanders during the Third Crusade) called Garnier of Nablus (@UUID[Actor.oCV22rd7effi8QlD]{Crusader Champion}, CG) are one of the most prominent knights of the order as the Grand Commander.

Roger de Moulins is an elderly man with great knowledge, wisdom, and experience. He is one of the most powerful priests in Jerusalem and has the abilities of a 5th-level Life Domain Cleric in addition to the statblock and this feature: He can cast the healing word spell at will. Roger is an enthusiastic priest in his thirties with a respect towards all life and an interest towards the working mechanism of the human body as well as arcane matters. He usually is close to wherever combat and raids are and rarely spends time in the city. He helps injured soldiers all over the kingdom.

William Borrel is a middle-aged man with a short temper and great talent. He is one of the best duelists in the order and has never lost a one-on-one duel. He usually seeks out friendly competitions in the kingdom and tries to locate talented youth by observing them and organizing small tournaments. He also disguises himself from time to time and observes the youth in the city from afar to detect talented and dedicated ones.

Garnier is a man of high charisma and is a very perceptive knight. He adapts to the changing world quickly and embraces the new conditions better than most. He is a devout and good man, believing that taking up arms against foes must be the last resort. He occasionally talks about the good of the realm and that they should start discussing peace and co-existence with the Muslim world. He is constantly in touch with members and puts a keen eye on the order. Although the order was founded to help the injured and the ones in need, he believes that the threats to the order and the City of God are so great that one must secure one’s homeland before dealing with any external business. He is seen as weak and cowardly by some of the members of the order, due to his talks about peace, but there are a good number of knights following his example.

Mechanical Effects of the Church

The ones that spend the night in the church, if they are believers and part of the order or treated by one of the members, wake up with 2d4 + 4 temporary hit points. If any member of the order or one with an intent to protect the church rolls initiative inside or within the perimeters of the church, they gain the effects of the bless spell for 10 minutes.

Each fiend or undead that enters the church takes 7 (2d6) radiant damage while inside the church.

Apart from these effects, one of the following effects can be assigned each Sunday or each 1d8 days:

d8

effect

1

Serene Aura: The residents are immune to disease, and only 1-hour of rest is enough to reduce all levels of exhaustion.

2

Divine Blessing: Any believer who finishes a long rest in the area receives the effects of the bless spell for the day.

3

Ready for War: Any believer who finishes a long rest in the area can’t be surprised and has advantage on Initiative rolls during the day.

4

Eyes of the Angel: The members of the order that finish a long rest in the area can understand if a creature is a shapechanger during the day.

5

Beacon of Hope: The members of the order can see normally in dim light until dawn.

6

Endurance of Faithful: The members of the order have advantage on Strength and Constitution saving throw during the day.

7

Healing Aura: When a member finishes a long rest in the area during that day, they receive the full amount whenever they heal someone else, or they are healed by another source or through short or long rest.

8

Clinging to Life: After a member finishes a long rest in the area, whenever it drops to 0 Hit Points it is immediately stabilized until dawn.

Tending Injuries

As their fame rose with the First Crusade, injured knights were healed at the Church of John the Baptist. Any knights who fight in the Crusade, wars of the Kingdom, and especially against Saladin are welcomed to the hospital. However, the order relies on donations, and any form of contribution is welcome.

All members working in the order have advantage on Wisdom (Medicine) checks and other skill checks required to perform surgery or tending a wound.

Features

The Grand Master is the leader of the order. The Grand Commander follows the Grand Master in the hierarchical order, and they are followed by the Marshal, the one who prepares the order for war and protects the hospital.

Members of the order (even player characters) can acquire these features if you deem them appropriate.

Hand of the Blessed Gerard: Blessed Gerard, the legendary founder of the order, guides the hands of the Knights Hospitaller. When you roll for a Wisdom (Medicine) check on a creature that has 0 hit points but is not dead, the creature can immediately spend one of its hit dice and add its Constitution modifier, and regain hit points equal to the total.

Devotion to the Cause: When you drop to 0 hit points, you are immediately stabilized and still roll for death saves. On a roll of 18-20, you regain 1 hit point.

Divine Protection: While wearing armor and below half of your maximum hit points, you take 1d6 + Constitution modifier less damage.

Sacred Strikes: A Hospitaller’s strength is legendary. Your weapon attacks ignore all resistances.

Armor Proficiency: You gain proficiency in light, medium, heavy armor, and shields.

Weapon Master: You gain proficiency in simple weapons and martial weapons.

Knights Templar.name: Knights Templar
Knights Templar.text:
Pauperes commilitones Christi

Templique Salomonici Hierosolymitanis

When the stark crimson cross emerges against the backdrop of white, pure as Mother Mary herself, you know you’ve encountered a Knight Templar. The contrast of crimson and white and the overwhelming dread are unmistakable signs of their presence, embodying the fearsome reputation and steadfast faith of the legendary warriors of the Holy Cross.

If you stand as their ally, the Knights Templar’s presence signifies protection. Their unwavering faith is not just carried in their hearts but also emblazoned across their armor and engraved on their shields. With swords at the ready, they are prepared to strike down the foes of the Crusader States, defending their sanctity with their lives. Their entire being resonates with the commitment to safeguard their allies and uphold their sacred duty.

Possibly one of the most famous knightly orders in history, the Knights Templar consists of strong and devout warriors. Founded after the First Crusade, their main goal is to protect the pilgrims in Outremer and in the Holy Lands. Their base of operations is the Mosque Al-Aqsa, in their words, the Temple of Solomon, the east wing of the royal palace and one of the most sacred places in the whole of Jerusalem.

Their current Grand Master is Gerard of Ridefort (@UUID[Actor.oCV22rd7effi8QlD]{Crusader Champion}, LN), a devout and talented warrior. At his side, another devoted warrior serves the kingdom: Walter du Mesnil (@UUID[Actor.oCV22rd7effi8QlD]{Crusader Champion}, N).

Gerard of Ridefort is a very faithful man and a talented knight. He believes all members of the order should be as pious as he, disciplined in their religious rituals, and that their acts of faith must be sincere. Otherwise, it would be hypocritical to bear arms for the Lord. He occasionally visits the countryside and upcoming pilgrims on their road in disguise, secretly protecting them, looking out for their troubles, and personally observing the conditions of the roads of pilgrimage. He also pays regular visits to local nobles to gain donations, as the Knights Templar depends entirely on donations. Gerard’s flaw is isolation: his devotion to the order and its way leads him to believe that all members of the order are devout as he is, and his usual missions outside the city may make him blind to many internal problems. He is also aware of the arcane realm but considers it a distraction from the true duties of a Knight Templar. He has no problems with magic drawn from nature and holiness, but if he witnesses arcane power emanating from a darker place, he will consider it his mission to cut the source down.

If adventurers wish to help Gerard, they can either escort him in the wilderness and help fight off some potential threats (check out the table Wilderness Threats below) or investigate the corruption within the order (check out table Internal Affairs below).

Walter du Meslin is a devout and charismatic man with great leadership skills and a strong belief. He believes that the Crusade must continue everywhere, all the time. He is known as the “Wolf under the Cross” by the members of the order, as he is always ready to fight, devoted to the cause, and sees enemies everywhere. He has a personal grudge towards Saladin, often describing him as the “Anti-Christ,” and frequently checks Saracen activity around the city. He is strict on this business, and he is against letting Muslims into the city, as he thinks that they threaten the integrity of the city and may be spies of Saladin. He also disdains magic, seeing it as a taint on the face of the Earth. He is very respected and loved by the Western Crusaders, yet most of the Eastern Crusaders approach him cautiously. He constantly has disagreements with the Grand Master on these matters, but they are very old friends and both are very devoted to the cause of defending the City of God.

Walter’s brother, One-handed Aaron, has actually converted to Islam and turned to the side of Saladin years ago. Walter is keeping the matter a secret and does not wish it to be known publicly. He believes that Saladin tormented his brother and broke his will. In truth, Aaron met a traveling imam, a member of a Sufi order, while patrolling a border town. The imam and he had a chat, and Aaron started to read the Quran after a deep conversation. He decided that he believed in Allah the same way the Muslims did. He peacefully converted sides but swore an oath never to take up arms against his brother’s side. He often writes him letters from Cairo, but Walter immediately burns those letters. Aaron is known as Harun the Barbarossa (@UUID[Actor.kDX72EozbFjhaiYT]{Local Priest}) due to his copper beard. Aaron’s Arabic version is Harun, the biblical brother of Moses (Musa). For further information about Aaron, check out the Ibn Tulun Mosque section at Cairo: The Jewel of the Nile chapter.

If the adventurers are interested in the Knights Templar and Walter du Mesnil, Walter will inform them of his life’s mission: he desires revenge for his old master, the former Grand Master of the Order Odo of St. Amand, who has been captured by Saladin and died in his cells.

Internal Affairs

One of the prominent warriors (a Crusader Veteran named Alfonso) has actually made a pact with a creature from Al-Ghaib ( a devil like @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.KtM6IV9I5l1MWUDk]{Chain Devil}j or a demon like @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.OGPHF4sCVOAi87TU]{Glabrezu}j) and wants to plant some “evidence” against the commanding officers by accusing them of adultery or a similar huge crime.

A @UUID[Actor.E0CgpeW5IWLIHZ18]{Crusader Infantry} is in love with a Muslim woman, while the rest of his band is unaware of this relationship. It will create a dispute amongst them if or when they find out.

State of the Order

During its foundation, one of the greatest problems of the order was poverty. Their sigil of two knights riding one horse was a symbol of the meager financial situation of the order, as it solely depended on donations from other institutions and the wealthy.

The Knights Templar made a name for themselves at the Battle of Montgisard, when the Templars showed great courage and strength against the forces of Saladin, turning the tide and securing a decisive victory. Since the battle, trust in the order and the number of volunteers significantly increased. The order has about two thousand men at their disposal, two hundred of whom are actual knights.

Features

There are four main ranks in the Knights Templar: Grand Master, Noble Knights, Non-Noble Sergeants, and The Chaplains. The Grand Master is the leader of the whole order, and he appoints masters in different regions, such as France or Aragon. Noble Knights are the knights that joined the order and make up the best armed warriors within the ranks. They wear white to symbolize their devotion and chastity. Sergeants are mostly non-nobles and bring in important crafts and artisanship to the order: blacksmiths, builders, cartographers, cobblers, and more. Chaplains are ordained priests and are there for the spiritual needs.

Noble Knights can use any Crusader statblock found in the Book of Ingenious Monsters. Non-Noble Sergeants use less powerful Crusader statblocks, while the Chaplains can use @UUID[Actor.hyc7JlRpp4jTTNdg]{Crusader Priest} or @UUID[Actor.kDX72EozbFjhaiYT]{Local Priest} statblocks, as well as any priestly or spiritual statblock available or suited for your game.

Besides these statblocks, some members (even player characters) may be given these features if they are considered to be a part of the Knights Templar:

The Crimson Cross: Your enemies tremble before the Crimson Cross of the Templars. You have +2 bonus to your Charisma (Intimidation) checks.

Heavy Cavalries: Templars have served as heavy cavalries and the backbones of the armies of the City of God. You spend only 5 ft. of movement to mount or dismount. While mounted, you have advantage on checks or saving throws made to dismount you.

Pilgrims’ Protector: The order’s fame for helping pilgrims and the poor has become legendary. You have +2 bonus on Charisma (Persuasion) checks with the ones that follow the same faith as you: Roman Catholicism.

Deus Vult: A Knight Templar is always ready for war. You have +1d4 bonus to your initiative rolls.

Devoted Strike: The devotion of the Templars is legendary. When you score a critical hit, you apply one of the conditions: prone, grappled, or frightened. The condition lasts until the end of your next turn.

Armor Proficiency: You gain proficiency in light, medium, heavy armor and shields.

Weapon Master: You gain proficiency in simple weapons and martial weapons.

Banking System

While the Templar Order primarily focused on military endeavors, only a minority of its members engaged in combat. The majority served in auxiliary roles, supporting the knights and overseeing the economic framework. Despite their vow of personal poverty, the Templars managed substantial assets beyond mere donations. Nobles aiming to join the Crusades often entrusted their wealth to the Templars’ care during their absence. This practice allowed the Templars to amass considerable wealth across Christendom and the Outremer. By 1150 CE, the Templars pioneered the creation of letters of credit for Holy Land pilgrims. Travelers could deposit their valuables with a local Templar establishment, receive a receipt reflecting their deposit’s value, and then reclaim their wealth in the Holy Land, equivalent to the deposited amount. This early form of banking, potentially the first to utilize cheques, not only enhanced pilgrim safety by reducing robbery risks but also significantly boosted Templar financial resources.

Mosque Al-Aqsa | Temple of Solomon

You almost hear the bells of a church, the preachings of a rabbi, and the call to prayer of a muezzin. Where you stand right now is the ultimate sacred place, carrying the prayers of all believers upon its shoulders and whispering all that is holy into your ears. Whatever you believe in your heart, when you stand here, you see devotion, dedication, and worship of thousands of years.

Red crosses surround the area, the adorned walls, and the church that was a mosque before. The holiest of sights is under your feet.

The headquarters of the Knights Templar is probably one of the holiest places in the city. Granted by the King of Jerusalem in the 1120s, the Temple of Solomon has been the seat of power for the Templars and an important place for the city’s defense.

The place has been subject to legends, a possible home for relics and artifacts. No one knows if the rumors are true that the Holy Grail itself is barred safely behind the thick walls. Many Crusaders roam the area, and many Templars pray around the courtyard and in the buildings. Most of their quarters are interconnected with others – sleeping under the same roof makes the best of brothers, after all.

Mechanical Effects of the Temple

As a sacred ground, the Temple Mount has some features that affect the members and possible allies. Each member of the order that finishes a long rest in the area can reroll a saving throw that they failed once a day.

You also can choose from the table below or roll for one. The chosen effect lasts for 1d8 days or changes every Sunday.

effect

1

Serenity of a Believer: Any believer who takes a long rest in the area is under the effects of the sanctuary spell during the rest.

2

Temple’s Protection: Any believer who finishes a long rest in the area receives the effects of the aid spell.

3

Days of War: Any believer who finishes a long rest in the area is under the effects of the divine favor spell.

4

Mounted for War: Mounts that finish a long rest in the area gain 2d4 + 5 temporary hit points and have resistance against extreme weather conditions.

5

Interior Quarters

Most of the members spend their time in the quarters. It is designed to handle their daily needs: kitchen, library, chapel, training rooms, arsenal, bathrooms, storage, and personal quarters. Usually, the non-knightly and non-combatant members occupy these places and keep the order running and going by tending to daily problems and administrative matters, as well as economic integrity. Builders constantly address structural problems and add new places if necessary. The main person attending the needs of the Interior Quarters is a priest called Gundemar (Crusader Priest). Gundemar is a punctual and strict man handling the main discipline of the order. Usually, he oversees all schedules and approves them.

Courtyard

The courtyard is a place of training, preaching, and meeting. It is part of the Royal Palace, so the knights and members must always be clean, respectful, and ready to meet a royal member. Stables are also in the courtyard and filled with horses, as they are the backbone of the order and military. Most of the archery training, mounted combat training, and similar activities are done in the courtyard.

The master of the courtyard is a Crusader Knight (with Level 3 abilities from Ranger - The Sentry) called Arnold of Toledo, one of the most skillful riders amongst the ranks. Arnold is a free spirit with a good understanding of nature and the mood of beasts, especially mounts. He has a warhorse, a riding horse, a camel, and a mastiff. They are named Cazador (hunter in Spanish), Trueno (thunder in Spanish), Andalucia, and Gordito (chubby in Spanish), respectively. It is rumored among the members that Arnold can even tame and mount a dragon. He is sometimes seen with more interesting mounts, such as elks or even wolves. For the related quest, check out The Hunt section below.

The Chaplains

Spiritual leaders of the order are the unseen leaders behind the barred doors. Grand Master Gerard’s personal mentor, Godfrey of Montferrat (@UUID[Actor.hyc7JlRpp4jTTNdg]{Crusader Priest}, LN), is one of the de facto leaders of the order. He is also the oldest member of the order. He was born the day Jerusalem was taken by the First Crusaders to a woman who died in the Temple Mount after her deep wounds.

Godfrey is one of the most devout Christians that can be found in all of the Holy Lands. His experience and wisdom help the members constantly, and his spiritual leadership is without an equal. He spends most of his time around the knights and other members. He doesn’t believe in seclusion and praying alone, distracted from the real world. He is a man of action, and despite his age, he is healthy and active. He is not very tolerant of those from other religions and especially keeps Saladin and his army at the top of his list of enemies. From his early days as a simple priest to his way to the top seats of the Templars, he always preached taking the fight to the Muslims, and unity amongst the Crusaders, whether it be newcomers from the West or the locals in the East.

He has a unique arcane ability: understanding lies without difficulty and seeing the truth in all things. From a mechanical perspective, he understands when he hears a lie and has truesight of 30 ft.

Godfrey has two young pupils: Jean Charles (@UUID[Actor.hyc7JlRpp4jTTNdg]{Crusader Priest}, NG) and Jacob (@UUID[Actor.hyc7JlRpp4jTTNdg]{Crusader Priest}, LN). Both are very talented and respected priests in their mid-twenties. They participate in the activities and patrols at the border and in the countryside. Jean Charles has a family in secret in one of the border villages, although he is not allowed to marry. He has a wife named Lucia (@UUID[Actor.nW8Aj5aNHyswBvNs]{Traveling Artist}) and two infant children. Jacob is actually very afraid of combat and similar situations, but he has made a promise to a fallen comrade that was grievously wounded in the Battle of Montgisard to build up courage. Due to the promise, he never backs down from a fight and is known as one of the bravest priests in the order. Most warriors and knights come to him for blessings and confessions.

Vault of Heaven

The vault is a myth among the outsiders and even among the members. Its place is a secret and only known to a few selected individuals. Only the Grand Master could reveal the place and the ways of entering.

Four Fallen Crusaders are hexbound to the gate for protection. They have a unique feature: they can sense belief in living creatures, and ask two questions to those who approach. The first question is: “Who dost thou believe in?” The answer must be specifically “The Lord that died for our sins,” and one must mean it. The bound undead can sense any lie. The second question is: “Wherefore is thy cross crimson?” The answer must be specifically “The Lord bled for this.”

The vault is a 60 x 60 foot room with a 60-foot high ceiling, designed as a cube. Inside, there are fourteen chests that fill all three sides of the vault. All chests are large. Except for the one with the theta letter from the Greek alphabet, all other thirteen chests are actually mimicsj.

The marked chest has a lock on it (DC 20) and contains the following items: sundial of Alexandria, rod of the seeker, lantern of otherworldly ward, judge’s hammer, crusader armor, five 3rd-level spell scrolls, eight 2nd-level spell scrolls, ten 1st-level spell scrolls, and a special item called the Holy Grail. It is not the one in legends, but it has magical properties and is a powerful item for the order.

Holy Grail

Wondrous item, very rare

A grail made of clay that seems ordinary but has wonders hidden in it. For regular eyes, it is just a simple example of daily pottery, but heroes, saints, anointed knights, priests, or even an apostle’s hands were on this.

Any liquid poured in the grail gains the abilities of a flask of holy water or a healing potion (user’s choice). Only those of good alignment can use the holy grail. Creatures with neutral or evil alignments that touch the grail take 35 (10d6) psychic damage.
