This faction is further explained in

The Sigil of Jerusalem.

The Origin of Magic.name: The Origin of Magic
The Origin of Magic.text:
The Origin of Magic

Acrusader marches through the gates of Jerusalem with a bright eye and burning soul. With faith as his guardian, his power is unmatched. A fortune-teller in the city of Cairo gazes through the skies under the scorching sun and reads the tides of fate among the scattered clouds. A Mamluk stands ready at the towers of Damascus, ever watchful against the Crusader forces, facing the dreadful winds flying to the south and ready to face every danger that may stand in his way. A pilgrim and a traveler share bread and the dangers of the road together.

“Magick took her name and original form from Persia,” wrote John Baptista Porta in his Natural Magick (originally Magia Naturalis, 1558 CE. The English translation is dated 1658 CE). “A magician is nothing else but one that expounds and studies divine things.”

In the world of Historica Arcanum, humankind discovered the power of magic in ancient times, through many different methods of channeling: chanting, dancing, rituals, prayers, battlecries, potions, and more. The unnatural power they possessed was rare, wild, and dangerous, as it broke the laws of reality.

No human knows the true origin of these abilities that can break apart reality, but it is known that, through practice, some words, movements, and materials trigger the power. The raw talent of the practitioners from ancient civilizations slowly turned and diversified into the enlightened magicians, able priests and powerful sorcerers who developed methods of their own.

Yet one thing has remained constant: reality does not take kindly to those who break its rules. Time and space will expunge the effects of arcane powers either through “coincidences,” or, in more severe instances, collapsing the spells back on the arcanists, and even onto innocent bystanders in the proximity of the spellslingers. Beyond superstition, this is the reason why magic is forbidden in many cultures, and why species and races that carry the taint of magic are distrusted. Once you are involved in magic, reality will take its vengeance, one way or another.

A Vengeful Reality and Magic Untamed: Sp.name: A Vengeful Reality and Magic Untamed: Spell Rebound Effects
A Vengeful Reality and Magic Untamed: Sp.text:
A Vengeful Reality and Magic Untamed: Spell Rebound Effects

This section is the revised version of the Spell Rebound Table section in Historica Arcanum: The City of Crescent (p.58).

Magic comes at a price.

This is the first lesson every disciple of the arcane arts learns, the easy way, or the hard way, whether they are in the esteemed arcane chambers of mighty libraries, twilight forests with the deepest roots, the coldest zeniths of the highest mountain or amongst scorching deserts where the dunes forgive nothing.

A GM may want to include these rules in a game set in the world of Historica Arcanum to show why magic is considered dangerous universally and add some consequence to spell casting.

Core Mechanic

In the table below, a trigger for a Spell Rebound is shown depending on the caster’s proficiency bonus. However, a GM may deem a situation to be appropriate for a Spell Rebound.

Pr.Bonus

Trigger

+2

Expending all spell slots.

+3

Expending a highest level spell slot.2

+4

Casting two spells in successive rounds or in the same round3. Cantrips do not count.

+5

Casting a spell that includes a damage roll.4

+6

Casting a spell of 6th level or higher.

+7 or higher1

Dropping a creature to 0 hit points with a spell, magical ability, a supernatural feature or the like or restoring life to a creature while it is on 0 hit points with a spell or a similar magical effect.

1The usual maximum proficiency bonus for a player character is +6. Some creatures may have higher proficiency bonuses than that, such as a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.bfh29vIEoGzI240e]{lich}j or an @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.vFeFRlF2FOgf2HIL]{ancient red dragon}j, but those kinds of immensely powerful creatures are very rare or nonexistent in the Historica Arcanum universe.

2For warlocks, this trigger is considered as “Casting a spell that is provided with Eldritch Invocations requires to expend a spell slot or somehow limited way, such as casting compulsion through bewitching whispers.”

3Such as casting the magic missile spell on its own initiative count and casting the shield spell at another creature’s turn but during the same round.

4Such as fireball, magic missile, blight, and scorching ray. Cantrips do not count.

Triggers are cumulative. If a creature has +4 proficiency bonus, the triggers for lower proficiency bonuses apply as well.

Trigger

The character makes a saving throw using the same ability used for spellcasting. For example, a wizard makes an Intelligence saving throw because the wizard’s spellcasting ability is Intelligence. The DC equals the character’s own spell save DC. On a failed save, consult the Effects table below. On a successful save, nothing happens, and the character cannot trigger the same Spell Rebound until it finishes a long rest (A creature that fails can trigger the effects again). If it can trigger it by another means, the trigger will happen again. For example, a 5th level wizard casting a fireball triggers the spell rebound. When the wizard expends their last spell slot, the spell rebound is triggered again.

If a creature has two separate spellcasting ability scores due to multiclassing, taking a feat or other reasons, the source of the spell determines the ability score. If a spell somehow comes from separate sources at once, use the highest DC possible.

Some situations can cause more than one trigger, so each one requires its own saving throw.

Effects

There are three types of effects: Cosmetic, Destructive, and Internal. Cosmetic effects usually do not harm creatures or affect nearby objects or constructs in the means of dealing damage, but it may bring many social or similar consequences with them. Destructive effects usually damage nearby people and/or objects, possibly including the caster. Internal effects usually only affect the caster.

There are alternative ways to determine which category of effect occurs:

  • A GM may roll a d6 and choose which categorical effect occurs.
  • 1-2:Destructive
  • 3-4:Internal
  • 5-6:Cosmetic

It may depend on the school of magic the spell that triggers the effect. A GM may choose a different category from the ones listed below:

  • Abjuration: Internal
  • Conjuration: Destructive
  • Divination: Cosmetic
  • Enchantment: Cosmetic
  • Evocation: Destructive
  • Illusion: Cosmetic
  • Necromancy: Internal
  • Transmutation: Internal
  • The GM may decide which category to use depending on the triggering spell’s theme, effect, or type. For example, a healing word spell may cause internal damage, while a damaging spell could cause destructive damage. A necromancy spell may cause internal damage regardless.
  • It may depend on the situation. If the caster tries to harm someone, the effect could be internal. If the caster is deceiving someone, the effect could be cosmetic.

The Exceptions

  1. Some spells are ignored when its casting coincides with a trigger: detect magic, identify, lesser restoration, dispel magic, counterspell, greater restoration and antimagic field. (Except 9th level spell slots)
  2. Casting a spell that is 4th level or higher from a spell scroll always causes a trigger.
  3. Using a class feature or a similar effect that enables a creature to cast a spell of 3rd level or higher or expending a spell slot of 3rd level or higher directly causes a trigger. For example, mystic arcanum of a warlock, divine smite (3rd level or higher) of a paladin.
  4. Some vague but apparently magical features require the caster to succeed a Constitution saving throw. The DC is equal to caster level’s + its proficiency bonus. On a failed save, it causes a trigger. These magical features include channel divinity, some eldritch invocations
  5. Casting a 9th level spell or expending a 9th level spell slot is counted as another destructive trigger, no matter what the spell is.

As an optional rule, you can check out the Plague & Disease Module in Empires of the Silk Road for Rituals or Magical Symptoms to replace an Effect or a Special Condition. For example, Power Drain could be an effect, and its special condition can be “can be removed by a Clover Ritual.”

Cosmetic Effects

These effects usually cause visual changes on the caster or its surroundings. Applying advantage or disadvantage on a check besides the stated effects is up to the GM. For example, the first and fourth effects could cause disadvantage on Charisma checks as well.

Permanent Effects

Running a Story in the Holy Lands.name: Running a Story in the Holy Lands
Running a Story in the Holy Lands
Running a Story in the Holy Lands.text:
Adivine ember has been ignited, and its sparks landed on the kindling – vainglorious men of ambition and desire. Millions of people, aflame with the desire to rescue a distant city they had only heard of in legends, embarked on a journey seldom witnessed in the annals of history. Lords, knights, priests, monks, peasants, slaves, and kings rallied under the banner of the Crusade.

Most of the flock found themselves confronting the inescapable specter of death – via the claws of a perilous journey or at the sharp end of a blade – with the whispers of heavenly choirs in their ears.

The few who survived the years of untold misery on the treacherous paths arrived in ancient lands where the holy dead rose, where a hundred prophets’ cries echoed in a thousand temples still, and where the voices of God resonated in every wall, street, and mountain.

Crusaders, after years of untold carnage, have carved their way into the City of God. Yet the laments raised high to the heavens by the Holy Cross were, in the end, as sorrowful as the lament raised by the Holy Crescent, for even if victory was achieved in the end, a lasting peace was not within the confines of possible.

The banner of the Crusaders that had been waving atop the walls of Jerusalem for almost a hundred years was now put to a vengeful siege; attrition and infighting ensued. With castles and settlements being surgically removed by cunning statesmen and generals of the Holy Crescent each year, the fate of the Crusaders was grim.

The divine spark was now carried only by the king of Jerusalem and a handful of knights. These sacred lands no longer echoed with the invading Knights’ chants of war and conquest, but a whimpering melody befitting victims succumbing to the relentless ambitions of warmongering Lords and Bishops. Now, what seemed like a quest worthy of heroes of the legends, is a chessboard of power struggles – the end result of each and every grand endeavor.

Alliances were formed, lines were blurred, and the Crescent and the Cross became one - not in peace, but in cutthroat politics.

The era is changing. A visionary leader who united the scattered forces of the Holy Crescent had set his sights on the gem of the Holy Lands - a vengeance hundreds of years in the making. Yet this master plan was cut short by an ascendant king with but a few years left in this world. Now, the world held her breath as the two men sat down on the opposite ends of the chess board.

The first move, however, was made long ago, and by neither the white nor black pieces.

Arcane & Divine Matters.name: Arcane & Divine Matters
Arcane & Divine Matters.text:
Arcane & Divine Matters

The world of Historica Arcanum is where arcane powers, occult secrets, and eldritch creatures lurk in the shadows - hiding, hunting, or pulling the strings.

Most of the common folk of the Holy Lands may believe in the existence of magic due to bedtime stories, urban legends, religious revelations and folktales; however, most of them don’t know about the actual spellcasters and arcane matters that truly exist in this world.

Magic is rare but focused.

In the Holy Lands, magic is still very rare. Spellcasters can only be found if one knows where to look, eldritch creatures and non-humans are an even rarer sight, and objects with arcane properties are extremely hard to come by. However, in the cases of Jerusalem and Cairo, these cities hold many secrets, both arcane and divine, hidden in their dark alleys and underground places.

Magic is hidden.

Spellcasters, magical monsters, and arcane humanoid species exist throughout the Holy Lands, but they keep a very low profile - especially if they are sentient. In discreet districts of large cities and remote villages within the wilderness, humanoid species can be found - if you know what to look for. In Jerusalem, they often conceal their identities by wearing heavy armor or clerical robes. Cairo, with its wide and overcrowded streets and bazaars, provides ample opportunities for them to move about stealthily.

Magic is punishing.

Magic means breaking reality. It is a dangerous life, where the Vengeful Reality pushes back against the arcanists, by setting up traps disguised as coincidences, and most importantly, by rebounding the spells.

All magic users and arcane researchers are aware that spell rebound is real, and the cost of spellcasting can be harsh, even deadly.

Magic hunts Magic.

For the few that already exist behind the arcane veil, the Vengeful Reality ensures their doom by entangling them in the lives of others like them - curious coincidences, unfortunate accidents, or paranoid encounters. Once one is marked for death, they will keep stumbling upon eldritch creatures, spellcasters, or abhumans - and in such a dangerous world, these encounters always carry deadly consequences.

Only the very cautious, or the talented can hope to survive, for Lady Luck seems never to be on the side of the marked.

Divine matters are unknown.

Everyone is entitled to their own beliefs. One’s ability to harness divine power doesn’t have to prove or refute a religion or belief. Spellcasting may be achieved through faith, but magical prowess is primarily a result of one’s studies, mindset, and the power that lies within them. Believers from various faiths and religions can demonstrate remarkable feats in spellcasting, and many indeed believe that this is a reward for their faith.

Monsters are hidden or dwell among the common folk.

Monsters hide in the wilderness or disguise themselves in dark corners using their shape-changing abilities, spellcasting, or other talents. Some lurk under your beds, dwell within your stories, or scheme for a bloody hunt, or political power through sinister means.

Non-Human Races

As magic plays a vital role in the world of Historica Arcanum, non-human races hold significant importance. Players can select a non-human race for their characters, and they may also encounter NPCs from these races. The purpose of this table is to provide guidance for blending in within a city, town, or caravanserai, and to assist the GM in creating non-human NPCs, societies, and interconnected ideas that encompass the realm of non-human races.

How to Disguise?

Elf / Half-elf

Usually, concealing their ears is sufficient, but some of them resort to using makeup and similar substances to avoid drawing the attention of common folk.

Dwarf

Dwarves are generally perceived as shorter individuals by common folk, making it easy for them to blend in. They are encountered more frequently than other non-human races, and most of the time, there's no need for them to disguise themselves.

Halfling

Halflings typically present themselves as children among the common folk, or by behaving like exceptionally short humans who were born that way. They don’t raise suspicion or fear, unlike a tiefling or an orc might. One thing they excel at is going unnoticed by taller individuals.

Orc /

Half-orc

Orcs who don't make an effort to move stealthily through a bustling city may encounter difficulties due to their distinctive features, such as tusks and fangs. They often conceal these attributes by wearing heavy cloaks and garments that obscure their appearance. It's not uncommon for orcs to hide their faces, as it helps them blend in with the human-dominated populace. Half-orcs, on the other hand, might find it easier to go unnoticed than their full-blooded counterparts, as their fangs are typically less prominent.

Gnome

Like halflings, gnomes excel at sneaking around. While their facial features are more obviously 'non-human' than halflings, they rely on their talents and arts as a means of distraction. Their access to innate spells like illusions makes this easier for them. Additionally, if their illusions fail, they might pretend to be afflicted by a disease to divert suspicion. However, a failed disguise can arouse suspicion and subject them to the supernatural fears of common folk.

DragonbornF

Dragonborns, with their scaly, dragon-like skin, require more extensive means of concealment than any other race. They heavily rely on masks, cloaks, and magical items to disguise themselves, often posing as individuals suffering from a skin disease to avoid drawing attention. Additionally, the GM may allow a dragonborn character to begin with the Amulet of Adam and Eve, a powerful magical item that offers a range of beneficial effects. If a disguise fails, common folk may perceive a dragonborn as a monster or a threat.

Tiefling

The tails and colorful skin of a tiefling can arouse suspicion and supernatural fear among the common people of the Holy Lands. Consequently, tieflings often take great care to disguise themselves effectively. Additionally, the GM may permit a tiefling character to begin with the Amulet of Adam and Eve. If a disguise fails, tieflings may encounter hostility from common folk due to their resemblance to devils in folktales and urban legends.

FA GM could allow a character to play a dragonborn with a more human appearance, featuring scales on their body but a human-like face.

Amulet of Adam and Eve

Wondrous item, uncommon, requires attunement

While attuned to and wearing this amulet, a humanoid belonging to a non-human race will appear outwardly human without altering their general appearance features. For instance, a tiefling will seem to lack a tail and will have skin resembling a shade of brown of their choosing. However, these changes, such as the disappearance of a tail, can be detected through physical touch.

Where Do They Live?

Secluded Streets and Districts in Cities

They typically reside in destitute and rudimentary areas adjacent to major cities, carving out their own distinct districts where a majority of the non-human population dwells.

It usually requires a DC 13 Intelligence (Investigation) or Wisdom (Insight or Perception) check to determine a district that belongs to non-humans. Most districts have signs here and there in Thieves’ Cant to explain the situation.

Secluded Settlements in Wilderness

Certain forests, deserts, valleys, and coastal areas provide secluded and hidden locations where many non-humans seek refuge to lead peaceful lives away from the cities. To deceive tax collectors and other officials, humans may reside among them and dabble in the arcane arts. Furthermore, outposts and watchtowers serve as warnings for incoming strangers.

The tracks of such a settlement can be distinguished by a DC 15 Wisdom (Survival) check.

Among Us

Some of them choose to live, work, love, eat, and marry among the humans through the use of disguises or other methods. It is easier for dwarves, halflings, and elves to live like this.

These individuals’ detection varies depending on the quality of disguise and usage of arcane methods. Usually the difficulty is not lower than 10.

Nomadic Lifestyle

Some don’t stay in one place for too long and are always on the move. They work as sellswords, caravan guides, foresters, explorers, hunters, and many different professions.

It usually depends on the individual’s ability to disguise to determine whether they are non-human or not. Again, the difficulty is not lower than 10.

Notes on Religions & Divine Powers

Within the Historica Arcanum Universe, real-world religions manifest in every corner of the Holy Lands. Abundant mosques, churches, synagogues, pagan shrines, ancient temples, and sacred sites are strewn across this realm. Faith constitutes a commonplace aspect of most individuals’ lives, occupying a significant position within their culture and psyche. Some individuals profess that their abilities stem from their convictions, pledges, deities, gods, beings, and benefactors. The landscape is populated with individuals assuming titles like clerics, druids, rangers, and paladins. Additionally, there exist warlocks who assert that their power flows through a pact with entities beyond this world.

All of these are true. They genuinely believe that their power comes from a higher or deeper place, and they have strong proof through their achievement of amazing and unbelievable feats before your eyes. This raises the question: are religions real?

Answers pertaining to the existence or nature of higher powers in the Historica Arcanum universe are inherently unknowable. Such beliefs are personal matters, influenced by one's individual faith, values, and spirituality. Magical and divine powers are not conclusive evidence of the existence or superiority of any particular deity or higher power.

For instance, a Muslim cleric might assert that their God, Allah, is the only true deity, yet they could witness another cleric from Kyoto harnessing similar powers in the name of Izanami. In the Historica Arcanum universe, divine powers are believed to be a consequence of an individual's devotion, hard work, prayer, and willpower.

When it comes to warlocks and their patrons, the matter is quite different. While the existence of divine beings like God, Zeus, Leviathan, Ishtar, or Osiris may be a matter of belief, demons, fey creatures, aberrations, celestials, djinns, and elementals are widely accepted as existing in the world. Warlocks typically form pacts with these beings, which are often of a lesser power than the divine beings mentioned previously. For example, they may make a pact with a specific succubus, a greater djinn, or a hag, depending on the nature of their powers and the terms of their agreement.

A Pantheon

Most TTRPGs, and especially 5th Edition, include pantheons for clerics, paladins, rangers or druids. These pantheons also exist in the world of Historica Arcanum. For example, all of the gods from Greek Mythology are sources of godly beliefs and magical power of their own respective domains.

Note on Economy:Instead of gold pieces (gp) gold dinar (gd), instead of silver pieces (sp) silver dirham (sd) and instead of copper pieces copper fals (pl. fulus) (cf) are used. The conversion is the same: 1 gold dinar is equal to 10 silver dirhams and 1 silver dirham is equal to 10 copper fulus. Please note that these changes do not affect the official pricing of items and other shopping and are not designed to be historically accurate.

Notes on Languages.name: Notes on Languages
Notes on Languages.text:
Notes on Languages

In most TTPRGs, humanoids have languages based on their cultures, and other races largely speak the same language, such as Elves speaking Elvish. However, in Historica Arcanum as in real life, humans speak a variety of different languages, and fantasy tongues such as Elvish, Giant and Orc don’t exist.

Table of Languages

Common

If a player’s chosen character allows them to speak Common, there are three alternatives for a player:

  • Choosing the languages that are spoken in the Kingdom of Jerusalem: Latin, French, and Italian.
  • Choosing the languages that are spoken in Egypt and Syria: Turkish, Arabic and Persian.
  • If they are from another civilization, they can choose the civilization’s native tongues (e.g. German, Danish, English, Mandarin Chinese, Mongolian, Spanish) and one extra language that is spoken in the Holy Lands.

Normal Languages

If a player’s chosen character allows them to speak regular languages in the 5th edition (Elvish, Gnomish, Dwarf, and the like), they can choose other living languages throughout the world and take the other option in the Common section. Examples of living languages include: German, Greek, Aramaic, Hebrew, Kurdish, Armenian, Mandarin Chinese, Tibetan, and more.

Exotic Languages

If you allow your players to choose exotic languages, they can learn dead and/or worldly exotic tongues, such as Ancient Greek, Ancient Latin, Sumerian, Sogdian, Old Norse, and even hieroglyphs in Egypt.

Note: To avoid confusion in the matters of communication, as there are many languages in the area, players may be allowed to choose the first two options of the Common, as they will encounter those languages mostly.

As for script: Most of the Western languages use the Latin alphabet and almost all of the languages spoken in the Ayyubid dynasty use the Arabic script.

The People of the Holy Lands.name: The People of the Holy Lands
The People of the Holy Lands.text:
The People of the Holy Lands

The people living in the Holy Lands can be categorized into these: The Levantines, Eastern Christians, Eastern Crusaders, and Western Crusaders.

Levantines represent the local Arabs, Turks, and other minorities that live under the rule of Saladin. However, many Muslims may come from far lands to fight against the Crusaders. For example, they can be Seljuks, Khwarazmians, or even Indians. Most of the Muslim characters fall into this category, such as Saladin, Ismail al-Jazari, and more.

Eastern Christians represent the locals that lived here and had roots in the Holy Lands before the Crusades. Mostly, Greeks, Armenians, Copts and others fall into this category.

Eastern Crusaders represent the descendants of the First Crusaders that settled in Jerusalem and had a mixed culture of the West and the East. Usually second or third generations of Christians fall into this category, such as King Baldwin IV, Princess Sybilla, and Raynald of Chatillon.

Western Crusaders represent the warriors, priests, pilgrims and others that were born in Europe and came to Holy Lands in recent years. Characters like Guy of Lusignan fall into this category.

The People of the Levant

Cairo, Damascus, Aleppo, Dimashq, Konya, Baghdad… The people from Mesopotamia, Syria, Egypt and Anatolia are of mostly Turkish, Arabic, Persian, or Kurdish descent. Syria and Egypt are under the control of a new rising dynasty: The Ayyubids.

Usually, the names appear like this throughout the Levantine lands:

Masculine Names: Mehmet, Muhammad, Ahmet, Hasan, Rıza, Halil, İbrahim, Selim, Mahmut, Aziz, Mustafa, Şevket, Emin, İsmail, Yusuf, Musa, Ali, Hüseyin, Ziya, Adem, Akif, Bahri, Bashir, Fuad, Haldun, Hamza, Jubayr, Kadir, Labib, Muhsin, Nusret, Omar, Shakir, Talal, Zafer

Feminine Names: Ayşe, Hatice, Behiye, Cemile, Dilşad, Hacer, Mihrimah, Mediha, Naciye, Şerife, Fatma, Berhayat, Nesrin, Nergiz, Emine, Esma, Fehime, Gülüstü, Elif, Ayla, Nur, Amina, Bushra, Dina, Esma, Farida, Hafsa, Nafisa, Nayla, Rabia, Sabiha, Yasmin, Zehra

Surnames were not common among the folk; they were usually identified with their birth place or a nickname that was earned:

Place Names: Al-Jazari, Al-Baghdadi, Al-Sham, Al-Rumi, Al-Isfahani, Al-Qudsi, Al-Halabi

Nicknames: Sayf ad-Din (Sword of the Faith), Nur ad-Din (Light of the Faith), Abadi (Eternal), Hakim (Wise), Abd al Haq (Servant of the Truth), Abd al Latif (Servant of the Kind), Sabah ad-Din (Dawn of the Faith), Ghazi (Warrior, The one that fights for the glory of Islam), Al-Ghalib (Victor), Al-Muzaffar (The Victorious), Jalal ad-Din (Glory of the Faith)

Common Folk of the Levant

Most of the common folk of the Levant are of Turkish, Arabic, Persian and Kurdish origin. The concept of “ümmet (ummah)” binds them together and mostly unites their cultures as one. Of course, many cities have their own flavor and differences from the others, but the ones that are controlled by the Seljuks or Ayyubids share many similarities. Thus, the common folk have certain aspects in common.

  • The usual languages are Arabic, Turkish, Persian and Kurdish. Most of the common folk know Arabic and Turkish. Turkish is especially common among the military and Arabic in scientific or artistic circles and highborns. Persian is mostly used in bureaucracy, governing business and especially in poetry.
  • They are weary due to the Crusades. It is a time of troubles, and since the Zengis (The most notable Noble lineage) took power in the area, the fight against the Crusaders has accelerated, and this has cost the common folk mostly. They pay taxes and are raised as levies by nobles and commanders of the area. However, they are devoted to Saladin and his campaign, as most of them want to see the Kingdom of Jerusalem defeated and the Holy City reconquered.
  • Almost all do not know about the real magic of the world. Their aspect is limited by folktales, urban legends, stories, and superstitions. Most Muslims believe in the existence of the Djinnkind due to religious texts and oral tradition.
  • They live closely with the Crusaders and Eastern Christians. Not all relations are hostile. In the past, the Holy Lands have seen many alliances between Muslims and Crusaders that fought against other Muslim and Crusader alliances. Such an example happened in 1108: Tancred, the Prince of Galilee, and Rıdvan of Aleppo made an alliance against Baldwin II and Jawali of Mosul, an infamous Muslim commander and governor.

Military of the Ayyubids

The army of Saladin consists of three main parts: levies, Mamluks, and Turkomans. Mamluks and the Turkomans are the main and most effective sources of power.

Seasonal levies

Levies represent the seasonal warriors who are either volunteers to participate in the conquest of Jerusalem or the ones raised by noble emirs and beys.

Mamluks

Mamluk refers to a soldier who was once a captive or a slave but was granted freedom in exchange for joining the army. They receive excellent military training, and, as free men, they are able to marry, own land, and even become heirs to their masters. It is mostly derived from the Ghilman system of earlier caliphs. Mamluks eventually gained much more influence due to their military effectiveness. In the future, they established the Mamluk Sultanate in Egypt.

Turkoman Soldiers

The nomadic Turks that continue to live and fight like the people of the Eurasian steppes. Many Turkoman tribes lived in the borders of hostile countries and raided the lands. They rely on their mobility and their expertise on horseback archery to overwhelm and defeat the enemies. They mostly serve as vanguards, scouts, and cavalry for the Sultan’s army. They are mostly lightly armored and heavily trusting their mobilization.

The Highborn of the Levant

The nobility is ephemeral in the Muslim society. Ranks, lands, and castles could easily be gained and lost, as they usually relied on the relations with the Sultans and greater governors. Military successes, scholarly progress, serving the state and similar activities could make a man a noble, but failure, disobedience, strife and discord with the sultan could result in losing all titles and lands. “Noble families that last hundreds of years” as seen in the West are not that common in the Muslim lands.

“Emir” is the given name to the lords and commanders.

Most of the nobles in the Levant are of Arabic and Turkic descent, usually assigned by the Great Seljuk Sultans and earlier bloodlines descended through the Umayyad and Abbasid emirs. They are mostly tasked with raising armies and organizing the fight against the Crusaders and defending their lands and trade routes from possible enemies.

  • Most emirs have military characteristics due to ongoing wars: The Crusades, power strife between the Sultanate of Rum and the Great Seljuk Empire, and other conflicts. An emir is expected to know how to command an army and train the levies well. A good portion of them may have fighting abilities themselves.
  • They are mostly literate and educated. They know many languages due to the multicultural milieu of the area. Most of the emirs have an occupation at their disposal, such as being a poet, woodcarving, goldsmithing, blacksmithing, philosophy, or the like.
  • Some of them may be a witness to actual magic in the game. They may possess a magical weapon, an heirloom from their families, magical loot that was gained by plundering, or a similar item. They may be in pursuit of the arcane themselves and have an advisor that also possesses some arcane abilities, especially skilled with divination and augury.
  • Some emirs trust Saladin entirely and support him to the fullest. However, due to envy or the earlier failures of the Sultan, some emirs developed an enmity towards the Sultan and are showing open signs of displeasure and are putting a pressure on him to conquer Jerusalem. Some are sincere emirs that want to see Jerusalem conquered, while others want to see him fail and gain power themselves.

The Titles of the Land

Title

Meaning

Sultan

An Arabic word coming from “to rule,” Sultan means “the one who has sovereignty.” The Caliph blesses the sultans so that they can rule their country.

Emir

Equivalent to feudal lords, it comes from the Arabic word “to command.”

Tegin

The Turkish equivalent of “prince.” It is usually used as a nickname among the highborn of Turks to denote nobility.

Beg/Bey

Equivalent to lords in nomadic cultures, mostly the leaders of Turkomans.

Atabeg

Another word for nobles. It actually means “Father Beg/Older Beg” but is used to represent the teachers of the nobles, princes, and other highborn children. It represents a lesser nobility.

Malik/Melik

Persian equivalent of “prince” and currently used by Muslim rulers, heirs and similar highborns, relatives of sultans, and their family.

Hatun/Khatun

Hatun was the wife of a Khan/Khagan. It now means “woman of higher importance” in Muslim lands. Concubines, sisters, and relatives of the Sultan may hold this title.

Hodja

Hodja actually means “teacher” but has a religious understanding during the time period of this game. Usually imams and other religious figures are called hodja.

Imam

The priests in mosques. They are respected among society. They conduct the prayers, teach the local kids how to read, and guide the people spiritually.

What Did They Wear?

Hijab

A usually religious headwear. Peasant women living in the outskirts of big cities usually wear a non-religious and more colorful head attire to protect their hair from sun and dirt.

Sarik

Many officials, merchants, and other members of society wear sariks as headwear. A sarik is made up of several pieces of cloth wrapped around the head, and its color can signify different aspects of society. For example, white sariks are commonly worn by the clergy.

Shalvar

The long-legged traditional clothing is preferred by both men and women. It is baggy and long.

Turban

Traditional headwear of the middle and upper classes. There are many colors and types, often used for a sense of fashion.

Veil (Peche)

Many women preferred transparent veils when going out. This traditional outfit holds an important place in Turkish culture. Many different colors and types were preferred by the women.

The People of Jerusalem

The protectors of the Holy Sepulchre stood strong in the holiest of cities, and for a hundred years they ruled and defended the city with all their might. Either descendents of the First Crusaders or newcomer Crusaders, the people of Jerusalem face a great threat to their very existence.

Names usually appear like this throughout the land:

Masculine names

Gerard, Giovanni, Albert, Guy, Raymond, Guiseppe, Bartholomew, Archibald, Robert, Thomas, Alaric, Balthazar, Conrad, Otto, Baldwin, Arthur, Henry, John, Richard.

Feminine names

Anna, Emma, Joan, Eleanor, Hildegard, Alice, Ursula, Mary, Abigail, Euphemia, Beatrice, Elizabeth, Margaret, Celestina, Valentina, Paola, Cristina, Sofia, Rosa, Caterina.

Eastern Christians

After the capture of the city in 638 CE by Caliph Umar, the Jewish population were let into the city once again, and all three of the Abrahamic religions once again coexisted in the Holiest City. Umar made a treaty with the Patriarch, and the Christians were also allowed to live peacefully inside the walls. Patriarch Sophronius invited the Caliph to pray inside the church, but Umar declined so as not to set a precedent and thereby endanger the church’s status as a Christian site. Instead he prayed outside, on the steps east of the church.

The peaceful coexistence crumbled into dust when Jerusalem was conquered in the First Crusade.

When the First Crusaders took the city, it is said that their massacres were considered extreme even by medieval standards. Muslim holy sites were converted into Christians ones, and the very few Non-Christians that survived the bloodshed were expelled from the city. Many sources speak of Eastern Christians living in the City following the conquest, so they are considered to be relatively untouched by the Crusaders.

  • They are mostly of Greek, Armenian, Coptic, and African descent. They are mostly Christians and follow the Eastern churches such as Eastern Orthodox Church or Coptic Orthodox Church.
  • They have had roots in the Holy Lands for a very long time. Most of their ancestors lived closeby or right in the heart of the Holy Lands. They know the area, its history and legends better than most. A good portion of them that live in the cities are literate.
  • They have a settled culture and usually are occupied with trade, all kinds of crafts and artisanships, husbandry, agriculture, and similar jobs. Since the advent of the Crusades, the Western Christians needed them as soldiers as well due to the failure of the 1101 Crusade and the Second Crusade.
  • Some of the ancient families (although not need to be nobles) are aware of the arcane matters, but most of them stay out of it. Some of the cities’ mages and divine spellcasters are among them.

Eastern Crusaders

The followers of the True Cross stand proud in the hills where Jesus of Nazareth was believed to have ascended to heaven in the first half of the Common Era. They are the descendents of those who have reconquered this city from the hands of Muslims, and it is now their duty to protect the Kingdom of God.

  • They mostly originate from Europe and are the followers of the Roman Catholic church. Most are of French, German and Italian origin and speak Latin, French, Italian and German.
  • They are the majority in Jerusalem and serve as soldiers, priests, monks, guards, blacksmiths, stablemen, armorers, knights, butchers, cavalry, and more.
  • Highborns are especially educated in Latin and Greek. Latin is important for religious rituals, and Greek is seen as important in philosophy and similar pursuits.
  • They have better relations with the locals of the lands, both Levantines and Eastern Christians. Most of the people are focused on protecting their kingdom and living in prosperity. Most trust their king, Baldwin, more than anyone else. However, his disease has had a major negative impact on the city, and the residents are in fear for their lives. They want to see a suitable heir to the throne.
  • Their daily lives have traces from both Muslim and Eastern Christian societies. Due to their differences over time, the local Eastern Crusaders sometimes struggle to get along with the Western Crusaders.
  • There may be arcane researchers and pupils among them, but most of them have never met with actual magic in our game. Mostly, urban legends and folktales are spread among them.

Western Crusaders

The calling of the Holy War has never been stronger. Brave and foolhardy hearts in Europe set sail to the Holy Lands and hone the yearning in their hearts to see the Holy Lands and fulfill their destiny. They strengthen the lines of the kingdom against the Saracens and bring tidings from Europe.

  • There are many knights, warriors, exiles, runaways, pilgrims, and wanderers among them.
  • Some of them sincerely joined this Crusade to defend Jerusalem against Muslims. However, there are many who pursue personal glory and other ulterior motives. Some failed to gain power and seek it in the Holy Lands. Some are running away from their families to start new lives. Others seek the wealth of the eastern lands, and some try to make a name for themselves.
  • There may be followers of the arcane business, some trying to find out the legends concerning the Holy Lands and see for themselves. However, few of them actually are aware of the arcane reality of the world.
  • Most of them are of European origin. Most speak French, Italian, English, and German.
  • Almost all of them are Roman Catholics.
  • They have trouble adjusting to local culture and living with different religions. Some of the warriors are seen as warmongers, vicious soldiers and stubborn individuals. A really good portion of them support military means and armed conflict against the Muslims. This creates a strife between the locals.
  • Some of them don’t feel like home here and regard this kingdom as a means of their divine duty or an extension of their loyalty to the kingdom. Their goal is to see the Muslims are defeated and the Kingdom of Jerusalem is put to safety. Others see the Holy Lands as a new home and want to be a part of it.

Nobles of Jerusalem

Highborns of the Holy City are the ruling class in Jerusalem, and they decide the fate of the kingdom. Most of them are stationed in their own lands, castles and fields to protect the people and the realm. Some share similar traits:

  • Most of them are proficient with heavy armor in case of war and emergency and one martial weapon, possibly longsword. They are used to the constant fighting and wars; thus, many have experience in commanding armies.
  • Almost all of them know several languages, including Arabic or Turkish, to be able to communicate with the minorities in their lands. They also learn Latin due to religious reasons.
  • Some of them are aware of the arcane matters and have appropriate means to access it, such as a mage servant or an advisor, a magical item found as loot, or tomes on magical lore of the world.
  • Some even know about where the non-human communities dwell and let them be. Some try to recruit them in secret business and arcane matters.

The Titles of the Land

Title

Meanıng

Advocatus Sancti Sepulchri

Advocate of the Church of the Holy Sepulchre. First King of Jerusalem, Godfrey de Buillion’s title. He refused to be known as king.

Bailiff

Regents during the absence of the king of Jerusalem.

Basileus

A title used by Byzantine Emperors, originally coming from Ancient Greek “king”.

Roi

The French word for king, coming from the Latin word “Rex” which means directly “king”.

King

Ruler of a realm. Coming from the German “son of the people”.

Queen

Consort of the king or the ruler of the kingdom. Originally coming from the German word “kwoeniz” meaning “wife”

Prince/Princess

Offsprings of the ruler. Coming from the Latin “princeps” originally meaning “ruler”.

Duke

Hereditary nobleman of the highest rank, originally coming from the Latin word “dux” meaning “leader, governor”.

Marquis

Coming from Medieval Latin “Ruler of a border area” and eventually coming from the word “frontier”. Signifies a lower rank than duke.

Count

Coming from the Latin “companion, attendant”, a title of nobility.

Baron

Coming from uncertain origins, possibly from the Latin “baro” meaning man. A lower rank in nobility.

Lord

Coming from Old English “hlafweard” meaning “one who guards the loaves” and its later version “hlaford - master of the household, feudal ruler”.

Knight

Military follower of a king or other superior. It wasn’t a nobility rank until the 16th century. Originally coming from Old English and Middle High German “boy, youth, servant and attendant”.

Jewish Community in the Holy Lands

The Oldest owners of the city of Jerusalem, the Jewish population defended the city in the First Crusade against the Crusaders but were slaughtered or expelled in the aftermath. Many Jews that were captured from the Dome of the Rock were taken prisoners and were deported to Apulia. Most of the remaining were slain during the first siege and only a very small and hidden number of them remained in Jerusalem. Others were expelled and settled throughout the Levant.

  • They are devoted to their religion and even practice it in hard times. If necessary, they practiced their religion while hiding from the governing factions.
  • They suffered from the Crusades harshly, and this made the communities deeply resentful of the Crusader factions. On the other hand, the relationship between the Jewish population and Muslim authorities has become considerably stronger.

Religious Strife.name: Religious Strife
Religious Strife.text:
Religious Strife

A very complicated topic, but it is important to address the main conflicts in the area. First one can be considered the elephant in the room: The war between the Muslim countries and the Christian ones. It is not the only religious conflict in the lands, as each religion has its own sects that are in conflict. It may be useful to know the main differences of the sects.

Christians: Great Schism

In 1054 CE, the Roman Catholic Church and the Eastern Orthodox Church parted ways, and this enmity is seen throughout the Crusades, even as the Pope agreed to help the Byzantine Empire against the invading Turks.

Both the warriors in People’s Crusades and the greater First Crusade’s army pillaged lands of the Byzantine Empire, causing great distress to the seat of the Orthodox Patriarch in Constantinople. The rift between the two peoples of the same faith has even resulted in infighting in the Crusaders’ ranks.

Witnessing the devastation that the Crusaders caused, Byzantine Basileos Alexios took it upon himself to make sure warriors from the West reached the Muslim lands as fast as possible.

During the Second Crusade, the Byzantines even fought against the armies of Conrad III, the Holy Roman Emperor, in the outskirts of Constantinople to evict the Crusaders from their lands. It is rumored that the Byzantines secretly supported the Sultanate of Rum against the marching Crusaders. Emperor Manuel and Sultan Mesud even signed a peace treaty and ended attacks on each other, resulting in a massive loss of trust between Byzantines and the Crusaders.

Ultimately, years after the events in this game (in 1204 CE) this enmity reached its peak when the city of Constantinople was captured by the forces of the Fourth Crusade. The Byzantine Throne, who first called for a Crusade, ended up being destroyed by the Holy War they initiated.

Muslims: Schism Between Sunni & Shia Sects

The strife in united Islam began in 656 CE, when the Caliph Uthman was killed. The schism brought Ali and Muawiya, favored candidates for the seat of Caliphate, against each other. Supporters of Ali were known as Shiites; they did not accept the Caliphate of Muawiya, and they proclaimed their own Caliphate eventually, known as the Fatimid Caliphate.

Muawiya and his supporters, known as the Sunnis, won the civil war between the two sects, establishing the Umayyad Caliphate. Umayyads were out-throned by the Abbasids, and Abbasids eventually lost their influence but managed to remain important as they continued to rule in Baghdad. Their influence was limited and mostly the Sultanates that originate from Nomadic Central Asia ruled the Islamic world in their stead.

In 1099 CE, the Fatimid soldiers were the ones that defended Jerusalem from the Crusaders’ siege. Following the fall of Jerusalem, the Fatimid Dynasty ruled in Egypt until Saladin’s rise to power. Saladin ended up swearing loyalty to the Sunni Caliphate in Baghdad, thus ending the influence of Shia.

The Artifacts of the Holy Lands.name: The Artifacts of the Holy Lands
The Artifacts of the Holy Lands.text:
The Artifacts of the
Holy Lands

In a land with full of legends and myths pouring from every corner, mystery and magic touch many items and artifacts of the past give them unique abilities. In this section, many legendary items and trinkets that belonged to famous characters from the pages of history and the ashes of civilization are presented here.

The Sword of Saladin.name: The Sword of Saladin
The Sword of Saladin.text:
@UUID[Item.4ZwdBaEzdci8nkEL]{The Sword of Saladin}

Yatagan, legendary, requires attunement

It is said that this sword was a gift to Saladin from Nur ad-Din Zengi himself. At the time of its gifting, this was a masterfully crafted blade, but it held no magical properties. Yet the current state of the blade is much more powerful, hinting at Saladin’s skills in enchanting artifacts.

The Sword of Saladin is a yatagan with a classic curved blade; its hilt is decorated with black gems, the insides of which are adorned with purple silken script telling the legend of the Caliph Umar, who took Jerusalem in the 7th century CE. On it, the following is written:

تعلموا العلم، وتعلموا السكينة والوقار

These words are written on the blade. It is a quote by the Caliph Omar: “Acquire knowledge, and learn tranquility and dignity.”

  • Each creature of your choice within 30 ft. of you gains advantage on all saving throws for 1d8 rounds.
  • You roll a d8 and add the result to your and up to 3 creatures’ Armor Class within 30 ft. of you for 1 minute, as if you are concentrating on a spell.
  • You choose a damage type; you and up to 3 creatures of your choice within 30 ft. of you are immune to it for 1d8 rounds.

The item gains 1d4-1 charges at dawn (minimum of 1), and two of the features can’t be active at the same time.

The Mask of The Leper King.name: The Mask of The Leper King
The Mask of The Leper King.text:
@UUID[Item.Fr0vwyThOOJdVuqY]{The Mask of The Leper King}

Wondrous item, legendary, requires attunement

This marble mask is carved to resemble a kingly visage and adorned with fine lines and astonishing details. It is the mask that was worn by Baldwin IV, the Leper King to hide his leprosy-afflicted face. An arcanist could easily tell that The Mask contains a sliver of Baldwin’s immense arcane power and consciousness, an eldritch accident undoubtedly related to the Leper King’s disease.

The mask fixes a creature’s Charisma, Wisdom and Intelligence scores to 19, if it isn’t higher already and gives advantage to all saving throws while wearing it.

The Robe of The Leper King.name: The Robe of The Leper King
The Robe of The Leper King.text:
@UUID[Item.MZqmv09oEBalvRvT]{The Robe of The Leper King}

Wondrous item, legendary, requires attunement

This white robe made of silk has many adornments made with ultramarine lines. The robe produces an aura of 60 feet and can affect as many creatures as the wielder wants within it. Within the aura, chosen characters add your Charisma modifier to their attack rolls and saving throws. You can’t use this if you are incapacitated or unconscious.

The Silver Cloak.name: The Silver Cloak
The Silver Cloak.text:
@UUID[Item.0YgJ5TGuQCk9w77J]{The Silver Cloak}

Wondrous item, legendary, requires attunement

Adorned with handwoven symbols of Christian and Mesopotamian origins, the wielder of this cloak is surrounded by a gentle hum of singing and whispers. It is currently worn by the brave knight of Jerusalem: Guy of Lusignan. This silver robe grants the wearer +2 bonus to Armor Class and advantage on all saving throws.

Ring of Muawiya.name: Ring of Muawiya
Ring of Muawiya.text:
@UUID[Item.Kf6QhgmN0MdjECp3]{Ring of Muawiya}Wondrous item, legendary,requires attunement

Legends tell the story of Muawiya’s Caliphate ring during the Battle of Sıffin, as he forced Ali to arbitration using his wits and possibly this magic ring.

The user can cast the charm person and suggestion spells at will and without using any components. If the target does not succeed on the saving throw with a total of at least 5 more than the DC, it does not understand being charmed or that any magic was involved once the spell wears off.

In addition, the user can cast the mass suggestion spell once per day. This ability recharges at dawn.

Amulet of Al-Jazari.name: Amulet of Al-Jazari
Amulet of Al-Jazari.text:
@UUID[Item.Sh76pUFstrl4etDF]{Amulet of Al-Jazari}

Wondrous item, legendary, requires attunement

This clockwork amulet’s past is a mystery, though it does possess Egyptian hieroglyphics and Phonecian runes hinting at its ancient Mediterranean origin. It is said that only the most powerful minds in the world can bind it to its will.

The amulet can be fed with spell slots of any level. The total level of spell slots used to feed the amulet determines its charges. It can have 15 charges maximum. By spending any number of charges you want with an action, you can do one of the following:

  • Golem Summoning: You can summon a golem within 30 ft. of you in an unoccupied space based on the charges you spent: Jahi Golemh (1) Flesh Golemj (3), Grim Golemj (4), Clay Golemj(5), Stone Golemj (6), Iron Golemj (8). The golems that have been summoned stay for 1 minute and fight by your side. You can issue commands using your bonus action. They vanish after 1 minute, they reach 0 hit points, or until you die.
  • Breath of Life (at least 5 charges): You animate objects around you following the rules of the animate objects spell by spending 5 charges. You can make your creations more powerful depending on the extra charges you spend: +1 attack bonus to each object (2), extra hit points equal to your proficiency bonus to each object (2), +1 to Armor Class of each object (2), or +10 movement speed (2).

Bow of Barjik.name: Bow of Barjik
Bow of Barjik.text:
@UUID[Item.9eVZvpaxwdOjbZRD]{Bow of Barjik}

Longbow, legendary, requires attunement

Legendary commander of the Khazar cavalries and bane of the Arabic armies marching into the Caucasus, it is said that Barjik single-handedly hunted down the most prominent commanders in the opposing army with this longbow. With a twist of fate following Barjik’s death, this longbow found its way to a Kievan merchant, stolen by Black Sea pirates, who sold it to a Maghrebi merchant, who supposedly lost it over the dunes of the Sahara.

This is a magical longbow. It gives +3 to attack rolls and damage rolls made with it.

As an action, you whisper three names that are within 500 ft. of you and loose one arrow from the bow to the sky. Nicknames, pseudonyms, and titles do not work. Each creature you named must succeed on a DC 17 Constitution saving throw or take 10d10 force damage. The weapon can be used this way once a long rest.

The bow holds the text in Old Turkic: 𐰚𐰀𐰠𐱅𐰢𐰚𐰇𐰼𐱅𐰢𐰘𐰀𐰏𐰓𐰢, which translates to the famous words of Julius Caesar: “Veni, vidi, vici.”

Ring of Roland.name: Ring of Roland
Ring of Roland.text:
@UUID[Item.LTwWLMtG92pbXvbd]{Ring of Roland}

Wondrous item, legendary, requires attunement

This legendary ring is rumored to have been worn by the great Charlemagne and was gifted to a young man-at-arms after a feat of courage. Although a mundane ring at first, the young soldier’s faith in the emperor, and hidden potential exposed by the magic in the ring, helped him to become one of the finest warriors ever: Roland from the Song of Roland. The Ring’s exact succession is lost to history, but it is known that it reached the hands of Balian of Ibelin.

While wearing and attuned to this ring, you can choose a creature within 60 ft. of you and grant them temporary hit points as an action equal to your Charisma modifier + 2d10. The ring has 6 charges and gains charges equal to 1d6 at every dawn.

  • Spending 4 charges, you choose up to ten Commonersj or a similar humanoid with a CR lower than 1. All of them now count as Knightsj. This change lasts until the next dawn. You can use the ring’s power once per dawn. If you choose the same people for ten consecutive days and succeed on a DC 15 Charisma saving throw for each person, the change becomes permanent.

Weapon (spear), legendary, requires attunement

The spear has a reach of 10 ft. and 3 charges (regains 1d3 charges at dawn). Once you expend a charge with a bonus action you gain the following benefits for 1 minute: Your walking speed becomes 60 ft, you are immune to fall damage, you don’t provoke opportunity attacks, you gain +2 bonus to your Armor Class, and you have advantage on Dexterity saving throws.

Magical Items & Trinkets in the Holy Lan.name: Magical Items & Trinkets in the Holy Lands
Magical Items & Trinkets in the Holy Lan.text:
Magical Items & Trinkets in the Holy Lands

Most of the common magic items, although named common, are not that frequently encountered among the common markets or are mostly ignored by the common folk due to not knowing they are magic items at all. Most of them became magical over time due to the natural magic surrounding the world and thanks to the will of others rather than sentiently crafted by magicians and inventors. Uncommon magic items are harder to come by in regular markets and remote corners of the world. Unlike common magic items, they are usually crafted by magicians or inventors, most notably potions, weapons, shields, and ammunition. Rarer magic items might not catch one’s eye in a market; they will be in the hands of the most prominent figures or be lying within the dust and rust in forgotten corners. Due to Historica Arcanum’s magical rules, rarer items are hardly encountered, and thus there are fewer number of Rare and Very Rare items.

Deck of the Damned.name: Deck of the Damned
Deck of the Damned.text:
Adventuring is an endeavor full of risks and hazards, from entering deadly catacombs filled with angry and cackling undead, striking a deal with very stubborn shopkeepers, to facing the wrath of hungry, and gluttonous red dragons. Unpredictable and unfortunate events may happen to the adventurers other than getting hurt, such as dealing with too much stress, suffering the tragedy of a lost one, witnessing an otherworldly entity that devours mortal lives, or uncovering horrible truths. These situations may create scenarios where hit points and the like are not enough to represent them mechanically.

5th edition offers some alternate ways for these scenarios, such as Sanity ability scores and Madness Tables tied to them; however, they are mostly tied to alien contact and psychic damage, and we wanted to create new mechanics for enduring the stress caused during adventuring.

How can you receive stress?

Stress may be caused in three ways in this system: During combat, dealing with arcane mysteries, or through grim events that happen outside of combat that we call tragedy.

During combat, an adventuring party may witness many occasions that can cause stress to one or all members of the party: death of a party member, extreme and permanent injuries, being defeated and cornered by an enemy, and so forth.

Arcane horrors may cause extreme stress, even to those who are attuned to magic, in such events like: Contacting otherworldly creatures for the first time, discovering horrible truths on arcane matters, sustaining mind-altering effects, witnessing excessive magic used in a less-than-savory way, and many other cataclysmic supernatural occurrences.

Tragic events may break even the most heartless. Suffering the loss of a family member, witnessing the fall of the city they grew up in, treachery by a beloved, trusted individual or an organization, dissolving the adventuring party, watching a friend walk away for good, scenes of merciless savagery, and other quite distasteful situations are all incidents that may cause lasting changes.

When such an event happens, follow the rules below and apply the written instructions. If some situations coincide in more than one category it is up to the Game Master to decide which category to apply.

If you have the card deck called Deck of the Damned instead of using the written section here, it is advised that a card from the deck is drawn when an event is triggered. It is much more immersive to slam an ominous card deck on the table when damnation is near.

Mental Threshold

It is important to note that each adventuring group may have different thresholds while dealing with stress. Not every heavy injury or death has to impact the party greatly, and may not result in drawing a card from the deck. To that end, we added different severities to ease the burden on the Game Masters. However, it is ultimately the Game Master’s duty to tailor the triggers to the feeling of the setting.

General Rules

  • Severity I category usually deals with DC 12 saving throws.
  • Severity II category usually deals with DC 14 saving throws.
  • Severity III category usually deals with DC 16 saving throws.
  • Events usually contain negative outcomes for the adventurers and in times of success, the possibility of the negative is countered by a chance of smaller positive effect.
  • The GM always has the final say on the mechanics and role-playing effects.

Combat Deck.name: Combat Deck
Combat Deck.text:
Combat Deck

Some fights do not go according to plan. Adventurers that are usually unfazed in the presence of danger, may lose all sensibilities when confronted with death being a distinct possibility. Severe injuries and other desperate situations impact the adventurers in ways other than simply physical, to their dismay.

Combat stress can occur in hard combat encounters, harsh situations and desperate outcomes. Follow the table below to determine which severity applies to the situation at hand.

SEVERITY LEVEL

TRIGGERS

Severity I

Generally, if the combat is going in an unfortunate direction for the Players:

  • A Player Character or an ally taking significant or unexpected damage:

    • A Critical Hit.
    • A Player Character dropping below half of their maximum Hit Points.
    • A Player Character losing a third of their Hit Points due to a single Attack/Spell.
    • A Player Character being hit by an Attack of Opportunity.
  • Encountering powerful enemies (Total Enemy CR Count being 3 CR Higher than the Party Composition)

  • Enemies showing advanced talent for warfare:

    • A Legendary Resistance triggered,
    • An enemy casting a 5th level or higher Spell,
    • Other unique or powerful features.

Severity II

Generally, if the combat is going in a direction that threatens the lives and/or freedom of one or more party members or allies:

  • A Player Character or an ally taking heavy damage or being stuck in a dangerous position:

    • A party member or an ally dropping to 0 hit points.
    • A Player Character losing at least half of their Hit Points due to a single Attack/Spell (rounds up)
    • Harsh, permanent injuries (losing an eye, a limb, crippling, etc.)
    • A Player Character being Flanked, attacked and damaged.
  • A Level 3 or Higher Spell by Player Characters being Counterspelled, or failed due to the enemy breaking the caster’s concentration.
  • Facing malicious actions by NPCs; for example, a party member or an ally taken prisoner by the enemy.

  • Encountering deadly enemies (Total Enemy CR Count being 5 CR Higher than the Party Composition)Enemies showing deadly talent for warfare:

    • A Legendary Action triggered,
    • An enemy casting a 6th level or higher Spell,
    • Other unique or powerful features.

Severity III

Generally, if the combat is going in a direction that all but ensures total destruction for the party members and their allies:

  • A Party member or an ally taking insurmountable damage or being stuck in a life-threatening situation:

    • A party member or an ally dying.
    • A Player Character losing at least three quarters of their Hit Points due to a single Attack/Spell (rounds up).
    • A Player Character being completely surrounded by enemies.
  • A Level 5 or Higher Spell by Player Characters being Counterspelled, or failed due to the enemy breaking the caster’s Concentration.
  • Facing incredibly cruel actions by NPCs; for example, assaulting already downed allies.
  • Encountering cataclysmic enemies (Total Enemy CR Count being 7 CR Higher than the Party Composition)

  • Enemies showing impervious talent for warfare:

    • A Legendary Action triggered twice in one round (from multiple enemies or sources), or a Legendary Action that costs 2 points is triggered,
    • An enemy casting a 7th level or higher Spell,
    • Other unique or powerful features.

Arcane Deck.name: Arcane Deck
Arcane Deck.text:
Arcane Deck

A journey into the arcane and the eldritch mysteries will make a mockery of a feeble mind. One may never know what secrets the magical weapons or arcane tomes found in gloomy dungeons, eerie graveyards, or forsaken mansions hold within. Encountering dreadful creatures, witnessing unimaginable spells and rituals, or facing supernatural monsters and threats that belong to horrible realism beyond imagination can affect one’s psyche and connection to magic severely. Beware, for arcane breeds arcane, and eldritch anomalies may turn the tide in an unexpected deluge of magic.

Removing the effects:The negative effects gained by the Arcane Stress have three general rules:

  • Severity I effects can be removed with a lesser restoration spell.
  • Severity II effects can be removed with a remove curse spell.
  • Severity III effects can be removed with a greater restoration spell.

Lesser severities can be removed with higher severities’ spells. For example, remove curse spell can be used for Severity I effects.

For Arcane stress triggers, you can check the table below:

SEVERITY LEVEL

example TRIGGERS

Severity I

  • Encountering a hostile otherworldly creature for the first time.
  • Being subjected to mind-altering spells (such as command or charm person)
  • Witnessing the impeccable talents of non-humanoid creatures that are not beasts or monstrosities (Such as a dragon’s breath, a zombie’s undead fortitude, a vampire spawn’s fangs, a werewolf’s shapeshift, or a similar feature).
  • Witnessing the effects of a destructive spell. Level 3 spells or higher.
  • Encountering non-humanoid creatures that have a CR greater than 6. Some monstrosities may also apply this condition due to their nature.
  • Hearing otherworldly tongues. In classic fantasy games: infernal, abyssal, draconic, or primordial. For Historica Arcanum universe: djinnspeech.

Severity II

  • Witnessing a strong curse or a deadly magical disease.
  • Witnessing a highly destructive spell like fireball, ice storm, or disintegrate.
  • Encountering non-humanoid creatures that have a CR greater than 9. Some monstrosities may also apply this condition due to their nature.
  • Witnessing a possession or a magical charm from an otherworldly creature, such as a powerful fey, celestial, or a fiend.
  • Witnessing 4th Level spells or higher.
  • Witnessing CR 5 or Higher Aberrations.
  • Witnessing magical physical alterations such as a polymorph spell or a ghost’sj aging effect, a basilisk’sj petrifying.

Severity III

  • Witnessing a spell of 5th level or higher (In other universes, this may vary)
  • Witnessing a deadly curse or a mass magical disease (such as Chrysalis of Dreams from Historica Arcanum: Herald of Rain).
  • Being exposed to extreme psychic damage.
  • Facing creatures beyond imagining (Non-humanoid creatures above CR 12)
  • Encountering otherworldly heralds, messengers, harbingers, devotees of extremely important figures, such as: a demon lord’s messenger, an angel of a deity, a warlock of an archfey,
  • Facing powerful rituals, resurrections, artifacts, sentient magic items, and similar situations.

Some of the Arcane Stress usually results in flaws and other mid- to long-term effects rather than mechanical results. Communication between the Game Master and the Player Character is highly recommended while dealing with said flaws and effects and applying them to the game.

Tragedy Deck.name: Tragedy Deck
Tragedy Deck.text:
Tragedy Deck

Some friends may turn into foes, some comrades may stab you in the back, a vile sickness may turn your homeland into a noxious wasteland, or an unexpected arson can devastate whole civilizations. A tragedy may lurk behind every corner, and an adventurer never knows when it will strike - and what incurable wounds it may leave.

Tragedy stress may occur in such conditions as mentioned in the table below:

SEVERITY LEVEL

TRIGGER

Severity I

  • Betrayal of a dear and trusted comrade, companion or a loved one.
  • Being part of a disastrous battle, war or a similar conflict.
  • Watching friends, close relatives or people that are close to them fighting impossible illnesses or other long-time hardships, such as poverty, imprisonment, exile, discord among family or friends.
  • Failing an important quest.

Severity II

  • Death of people that are thought to be very dear.
  • Witnessing the rise of a corrupted faction that condemns innocents and spreads chaos and/or enforces their iron fists.
  • Watching innocents suffer.
  • Watching people that are close to you suffer and be in serious pain.

Severity III

  • Natural disasters such as fires, floods, earthquakes, and storms affecting the cities, towns or villages that are considered important.
  • Witnessing the fall or a defeat of a beloved organization, faction or a legal body such as a kingdom or similar entities (For example, The Fall of Constantinople in 1453 CE).
  • Losing or facing the failure of long-devised plans, hopes, or dreams.
  • Getting betrayed by almost all loved ones and trusted companions.
  • Being left alone or shunned by loved ones, comrades, or a beloved organization.

Tragedy Stress usually causes flaws for characters to deal with. Strong communication between the player character and the GM is advised to apply these flaws. Most of the results in this deck are considered permanent and require a serious healing process if one wishes to be cured. If a GM wants an easier solution, it is advised to use rules from Arcane stress to get rid of the effects.

Blessed One.name: Blessed One
Blessed One.text:
@UUID[Item.kI0B3ZJMO6XCedD5]{Blessed One}

Your dedication and time spent in holy places have affected you. You feel a divinity in your heart and you know a blessing is upon you:

  • Your Wisdom score increases by 1.
  • You learn a cleric or druid cantrip of your choice.
  • You choose either the bless or the protection from evil and good spell. You can cast that spell without expending a spell slot. Once you do so, you can’t do so again until you finish a long rest. If you have spell slots, you can cast the spell normally using your spell slots.

Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

Desert Wanderer.name: Desert Wanderer
Desert Wanderer.text:
@UUID[Item.FmhbgFdnE4zmCMMn]{Desert Wanderer}

A life in the desert is not unfamiliar to you. You showed respect to the sands, and now they respect you back. You gain the following benefits:

  • Your Strength, Constitution or Wisdom score increases by 1.
  • You gain proficiency in the Survival and Nature skills.
  • Choose one skill you are proficient in. You double your proficiency bonus on the chosen skill if you have not already doubled it from another source, such as Rogue’s expertise.
  • You are not affected by extreme heat conditions.
  • Your speed is not affected by dunes, sandstorms, and other phenomena of the desert.
  • You only need 1/3 of the water humanoids normally need.

Eldritch Warden.name: Eldritch Warden
Eldritch Warden.text:
@UUID[Item.k5IhTrX0vJzYJ64P]{Eldritch Warden}

Prerequisites: Spellcasting or Pact Magic feature

You dedicated your studies to eldritch lore, and your skills and insight understand the rift between the material world and beyond the veil. You gain the following benefits:

  • Your Charisma score increases by 1.
  • You sense any djinn or aberration within 10 ft. you.
  • You can cast the detect evil and good spell once a day, without expending a spell slot. You can’t do so again until you finish a short or long rest.
  • By expending a spell slot when you deal damage to an otherworldly being (which is not humanoid, beast, monstrosity, dragon or giant) you deal an extra 2d8 force damage to the creature and an extra 1d8 force damage for each slot level above the 1st.
