New Recruitment Methods.text:
New Recruitment Methods

Donations

Most organizations require at least 25 gd of donations to let outsiders in.

Letter of recommendation

An important figure from a respected circle must recommend the individual(s) to the order: A noble knight, a respected doctor, a high priest, a bishop, an honored dervish, a well-known imam, etc.

A show of courage and chivalry

The candidates must prove themselves courageous and noble to join such an order. They must be challenged to a duel, asked to take on a quest, and face a fear. Earlier sightings of such actions can also be enough. For example, a candidate may have lost an eye while standing up to bandits, saved comrades during a battle, killed a renowned enemy, may have gained recognition for chasing dire wolves away from their village or a similar event.

A show of scientific work and research

Some organizations demand that the candidates are well educated and put effort into research, scientific advancement or scholarly pursuits. A book, the results of an experiment, or a similar proof may be needed.

Dedication, belief or determination

Some organizations require a show of loyalty and dedication, they may test the candidates for a period of time to test their determination to join the organization. They may be starved, put in heavy work or a similar approach may be followed.

Several tests, including mental and physical.

Some organizations may prepare challenges to test possible candidates. These tests may be physical: a show of strength, stamina or agility. Also, they can be mental and challenge their intelligence, conscience and wits, such as a puzzle, a mathematical question, a moral dilemma, a brain teaser, or a similar one.

Ballot

A group of voters may choose who joins the order or not. The voters may look for several qualities depending on the goal of order: Strength, belief, agility, intelligence, kind heart, deep pockets, or a similar one.

Interview

A recruiter may be assigned to interview and test candidates with certain important questions and examine given answers, body language and intention of the candidate and decide whether to let them in or not.

Pretty much anyone can enter.

It is usually an easy process to enter and almost everyone is welcome. This method is seen especially in times of war and turmoil.

Possible Quest Ideas

If players wish to join an organization, the recruiters may wish to test them by sending them on a quest to prove themselves.

Fetch Quest

The organization may ask the adventurers to find an object of importance. A saint’s bones, a sword of a late knight, a sacred jewel, a magic item, a cursed armor, etc.

Escort Quest

An important figure related to the organization must reach a destination unharmed. Adventurers are usually a good choice for these kinds of quests.

Infiltration Quest

The adventurers must infiltrate, undetected, a place of importance. They may be asked to fetch an item, extract an important prisoner, assassinate a specific individual, cripple the location’s supplies, or a similar purpose.

Supernatural Investigation

A mysterious event must be investigated by the adventurers; possibly they are the only ones capable of doing it. A disappearance, haunting screams, seemingly possessed individuals, undead, mishaps caused by magical objects, otherworldly creatures, etc.

Monster Hunting

Some dangerous monster(s) are causing problems nearby. The adventurers must hunt down the creature(s) and end this threat. It can be a harpy, ghost, imp, zombie, griffon, werewolf, wight, green hag, gorgon, troll or a similar danger.

Finding a Weakness

A suspicious leader may ask the adventurers to find a weakness in the organization and exploit it. This weakness may be a spy of another organization, a betrayer, a possessed individual, a garrulous member, a corrupt bureaucrat, or a similar person.

Strongholds & Headquarters.name: Strongholds & Headquarters
Strongholds & Headquarters.text:
Strongholds & Headquarters

An organization’s center is usually the most important part of it. Its strength, influence, quality of members, and many other aspects may depend on it.

Moving Center

Some organizations do not stay in one place and want to be agile at all times, such as steppe nomads of Central Asia. This method is usually adopted by knightly organizations that were put together for times of war, crusade, and turmoil.

Features

Agile and Adaptable

These kinds of headquarters enable the organization to move quickly and react steadily to dangers and very similar situations.

Mobile Members

Members of this organization possess horses and move at incredible speeds. They are usually armed and proficient with proper weapons and armors. Or at least they hire such mercenaries for protection.

Lack of Centralism

This organization suffers in the long run if it does not settle in a secure position and are only dependent on plunder and raids. This will make the members warmongers and hungry for such campaigns.

Charismatic Leader

Such organizations usually depend on charismatic leaders to operate and tend to dissolve quickly if an inferior power takes the lead.

Potential Size

250 - 2,000+ people

Possible NPCs

Commonerj, Guardj, Tribal Warriorj, Acolytej, Scoutj, Thugj, Spyj, Druidj, Priestj, Knightj, Veteranj, Steppe Riderh, Steppe Raiderh, Steppe Shamanh

Guild Hall

Some organizations take up, rent or settle in guild halls in large building complexes and operate from it.

Features

Small Sphere

These organizations are either newly founded, intentionally small, or remain small due to lack of success.

Economical Weakness

Small organizations tend to have relatively smaller pockets and must be careful about how to spend their resources. Resources could mean coins, weapons, medicine, food and members.

Special Members

Some organizations tend to stay small but care about their members more than all. Some of these members may be exceptionally good at what they do. This could be a band of brothers founded by very skillful swordsmen, the best craftsmen in the city, or a similar foundation.

Loyalty

Small organizations can lack greater numbers, but they excel in fostering strong bonds between members. Such organizations probably have more loyal and dedicated members that protect each other’s backs.

Potential Size

10-50 people.

Simple Building

Some organizations settle in large buildings with many floors and establish their roots from there. It usually implies their influence and relatively strong economic power.

Features

Guarding the Building

These organizations need to guard their rooms, entrances and possible vaults better than most. If the organization has military aspects, it is usually handled in-house, but other types of organizations either trust the sacred grounds or hire agile hands from outside.

Reaching Hands

These organizations probably have deeper pockets and many contacts in the city. They receive guests and have their hands reach far places among society. They are probably in touch with government officials or religious figures to secure them legally.

External Threats

These organizations probably have enemies outside and are challenged by them from time to time. They may send spies, challenge them legally, take up arms, or similarly threaten them.

Potential Size

50-200 people.

Possible NPCs

Commoner*, Guard*, Acolyte*, Scout*, Thug*, Spy*, Druid*, Priest*

Building Complex

Some organizations cover large areas consisting of many buildings, big and small, and gardens within them. Open fields can be used for gatherings, training, rituals, bazaars, or a similar purpose.

Features

Hard to Protect

Covering a large area creates weaknesses that could be exploited. Many organizations hire hands outside or train their own guards to prevent that.

Internal Threats

There may be many spies, ill-intended members that abuse the resources of the order, or similar corrupted members throughout the organization. Building complexes offer many hiding locations.

Famous & Rich

These organizations probably are influential among their society and respected (or maybe feared) by all. This situation creates many possibilities for the allies.

Great Potential

As the organization is growing, it hosts many potential stars and failures.

Potential Size

200 - 1,000 people.

Possible NPCs

Commoner*, Guard*, Tribal Warrior*, Acolyte*, Scout*, Thug*, Spy*, Druid*, Priest*, Knight*

Small Keep

Organizations that hold small keeps usually have military power and military purposes. The keep could serve the organization as a bastion, a base of operations, a sacred ground, or more.

Features

A Small Army

These organizations are possibly rich and influential enough to raise a small army and thus have efficient power and influence among the land. They can enact military campaigns, join bigger causes, defend themselves, and threaten their enemies.

Strong Walls

Thanks to walls that guard them, keeps can usually be defended against larger forces and offer a strong base of operations. Members, officials and all that depend on the organization can feel safe as long as the walls stand strong.

Crowded Spaces

This kind of organization possibly attracts many people from their land and is exceptionally crowded. This situation carries many potential boons or banes: Spies, undiscovered gems, betrayers, strong soldiers, devoted members, and more. It can also create a shortage of water, accommodation, arms, ammunition, tools, and food supplies.

Useful Connections

These organizations possibly have strong ties to local lords, religious leaders, and other powerful orders and organizations. Big cities and crowded lands probably know them, and there are many who want to be on their good side.

Potential Size

1,000-3,000 people.

Possible NPCs

Commoner*, Guard*, Tribal Warrior*, Acolyte*, Scout*, Thug*, Spy*, Druid*, Priest*, Knight*, Noble*, Veteran*, Ghulam Warrior

Castle & Fortress

The epitome of most orders and organizations is to own a well-fortified castle that could host armies inside it.

Features

Fate of the Land

Orders that are this big and powerful usually have enough power and influence to decide the tides of fate that impact their realm. In historical context, the Order of Assassins (Hashashin Order), the Order of the Templars, and the House of Wisdom are good examples of such organizations.

Powerful Connections

These organizations are probably recognized by powerful lords, influential bishops, patriarchs, kings, sultans, emirs and other monarchs throughout the land.

All Eyes On Them

These organizations draw eyes onto themselves and become the center of attention.

Potential Size

3,000+ people, that can go up to 5,000 or more.

Possible NPCs

Commoner*, Guard*, Tribal Warrior*, Acolyte*, Scout*, Thug*, Spy*, Druid*, Priest*, Knight*, Veteran*, Gladiator*, Mage*, Assassin*, Archmage*, Ghulam Warrior, Ghulam Veteran, Sage of Baghdad

Step III: When Player Characters Establi.name: Step III: When Player Characters Establish an Order
Step III: When Player Characters Establi.text:
Step III: When Player Characters Establish an Order

In the course of a game, players may want to start their own organizations for many different reasons. In order to do that they must attract many people to their goal and fund the necessary coins. Unless they take over an already established organization, they must start from the beginning.

It could be assumed that the players’ organization starts from the possible lowest options in the tables in Step I (Sphere of Influence, Scale of the Order, and similar aspects), and the process of building the organization can be tied to Downtime Activities.

Reputation.name: Reputation
Reputation.text:
Reputation

Organizations that are run by NPCs are usually under the GM’s control, and their reputation may be tied to powerful adventurers’ actions if they act on it. However, organizations founded by player characters may require a small system to show how their organization is doing and how it is perceived by society.

Reputation is a table that may be affected by external events, players’ deeds, and many other reasons determined by the GM. Reputation can be perceived as popularity, influence, and infamy of the organization, and low Reputation usually means negative thoughts and actions by society. Zero Reputation usually means that the organization is not that famous in the realm. +4 Reputation means that people of the realm have positive ideas about the organization but depending on the size of the order, this positive reputation may impact the game differently. A smaller scale organization may be seen as a strike team or a very valuable team as a greater scale organization may be viewed as a whole army.

Positive Passive Effect: Organization members gain a bonus equal to the effect’s level on Charisma and Wisdom checks including locals and topics related to their organizations.

Negative Passive Effect: Organization members gain a negative bonus equal to the effect’s level on Charisma and Wisdom checks. The GM may reverse the bonus on Charisma (Intimidation) checks if the organization’s Reputation is low due to infamous and cruel actions.

Other than these effects, each level gives different types of non-mechanical effects to organization members.

Reputation Table

Reputatıon Level

EFFECT

+4

The organization is one of the most influential and popular entities in the realm. People form long lines at the doorstep to sign up, and donations ensure the economy spins better than ever.

+3

The organization is loved by the crowds and the members are usually offered food, accommodation and even nightly companionships throughout the realm. People want to join the ranks and are more than happy to be in the organization’s favor.

+2

Locals are happy with the organization’s existence, may accept one or two favors and are more keen to give out donations.

+1

Locals are inclined to talk and listen to the organization members and genuinely think better of them.

0

No effect.

-1

People usually greet the members with a sour face but accept them as a part of society.

-2

The locals usually don’t like members’ presence around them and actively show it. Even some members dislike this situation.

-3

The locals verbally and physically show that this organization is not their favorite. Brawls, arrests, and similar unwanted situations may occur throughout the land.

-4

Either the organization retreated underground or the locals form up at your doorstep with strong voices and maybe torches and pikes.

Member Happiness.name: Member Happiness
Member Happiness.text:
Member Happiness

For each month spent without Focus the Internal Affairs (see below) during downtime (or without any actions to make members happier, such as increasing food supplies, generous gifts, or similar), the GM makes a d20 roll and adds bonus depending on the situation of the organization. The difficulty is usually 10.

Happiness Table

POSSIBLE SITUATIONS

BONUS

Recent battles (lost)

-4

Recent battles (won)

-2

Food or water shortage

-3

Prosperous times

+3

Scientific progress

+2

Natural disaster

-5

A visit from a powerful figure (such as a noble lord, a king, archbishop, or similar)

+2

A major schism

-5

End of dire times (such as a long war, a plague)

+4

This table is to offer ideas, not definite numbers. A GM may change the bonuses depending on the situation and apply more situations to the table as well, as it is advised to do so.

Happiness Table

Reputatıon Level

EFFECT

+4

Leaders (usually the player characters) have advantage on Charisma and Wisdom checks equal to the level while interacting with members of the organization.

More outsiders wish to join the ranks of the organization, thus the word is spreading.

Current members are more loyal than ever and are less keen on betrayal or departure.

+3

Leaders (usually the player characters) gain +3 bonus on Charisma and Wisdom checks equal to the level while interacting with members of the organization.

People are inclined and keen to be convinced to join the ranks of this organization.

Current members are exceptionally loyal and aren’t likely to betray the order or depart it.

+2

Leaders (usually the player characters) gain +2 bonus on Charisma and Wisdom checks equal to the level while interacting with members of the organization.

People are interested in joining due to the good standards the organization sets.

Current members are exceptionally loyal and aren’t likely to betray the order or depart it.

+1

Leaders (usually the player characters) gain +1 bonus on Charisma and Wisdom checks equal to the level while interacting with members of the organization.

Current members are happy where they are and mostly loyal.

0

No special effects.

-1

Members are unhappy and want things to be fixed by the overseers and leaders of the organization. Unless proven that leaders care about them and try to fix things, leaders receive -1 bonus to Charisma and Wisdom checks while interacting with the members.

-2

Members are restless and unhappy. They probably don’t see improvement efforts and are more prone to leave or betray the organization. Unless proven that leaders care about them and try to fix things, leaders receive -2 bonus to Charisma and Wisdom checks while interacting with the members.

-3

Mutiny may be at hand. Members are really unhappy. If this is a crowded organization, members have already started to depart the organization and some may have accepted bribes to spy on behalf of rivals. Leaders receive -3 bonus to Charisma and Wisdom checks while interacting with the members.

-4

A revolt is about to happen. Members are leaving daily and some may try to rouse the crowd for a revolt. The organization is on the brink of dissolving. Leaders receive disadvantage on Charisma and Wisdom checks when interacting with the members.

Downtime Activities.name: Downtime Activities
Downtime Activities.text:
Downtime Activities

Establishing an Order

Resources: One month and at least 2,500 gold dinars. If players already have loyal followers and a big influence over the realm, the cost can be reduced by half at the GM’s discretion. Most of the money is spent on a Guild Hall-like building and renovating the space, as well as handling official documents and other necessities.

Checks:

1) Charisma (Persuasion) check. Required to affect necessary people.

2)Intelligence check. Intelligence (Insight) or Wisdom (Insight) may also apply. Required to prevent extra costs and potential failure members as well as legal concerns.

Resolutions:

1) If the check total is equal to or above 10:the GM rolls 2d10 + highest Charisma modifier of the player characters that attended this activity. The result is the number of new members of the order. Depending on the type, members can have a variety of skills, proficiencies, talents, and features.

If the check total is below 10:Only a handful of people agreed to join. The GM rolls 2d6. The result equals the number of people who join.

If the check total is below 5:No one joins the order.

2) If the check total is equal to or above 10:The cost is reduced by 500 gd, and the GM reveals potential ill-intended members.

If the check total is below 10:The cost stays the same, and the GM does not reveal bad members.

If the check total is below 5: Due to complications, the cost is increased by 500 gd.

Complications:Before a one month-period ends, the GM rolls a secret d20. On a roll of 1 or 2, they select one of the options below:

  • The HQ is haunted.
  • A fire (or other seemingly natural cataclysm) badly damages the building.
  • Secretly, an adversary joins while acting as a humble and good member.

Recruit Members

Resources: One week and 250 gd per 5 recruits

Checks: Charisma (Persuasion) or Intelligence (Religion) depending on the type of organization

Resolution:

Check total is 20 or above: 2d10+5 people join your order.

Check total is 15 or above: 2d10 people join your order.

Check total is 10 or above: No one joins your order.

Check total is below 10: No one joins your order.

Check total is below 5: You gain an adversary and possibly lose Reputation.

Complications: Before a one month-period ends, the GM rolls a secret d20. On a roll of 1 or 2, selects one of the options below:

  • Bad word reaches out to the public, and your organization loses 1 Reputation.
  • Local law enforcement accuses you of challenging the established authority of the realm, and you can’t enlist new members.
  • Secretly, an adversary joins while acting as a humble and good member.

Carousing with Locals

Resources: 200 gd and one week.

Checks: Charisma (Persuasion) or Charisma (Performance)

Resolution:

Check total is 20 or above: Reputation increases by 1d3.

Check total is 15 or above: Reputation increases by 1d2.

Check total is 10 or above: Reputation increases by 1.

Check total is below 10: Reputation decreases by 1.

Check total is below 5: Reputation decreases by 1d2.

Complications: Before a one month-period ends, the GM rolls a secret d20. On a roll of 1 or 2, they select one of the options below:

  • Happiness decreases by 1 due to bad word about the organization.
  • A good number of members have been arrested.
  • The organization gains adversaries who have a strong voice among the locals.

Reaching Out to the Middle Class

Resources: 1,000 gd and one week

Checks: Charisma (Persuasion) or a proper tool check.

Resolution:

Check total is 20 or above: Middle Class and at least 3 important figures owe you a few favors.

Check total is 15 or above: Reputation increases by 1d2.

Check total is 10 or above: Reputation increases by 1.

Check total is below 10: Reputation decreases by 1.

Check total is below 5: Reputation decreases by 1d2.

Complications: Before a one month-period ends, the GM rolls a secret d20. On a roll of 1 or 2, they select one of the options below:

  • Artisans and traders refuse to work with you, thus Happiness decreases by 1.
  • You have been informed that the goods or items you received recently are bad.
  • The Nobility deem you a danger, and they threaten you and your organization with legal implications.

Meetings with Nobles

Resources: One workweek and 1,000 gd.

Checks: Charisma (Persuasion) check.

Resolution:

Check total is 20 or above: Four nobles owe you a few favors.

Check total is 15 or above: Two nobles owe you a few favors.

Check total is 10 or above: A noble owes you a few favors.

Check total is below 10: Reputation decreases by 1d2.

Check total is below 5: Reputation decreases by 1d3.

Complications: Before a one month-period ends, the GM rolls a secret d20. On a roll of 1 or 2, selects one of the options below:

  • The most embarrassing rumor about your organization or about you spreads in the land like a wild fire.
  • One of the nobles is severely angered or annoyed by you.
  • You are banned from operating in one of the nobles’ areas.

Focus the Internal Affairs

Resources:One workweek and 350 gd.

Checks: Charisma (Persuasion) check.

Resolution:

Check total is 20 or above: Happiness increases by 1d4.

Check total is 15 or above: Happiness increases by 1d2.

Check total is 10 or above: Happiness increases by 1.

Check total is below 10: Happiness decreases by 1.

Check total is below 5: Happiness decreases by 1d2.

Complications: Before a one month-period ends, the GM rolls a secret d20. On a roll of 1 or 2, they select one of the options below:

  • A small but significant number of members leave your organization.
  • A member from a higher rank develops negative feelings towards one of the leaders. It may grow dangerously.
  • Word reaches out to the public, and Reputation decreases by 1d4.

Law & Creed.name: Law & Creed
Law & Creed.text:
Law & Creed

What kind of rules and principles does your order follow? What are the definite prohibitions of your order that members should strictly abide by? What are the main points of your creed? The tables in this section can be rolled more than once to come up with several options.

Governing Style

@UUID[Macro.U8jElTxIP4gVHHAh]{Roll governing style Table}

d6

result

1

Elective (Term): A leader is elected among the members after the leader has served for an agreed period of time –for example, every 5 years.

2

Elective (On Death): A leader serves for life or until dispatched from leadership due to a crime, disease, or the like. After the leader’s demise, a new leader is elected.

3

Inheritance: The new leader is the heir to the late leader; he or she can be their blood relative, a designated follower, a pupil, or a similar individual.

4

Appointment by a higher power: A king, a lord, a high priest, a patriarch, or a similar individual of power appoints the head of your order. Perhaps this higher power is of the eldritch kind.

5

A ruling council: The order is ruled by a council which chooses its members.

6

Elders: The oldest members of the order rule and decide the future of the order.

Main Principles of the Order

@UUID[Macro.icC9V41MrlTluc8a]{Roll main principles of the order Table}

d10

result

1

Honor and duty

2

To help those in need

3

Triumph of the faith

4

Defense of the land

5

Profit and advancement

6

Exploration and discovery of the unknown

7

Science/medicine and progression

8

Protect the rights of their fellow comrades

9

Occult Studies

10

Protecting art/artisanship

General Rules

@UUID[Macro.lK9XrlnUpLWiHoGT]{Roll general rules Table}

d10

result

1

Armed conflict is the last resort.

2

Do not hurt the innocent.

3

Do not forgive or trust infidels.

4

Always help the poor.

5

Never resort to the arcane - whether it is a spell, or a sentient creature.

6

The arcane powers are the world’s salvation. Always utilize them for advantage, no matter the cost.

7

Preserve the written documents - the palest ink is better than the sharpest memory.

8

We protect one of our own, at all costs.

9

Treachery calls for death. Any other outcome is unthinkable.

10

Violence is not the answer; it is the question. And the answer is always a blood red yes!

Prohibitions

@UUID[Macro.WF8roWwbYToMnXlO]{Roll prohibitions Table}

d10

result

1

Members can’t marry.

2

Members can’t be from other religions.

3

Members can’t consume alcoholic beverages or any other mind altering substances.

4

Members can’t reveal their faces to non-members.

5

Members must not use their real names.

6

Members should live a humble life with little possessions except the tools of their trade.

7

Members can’t carry weapons / Members must always be armed.

8

Members can’t consume a specific type of food.

9

Members can’t resort to arcane powers, even if they are critically needed.

10

Members must go out of their way to access arcane powers. Letting go of an opportunity must be punished.

Cairo The Jewel of the Nile.name: Cairo The Jewel of the Nile

Cairo the Jewel of the Nile.name: Cairo the Jewel of the Nile
Cairo the Jewel of the Nile.text:
“The things of the invisible world attract me more than those of actual life.”

-Ibn Arabi

Pharaohs and god-kings of old, generals and the blood of Alexander, Caesars of many Rubicons crossed, the riders hoisting crescent-adorned banners, descendants of prophets and emperors… All have trod upon the sands of these lands. All have seen the cities of desert and water, ruling the horizons with reflections of eons, shimmering through the surface of the Great Nile.

From the most ancient of times, Egypt has been one of the most important cradles of civilization, expansion, great empires, invincible armies, and advancement in science. The great pharaohs ruled among the Nile and marched into the North, West and South. The great general of Alexander, Ptolemy, remade this kingdom in a Hellenistic image and passed the torch to The Roman Empire, with stories we still remember two millennia into the future. With the rise of Islam, Egypt has been captured by Muslim armies and has been a strong bastion of power and a symbol of legitimacy for all those who ruled it. Even as the reign of this Ancient Land passed from one power to another, however, the land, the culture, and the people held the true power over whoever was sitting on the throne. Egypt has always been Egypt.

Standing at the crossroads from North Africa to the Levant, Cairo was the heart of Egypt, and when the Caliph Al-Muizz declared her as the Capital of the Caliphate, the region returned to her old glory.

Now, Salah ad-Din Yusuf ibn Ayyub, or Saladin, is in power - one of the greatest sultans of all and savior of the Holy Lands. He rules with might, justice, and wisdom, as well as a burning ambition to unite the Caliphate and retake the lands lost to the Crusaders. With an avenging army and a string of brilliant victories, Saladin stands at the top of the Islamic world, with his plan in motion to be the sacred commander who takes back Jerusalem, fulfilling the destiny Caliph Omar left behind.

Culture.name: Culture
Culture.text:
Culture

The Ayyubid Dynasty is in charge of Cairo. In recent years, Saladin seized control of the city and overthrew the Fatimid Dynasty. With Saladin’s rule, Cairo has become a luminous beacon of Islamic culture and learning, pulsing with the vigor of a great civilization. Under his wise and just rule, the city is flourishing as a center of scholarly pursuits and architectural wonders. The air is perfumed with the scent of papyrus and ink, hinting at the thriving scholarship within the walls of grand libraries, where scholars of every discipline gather, their debates and discoveries as lively as the bustling markets.

The streets of Cairo are alive with the hum of a city that is both a sanctuary for the arts and a stage for the everyday drama of its people. Saladin, known for his chivalry and tolerance, encourages an environment where different faiths and cultures coexist and learn from one another, blending their distinct hues into the city’s rich canvas.

In the heart of the city, the call to prayer mingles with the bells of Coptic churches, intertwining with the marketplace’s symphony of bartering voices, the clatter of artisans’ tools, and the sizzle of street food. These are the tastes of Cairo: a feast where sweet meets savory, and the abundance of the Nile nourishes a culinary tradition that is as varied as its people.

Celebrations in Saladin’s Cairo are jubilant and inclusive, featuring poetry recitals, musical performances, and public feasts that welcome all. Even in times of conflict, the city remains a haven where the pursuit of knowledge, the appreciation of the finer things, and the care for the community are paramount.

This is Cairo, a city with an indomitable spirit, a crossroads of commerce and culture, a crucible of historical legacies. Here, amidst the winding alleys and majestic minarets, Saladin’s vision for a prosperous and enlightened realm have taken root, creating a legacy that would echo through the ages.

Religious Strife

Cairo was under Shia rule during the reign of the Fatimid Dynasty. Many of the Shia gathered in Cairo as their seat of power after the schism that divided the Islamic world. However, the power shifted when Saladin seized control and declared allegiance to the Caliph in Baghdad, which resulted in a Sunni victory amidst the ongoing religious strife. This victory, however, would not be the end of Shia, as they established dynasties in the future.

The city hosts a large number of Muslims that follow the Shia sect and some of the locals are against the rule of Saladin due to the enmity of centuries. This schism is led by a local preacher named Bilal al-Shair, Bilal the Poet (Priest). He usually preaches against the Ayyubid Dynasty. Saladin himself ordered that he is to be left alone by the local law enforcement and wants every religion and creed to be free in his dominion. Bilal wants Cairo to be the seat of the Caliph who would adhere to the Shia teachings once again. Due to Saladin’s power and tolerance, he keeps a subtle tone and waits patiently for a mistake to be made by the Ayyubids. During Saladin’s absence due to war, he usually attempts to force Al-Adil to make a mistake by organizing large crowds.

The Duality of the People of Cairo

The main difference between the populations of the city is explained in the @UUID[JournalEntry.i02FgpKAFAt5qbM8]{Running a Story in the Holy Lands} section.

The people of Cairo fundamentally fall into two categories: those from a sedentary culture, and those from a nomadic one. Apart from the settled population of Cairo, there are many who live in the desert and embrace a life of migration. They are usually known as Bedouin, but there are many interesting cultures that can be found in and beyond the desert.

The nomadic lifestyle was a key cultural point in Arabic and Turkic history. After the spread of Islam, both Arabs and newly Islamized Turks transformed their way of living, embracing a sedentary lifestyle. However, there were many tribes, both Arabs and Turks and also native Africans, that preferred a style of living that was free and in line with nature, away from the urban areas, only stopping by for trade or warfare. It is through these people that Saladin, a legendary cavalry commander, recruits his most capable soldiers.

Turks hailing from Central Asia have started migrating westward in nomadic hordes. These people form the backbone of Saladin’s military campaigns - as well as a decent part of his bureaucracy, bringing with them the political and economic innovations of Persia and the Silk Road. The balance between nomadic culture and sedentism has always been important for the Turks in the past centuries, a state of affairs that the adoption of Islam has complicated. Their earlier religion, Tengrism, was born out of the nomadic lifestyle and was a useful belief system for people on the move. While some Turks maintain their nomadic way of life, some have been actively trying to embrace a more settled existence away from the barren landscape of the steppes. Settled life was not possible in Eurasian steppes, so they migrated to western lands and eventually came to Persia, the Caucasus, and Anatolia. As they adapted to a settled culture, they converted to Islam and, in time, established Great Sultanates. However, there are many Turkomans, Uyghurs, Kipchaks, Pechenegs, Khazars and many other tribes that still won’t leave their nomadic roots.

Nomadic culture was also important for Arabs and native Africans. Arab children were raised in the desert and taught its ways, which was believed to be healthier for the child for the first few years of his or her life. With the spread of Islam, Arabs changed, and the tribal view of the country evolved into the word “Ummah,” the unity. They built cities, adapted to the ways of the settled empires, and founded one for themselves, eventually reaching Egypt very quickly.

There are some important aspects to both cultures:

Nomadıc Culture

Settled Culture

Horses and camels are really important for individuals. They are needed in most scenarios: Traveling, settling in new places, migrating, running away from enemies, engaging in raids. The mounts give nomads freedom over the lands. Some families have two or three mounts for each person.

Sheep, goats, and similar herd animals may prove to be more central in people's lives than horses. Camels are, of course, used frequently, but it is unusual for a person to have more than one horse. They are not an essential part of one’s life.

Usually nomads are harshly trained to survive in the desert’s difficult conditions. They know how to survive in the wilds, under extreme weather.

They are usually not trained in the use of arms. They are recruited by their lords in times of need with minimal training. They know how to tend a farm, or work in other professions.

They usually live in tents that are easy to take down and erect. They take shelter in natural caverns and similar places.

They usually live in wooden or stone houses and if possible, behind strong walls.

Some Turkoman tribes still worship Tengri, but most of them are Muslims. Very few of them still follow the old pagan religions, usually in secret.

Most of them are usually Muslims or Eastern Christians. There are Jews and some Roman Catholics as well but a very minimal number.

Al-Madina - The City Center.name: Al-Madina - The City Center
Al-Madina - The City Center.text:
Al-Madina - The City Center

The scent of spice, fish, meat, flowers and many flavors greet you in the heart of the city. Right in front of the citadel, this place is filled with merchants, salespeople, workers, scholars, preachers, priests, imams, fedayeen, civilians, Mamluks, and others. A harmony of sounds, sometimes annoying, fills your ears as you hear many languages at once: Arabic, Turkish, Persian, Latin, Greek, and more.

The city’s center is the heart of Cairo and acts as the main marketplace, bazaar and an ideal place for commerce to flow. Many of the residents of southern cities, the desert, Alexandria and other parts of Egypt come here to take their place in the trade. Wool, livestock, wheat, cotton, fish, salt, iron… One can find anything he or she wants in the marketplace, even the most interesting factions and organizations.

Bab-i Felek (The Gate of Destiny)

Sometimes, at the city center, a few tents are organized with a small banner inscribed with a wheel. Inside the central tent is a young fortune-teller (check out the Appendix section for statblock) named Hediye Seher (Neutral Good). She asks for interesting payments for her sessions rather than coinage. She wants the payment beforehand; you can come up with specific and interesting requests tailored to particular party members; She is sincere about what she saw, although she warns everyone that she can only sense a possibility for a future, not a determined fate set in motion.

She believes that once she has enough of these payments, her power will be awakened: she will become a “true seer” and will be able to see how she can save the world.

Payment Suggestıons

“Bring me a flower that has set sail on at least two seas.”

2

3

4

“I want a bright feather, given voluntarily by a beautiful bird.”

5

6

“I want a map, no longer showing the truth.”

Shahbal-i Melek

Shahbal is a name given to the longest feather in a bird’s wing. Melek is the creature known as an angel in Western cultures. Shahbal-i Melek is a thieves’ organization founded by the locals before the days of Saladin. Their leader Daman (@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.13K3XK2A3wwxVKLD]{Spy}j, LN) is a tiefling in disguise, and Shahbal-i Melek has roots in the vast desert and in underground caverns. They represent the non-human population of Egypt and usually act in accordance with the local Mamluk forces and one of the commanders, Nadim-lenk (see below). Nadim usually confiscates illegal goods and supplies and delivers them to Shahbal-i Melek.

The Citadel.name: The Citadel
The Citadel.text:
The Citadel

High towers strike a cunning beauty to the beholder, a message to all enemies and friends alike: Authority. The citadel and its walls represent the vast might in the hands of one of the greatest generals and sultans in Islamic culture. The copper color is in unity with the sun and the walls hail it with all the power held by Saladin. They seem impregnable and ward off all enemies of Saladin.

The Citadel is where Saladin lives and rules his sultanate. In his absence, his brother Al-Adil Saphadin (The @UUID[Actor.0ast70TWeCYniW4V]{Commander Emir}, Noble of Levant statblock, Lawful Neutral, INT 16) rules in his stead. Al-Adil’s name means “the Just One,” and he lives up to the reputation. While Al-Adil rules Cairo, Saladin’s son and heir, Al-Afdal b. Salah ad-Din, currently serves as the Emir of Damascus. He resides there with his grandmother Ismat ad-Din Khatun, who considers Damascus as her homeland.

Al-Adil is known as “Sayf ad-Din,” Saphadin to the Crusaders - meaning the Sword of Faith. He is an effective minister of war and has shown great administrative skills as one of the most reliable councilors and generals under the disposal of Saladin. The sultan only trusts Al-Adil to defend Egypt while he assembles his army for the final confrontation at Jerusalem. Al-Adil also secures the flow of supplies and men to Saladin’s campaigns, playing a key role.

The citadel is filled with special 100 Mamluk soldiers known as the “Sayf al-Jannah,” the Swords of Heaven. These specially trained soldiers receive their training in the desert under their infamous commander: Kalender Zaim (Mamluk Ghazi). Originally a man of African descent and a stern warrior, Kalender takes new recruits to the desert and sometimes only returns with but one-tenth of the recruits. Once a recruit survives, they are then introduced to the sultan with these words from Kalender: “They now have beards.”

The citadel is usually off-limits for anyone besides the royal family, the Mamluks, and those invited by the high-ranking members of the court. Al-Adil hosts guests in the main courtyard, in a lovely and open-roof building surrounded by flowers and delicious aroma.

Fatimid Palace & Law Enforcement.name: Fatimid Palace & Law Enforcement
Fatimid Palace & Law Enforcement.text:
The Old Fatimid Palace has two parts: Old Western Palace and Old Eastern Palace.

Fatimid walls surround the main living area of Cairo and many important buildings and houses can be found here.

Old Western Palace - The Pearl Palace

The Pearl Palace works as the core of dungeons and legislative business conducted in all of Cairo. The beautiful palace turned into a place for civil lawsuits, and similar businesses where qualified administrators, judges, and other civilian officers conduct their business.

The main official in the Pearl Palace is a just man known as “Tenzede Terazu” which can be translated as “The Silent Scales.” His real name is Abd-al-Hak Suleiman (@UUID[Actor.OksiTzyq7R5pinZR]{Warrior Priest of Levant}; can cast zone of truth once a day without expending a spell slot). Suleiman is known for his absolute sense of justice and even the richest and most powerful man in the land respects his justice. He even has the right to convict the sultan if he deems it necessary. Many times Saladin talked about him as: “If he would deem that I would be sentenced to death today, I will go into the gallows without hesitation; my heart will be sure that he is correct.”

Suleiman has two servants that he freed years ago: a woman named Vera Nalan (@UUID[Actor.nW8Aj5aNHyswBvNs]{Traveling Artist}) and a young boy named Tariq Halis (@UUID[Actor.XiG03vgMTRXPTmh9]{Wilderness Commoner}), both of whom have expertise in Insight and Perception checks and usually listen to the hearings and report any signs of lie, deception, and similar situations. They also can be used to investigate some cases with the local Mamluks.

Old Eastern Palace

The clamorous sound of clashing metal and the tension of drawn bows resonate through the skies, creating a symphony of training Mamluks-to-be. Under the eternal blue sky, men’s voices echo, a chorus of determination and strength. They are engaged in rigorous training, day and night, honing their skills and fortitude. Each strike of the sword and release of an arrow is a testament to their tireless pursuit of mastery in combat. The atmosphere is charged with intensity and the relentless spirit of warriors preparing for battle, their shouts merging with the metallic symphony, crafting an ambiance of unyielding resilience and martial prowess.

The Old Eastern Palace has been transformed into the center of the city guard and their training. The chambers have been reorganized into living, training, and administrating quarters for Mamluk soldiers and their training. It is commanded by Ziya Babur, the commander of all Mamluk forces in Cairo and one of Saladin’s most trusted warriors, who is entrusted with the defense of his throne.

Commander of the Mamluks: Ziya Babur (@UUID[Actor.zT88dyVK2LfpMcWF]{Mamluk Ghazi}, LN)

Ziya Babur is a distinguished Mamluk officer, renowned for his leadership as the head of law enforcement in Cairo, and a resident at the Old Eastern Palace. With a commanding presence and a keen eye for detail, Ziya stands out not only for his tactical acumen but also for his genial nature. His early life was marked by a natural affinity for strategy and an unwavering sense of justice, traits that guided him on his path to becoming a revered figure in law enforcement.

From a young age, Ziya displayed a sharp mind at the local mosque and a charismatic personality among the young population of his village, endearing him to both peers and elders. His journey to prominence began when he was noticed by a Mamluk recruiter during a local event: a cruel officer forcibly wanted to take some children to be trained but Ziya stood in his way and volunteered to be taken instead of his other friends. The cruel officer wanted to make him pay due to his fierce personality, and when Ziya turned back, he swung an attack. Ziya, although not able to see, responded to the attack quickly and proved his tendency to fight. In terms of mechanics, he has the ability to sense his surroundings: blindsight (15 ft.).

Ziya’s tenure is characterized by his innovative approaches to maintaining order and solving crimes. He has a reputation for being fair but firm, earning him the respect and loyalty of his subordinates and the community. Known for his ability to defuse tense situations with humor and wisdom, Ziya has become a beloved figure in Cairo. His leadership style, marked by empathy and efficiency, has led to significant improvements in the city’s safety and orderliness.

Beyond his duties, Ziya is known for his love of Cairo’s rich culture and history. He often engages with the local populace, sharing stories and participating in community events, which further solidifies his status as a personable and approachable leader. His life is a testament to the balance between authority and humanity, making Ziya Babur an admired and enjoyable character in the fabric of Cairo’s society.

Ziya Babur has hundreds of warriors at his disposal and usually has full responsibility for addressing internal crimes and possible problems in the city. He has two subordinates, two @UUID[Actor.xgNOVmJC7PrjTZ7l]{Mamluk Cavalries} named Nadim-lenk Halis (Neutral Good) and Zayd b. Khalid (Lawful Neutral).

Nadim-lenk Halis is an elderly man and a war veteran. He was retired to “desk duty” when he suffered an injury from an arrow. A Hashashin’s poisoned arrow in Syria pierced his leg and left him crippled, earning him the epithet “-lenk,” which means limping. He usually protects the weak against the powerful and usually has enemies among local emirs and nobles. He looks past small crimes especially by the poor folk and is harsh about the tax-evaders.

Zayd is younger than Nadim and a strict officer in his duties. He does not look past crimes and believes in a just punishment system, even how harsh that may be. Zayd, although feared by the locals, has their respect due to not taking sides and being just in delivering punishments. Some folktales about him say that he even stood up to Saladin when he believed he was overlooking a crime. He has a loyal cavalry unit called Barq-Fursan (all twenty members use the @UUID[Actor.FJUpeOJhezl3A3Un]{Mamluk Veteran} statblock), roughly translated to Thunder-knights. Fursan is the name for the historical cavalry unit commanded by the legendary commander Khalid b. Walid.

Al-Azhar University.name: Al-Azhar University
Al-Azhar University.text:
As you approach, whispers of intellectual discourse float in the air, mingling with the scent of ink and parchment. Quills and vials of ink are scattered liberally, a testament to the fervor of learning in Cairo. The gardens teem with eager students, their voices a melodious blend of debate and laughter. Scholars, masters in their crafts, hold court beneath the whispering trees, their words weaving through the cool breeze. The essence of Cairo, a city steeped in peace, prosperity, and a hunger for knowledge, permeates everything.

There, bathed in sunlight, stands the Al-Azhar Mosque, its presence a beacon of enlightenment. In this sacred space, under Saladin’s benevolent gaze, education thrives, generously funded by the royal coffers. You notice a subtle diversity in the attire of the students. Here, beneath the towering minarets, all are united in their quest for knowledge. Status is transient, and only the currency of intellect and scientific achievement holds any true value in this bastion of equality and wisdom.

One of the oldest universities in Egypt, Al-Azhar Mosque was founded for both religious and scientific research. Throughout time, it evolved into a full-fledged university that could dwarf the House of Wisdom in favor of the Fatimid Caliphate, pushing the Shia Fatimids ahead of their rival, the Sunni Abbasids in Baghdad.

Al-Azhar University prospered in scientific pursuit. When Saladin came to power, the Society of Banu Musa (explained below) followed him here and established a seat in Cairo under the leadership of Al-Jazari (further information on Al-Jazari can be found in The Sigil of Jerusalem’s Characters section) and conducted significant research on robotics and engineering.

In ordinary times, the university’s headmaster is Ismail Al-Jazari, the legendary father of robotics and a genius engineer. Despite his young age, his brilliant mind proved itself worthy at short notice. However, in the storyline of The Sigil of Jerusalem, Ismail Al-Jazari is away from Cairo, as explained in Act II: We Become What We Behold.

In his absence, a Mage named Sitara al-Defne (LG) (meaning Daphne of the Stars) is the acting headmistress. She is a tall woman in her early twenties with brown hair and tan and large eyes. Her affinity for magic has marked her with spell rebound - as parts of her limbs are in an unstoppable, arcane decay. However, even the curse of spell rebound hasn’t stopped her from pushing forward in her craft, as she is an incredible magician and expert in arcane creatures that do not originate in this plane of existence. She can cast the banishment, magic circle and hold monster spells without expending a spell slot 3 times a day (each), and she has advantage on Constitution saving throws. Sitara, much like Al-Jazari, is young but far more serious, devoted, and work-oriented. She usually spends time digging through arcane archives for knowledge on monsters, trying to figure out how to best fight them and immobilize them. She sees the world as a dangerous place and is constantly looking for ways to make it safer for those affected by spell rebound.

Membership and Education

In order to be a member or a student at the university, one candidate must bring forth a combination of these:

  • A letter of recommendation from a member or a renowned scholar.
  • Proof of scholarly pursuits, arcane interests, literary talents or artistic virtues.
  • Fluency in at least three languages: Arabic, Persian, Ancient Greek, Classic Latin or a Mesopotamian language.
  • Undergoing a test or a quest given by the teachers.
  • A humble donation (~250 gd).
  • A humble donation in the form of a scholarly text, artifact or a similar important item.

Non-members are not allowed in inner chambers and can’t borrow books from libraries. Members have access to inner chambers and some of the secrets depending on how far they are accepted and if they are able to borrow books. However, the rules on borrowing books are very strict and usually failing to bring the book back for more than a month could result in the death penalty.

There are interesting rules in the library that may seem odd at first: for instance, you can’t bring any form of fire to the library. It was the custom of the House of Wisdom, where they used fireflies inside lamps to see and read at night. Al-Azhar University rejected this solution and with a subtle touch of magic and engineering managed to light up every possible corner of the building.The walls are filled with small holes that are protected by glass. Inside the holes there are lamps that light the way. They are mechanically connected to the Headmaster’s Office, and when the sun starts to set, the lights follow.

Inside arcane chambers, harmless flames produced from the continual flame spell or other methods of magical lighting are also in use.

For being a “talebe (the one who demands)”, a student, there is no age limit, but a monthly fee (5 gd) is required. With the Ayyubid Dynasty’s rise to power, there are many students who can attend freely, as long as they keep up with classes, chores, and given quests.

Library

Anyone who wants to conduct research here by spending at least 4 hours must succeed on a DC 12 Intelligence (Investigation) check. If they receive help from veteran scholars or other teachers during the research, or it is a group effort to find related books, it is rolled with advantage. Consult the table below to see the different availability of books on certain subjects. The DCs may be adjusted depending on the availability.

There may be other topics that are not covered in the table but fit the game you want to play. The Al-Azhar University can be considered a center for players with scholarly tendencies to freely conduct their research on a topic of their desire. For rarer topics, scholars from arcane chambers may be of more help.

The library’s master is Mina el-Katip (Magej), a woman of Turkish descent. She is young and despite her age, she can read and understand 20 languages and has a flawless memory – she automatically succeeds in Intelligence (History) checks about remembering something that has happened to her, that she saw or heard. She is a chatty and easy-going person unless there’s a threat to a written document, then she unleashes a fury that could rival that of a hellhound.

When she was young, she was captured by Byzantine troops but saved by a Turkoman raiding party and fell in love with one of her saviors’ sons. She was granted freedom and married the son at a young age. Her intelligence didn’t go unnoticed, and she traveled to Egypt with her husband for further scholarly education. They attempted to go to Baghdad, to the legendary House of Wisdom, but the ongoing war at the borders between the Seljuks and Ayyubids made the already difficult journey insurmountable. During their journey, her husband fell ill and eventually died. Mina still has suitors but refuses them all; she does not want to marry again.

If the adventurers ever get in her favor by providing new materials to the library and acting carefully around written texts, books and documents, Mina may provide help in searching the library or other arcane businesses.

Those Who Recite: Muzahir

The title “Hafiz” is important for Islamic culture. It is a title given to those who can recite the holy texts perfectly, from memory. In the University, there are a significant number of people who carry the title Hafız. Inspired by the concept of Hafız, the Society of Banu Musa’s first leaders developed a construct that can hold and transfer information via reading or speaking. They look like mechanical parrots and pigeons, and for the uninitiated eyes, they truly seem like mere birds. These mechanical avians are called Muzahirs and have many uses: they can send messages, record information, or read written text. They have their own very limited intelligence, but they are built in a magical way to prevent them from harming other sentient creatures. Sons of Musa didn’t want these creations to be used as a means of destruction or killing. It was not in their desire to build an assassin or a warrior construct.
