These creatures can be found among the chambers that are only available to the members and they are commanded to help the members with all information they have in their memories. In addition, if one shares information with the Muzahir, he or she could earn the respect and favors of the university.

Chamber of Ruh-u Tevhid (Oneness of the Soul)

In the Chambers of “Oneness of the Soul,” the main teachings are about philosophy, religion, and Tasawwuf (Sufism). Its headmaster is Ekrem Imaro (@UUID[Actor.EcikReeMMNMXkAUy]{Scholar of Cairo}, in addition to 18 DEX and a 3rd-level Monk & Way of the Pilgrim abilities, 16 AC), and he is of Sudanese origin. He traveled to many places in the world to search for enlightenment, and he is well-versed in many religions of the world and a very open-minded person. He decided to stay in Cairo due to an injury he received while helping a distressed wild animal. He especially enjoys long conversations about life, the journey, and the beyond. He rarely takes offense; children’s or innocents’ lives must be in danger for him to resort to violence.

In these chambers, if players actively contribute to the conservation (DC 15 Intelligence or Charisma check, proper proficiencies like Religion may apply) they will be inspired. This inspiration will let them add +2 bonus to ability checks in the next 24 hours.

Chamber of Mucize-i Beden

In the Chambers of “Miracles of the Body,” a physician named Laila Yasmin (@UUID[Actor.EcikReeMMNMXkAUy]{Scholar of Cairo}, INT 19, with expertise in Medicine) discovers and lectures about the human body. Due to a genetic affinity to blood magic originating from a minor spell rebound at her birth, she is able to sense the flow of blood and the location of pain (she senses blood within 60 ft. of her; due to this talent, she can’t be surprised by creatures that have blood in their bodies). This ability helps her research and physicianship. She is a very curious and observant person, usually pointing out possible illnesses in people and advising ways to cure them. She’s married to another physician called Najm (Scholar of Cairo), who is an expert in crafting remedial concoctions. They were born and raised in Syria but followed Saladin into Cairo and chose to stay here. While a horrendous arsenal of blood magic and sanguinary hexes lies before Laila, she vowed never even to study let alone use them; and only use her unhoned powers for healing.

In these chambers, adventurers can also find frost-covered rooms to preserve dead bodies and conduct research on cadavers. The university pays good money (10 gd) for fresh corpses, but it refrains from purchasing those that died under less than legal circumstances. Storing dead bodies and not letting them rest under the soil is usually a topic of speculation and legends in the city. Most of the devout religious folk despise the act and defend that it is disrespectful to the dead.

Players can travel here in cases of injury or sickness. If one is brought here unconscious and stable, they will wake up with half of their maximum hit points 1 hour after the examination and tending.

Chamber of Asm-i Alâ

The Chamber of “Exalted Sky” is led by two women: Fatma al-Fihri and Razia ad-Din Ahra Nazar (both use the @UUID[Actor.EcikReeMMNMXkAUy]{Scholar of Cairo} statblock). They craft lenses and similar objects to sharpen their skill in astronomy further. Razia ad-Din is also famous for curing illnesses that affect the eye and helps out the Chamber of Mucize-i Beden staff. She even invented wearable lenses that could be used by the poor-sighted.

Chamber of Ulum al-Khafiya

Most of the students are not aware that the higher floors of the mosque also host another division: the Chamber of “Hidden Knowledge.” This chamber is led by Avni Burhan (@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.mQnsXanewsPiV7QE]{Mage}) and his subordinates. There, research about magical secrets, limits of wizardry and other aspects of the magical world are researched, the main topic being the spell rebound. The acting headmistress spends most of her time in the Ulum al-Khafiya and is the former head of this Chamber.

Avni Burhan is an elderly, curious, and silent man who tends to be lost in the books he reads. His title is “Dud-ul Kuttab,” which directly translates to bookworm. His primary research is about spell rebound, and he constantly conducts experiments on subjects suffering from the many side effects of the spell rebound. Due to his daily proximity to those burdened with the vengeance of reality, his body is affected by spell rebound as if he were an archmage. His body is filled with surgical scars from his many trials in removing the “organic tissue cursed by reality.” To hide these scars, he wears layer after layer of fabric - truly looking like a worm wielding books.

If the adventurers bring interesting items or spell scrolls and donate to this Chamber, Avni Burhan will reward them with a “potion of anti-spell rift.” When drunk, it gives advantage on saving throws related to spell rebound effects. Avni Burhan has ten of these potions and states that it takes “a long time” to produce one. He gives two of them freely, as he wishes to see how his concoctions work out of the confines of his laboratory. However, the rest requires donations or can be bought for 150 gd. This potion can not be produced with item-creating spells, item-creating class features, or similar methods, and its effects can not be duplicated by any spell. Even Avni Burhan is not sure how he can produce the potions, and he is reluctant to share the methods, as they could be dangerous and deadly.

Society of Banu Musa

Saghani al-Asturlabi (@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.mQnsXanewsPiV7QE]{Mage}j) and Ibrahim al-Yattara (@UUID[Actor.EcikReeMMNMXkAUy]{Scholar of Cairo}) are the spearheads of the society in the absence of Ismail Al-Jazari. Saghani is an elderly man with vast experience in astronomy, robotics and engineering. He is known as an astrolabe maker, but nowadays he deals with the topics of heat and cold and survival in the desert, as well as taking an interest in making the desert more habitable with the right intervention.

Ibrahim al-Yattara is of Ethiopian descent and a very enthusiastic and joyful scholar, especially taking an interest in building constructs that could help the mundane tasks of the world. He also designed a group of athletic and fast constructs that could play with children, especially in the streets and the games that contain a ball.

If the adventurers donate a sufficient amount of rare materials (such as gold, jewelry, meteorites, gemstones or similar), they could gain the favor of the society.

The society sells interesting items that can replicate some of the spells that could come in handy in adventuring, traveling, or similar aspects of life.

Banu Musa’s Useful Companion (100 gd): While holding this clock-like device, you have 5 charges to spend. When a charge is expended as an action, it can duplicate these cantrips: Al-Biruni’s fantastic quill, Al-Farghani’s alchemy, Al-Jazari’s metalsmith, Al-Jazari’s woodwork and Bedouin fabrics. When its charges are over, they are replenished at dawn.

Vigilant Companion (250 gd): This is a tiny clockwork construct that resembles a small pigeon that has the ability to keep watch while you rest in the wilderness or even at an inn or tavern. You command it a distance, and the construct warns you immediately when a living or undead creature enters the given area. If you pay another 100 gd, it comes with an attachment stone that lets you cast the alarm spell once a day without expending a spell slot. This stone’s ability recharges at dawn.

The Disk of Wonders (250 gd): This metal tray-like construct is circular in shape and no one would question it if one called it a tray to bring to coffee. However, when the command word is spoken, it becomes a floating disk (3 feet in diameter and 1 inch thick, that floats 3 feet above the ground) and follows the rules in the spell; its duration becomes 5 hours and can be cast 3 times per day. Its ability is recharged at dawn.

Ibn Tulun Mosque.name: Ibn Tulun Mosque
Ibn Tulun Mosque.text:
The Mosque of Ibn Tulun was built alongside the long-gone Palace of Al-Qata’i before the palace was ravaged. There were hidden tunnels underneath the buildings, used by Ahmad Ibn Tulun to join the prayers in secrecy. The imam of the mosque, Amir Nazim, and his muezzin assistant Manshour Musharraf know about these tunnels and make use of the resources left from the old days.

Imam Amir Nazim (@UUID[Actor.OksiTzyq7R5pinZR]{Warrior Priest of Levant}) is a man cursed with terrible nightmares. One day, while walking around the town sleep-deprived, he felt relieved and realized that the mosque was calming him, inviting him in. He started to pray instead of sleep, understanding the mosque was resting his mind, and within a few years, he took on the role of the imam of the place. Players resting or praying here benefit from the effects of the lesser restoration spell or reduce their exhaustion level by one.

Imam Nazim doesn’t feel at ease knowing that his problem has gone away without him doing something to fix it, so he starts looking for ways to redeem himself of his past sins. He patrols at night for devious creatures that might harm people. After getting injured multiple times, Mansour Musharraf (@UUID[Actor.UoXXok5SHNGW7elg]{Pilgrim}) starts suspecting that the old man will not survive without help and offers to join him. Muezzin Mansur scouts from on top of the minaret at night, informing Nazim in case of any danger, with a bird whistle. Together they explored the hidden tunnels underneath the mosque and found an old weapon forge belonging to the Old Palace of Al-Qata’i. If players improve their relationship with Imam Nazim and Muezzin Mansur, they can sharpen and gain a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls for their weapons within the forge. This effect lasts for 24 hours.

One of the preachers of the place is a @UUID[Actor.kDX72EozbFjhaiYT]{Local Priest} known as Aaron the Barbarossa (NG). He is actually one of the former Knights Templar and a brother to one of the most prominent knights: Walter du Mesnil. He converted to Islam years ago and settled in Cairo. He has a peaceful and patient personality and is a follower of the Sufi faith. He preaches about the oneness of the universe, the soul and the body, and advises to treat everyone with respect. His main advice is “to be curious, not judgmental.” He teaches kids mostly and wants them “to be the best of themselves.” He constantly talks about belief and its importance in life. He advises anyone, whether Muslim, Christian, or Jewish, or a non-believer, one must always believe, no matter what, and it starts with believing in oneself.

Hanging Church.name: Hanging Church
Hanging Church.text:
Hanging Church rises in place of what once was the south walls of an old Roman citadel. While the citadel is no more, the old church has been restored by the orders of, first Harun al-Rashid and then later Pope Abraham. Travelers from outside call it the Staircase Church because of its elevation above the ground and the long flight of stairs required to reach it. It is devoted to the Virgin Mary and is one of the first churches in Egypt.

The Hanging Church embraces those who are left alone. Most religious minorities are dependent on this church in a culture in which they are not adopted. They come here to keep their beliefs alive among others and receive forgiveness by confessing their sins. In addition to addressing religious needs, people come here to get various aids. If you are well versed in arcane lore, you may recognize one of the midwives casting spare the dying spell to stabilize the condition of newborn babies during birth and several nuns preventing the decay of bodies before burial by gentle repose. Players may be informed of these services by a Coptic priest named David (Local Priest) in case of an emergency.

House of Virgin Mary.name: House of Virgin Mary
House of Virgin Mary.text: The House of Virgin Mary is a shelter and a place to eat for those in need. It is built for this purpose and regularly hosts feasts, particularly on significant religious days. While the workers are pious helpful folks, the patron and benefactor of the place, Muhsin Abner (@UUID[Actor.0fq4S96P36D6XPNZ]{Crusader Noble}), is also funding the Hanging Church. His trustworthy servant Daniel (@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.PVD5wRdyO7iCJPs1]{Priest}j), a half-elf, who preaches both in the church and the house, often comes to these feasts and secretly casts create food and water to provide the food. Players resting here benefit from an additional 1d4 healing on a short rest.

Harun Madrasa.name: Harun Madrasa
Harun Madrasa.text:
Harun Madrasa is a grand building, built with the purpose of educating those who wish to learn how to read and write. It is dedicated to Harun al-Rashid, a legendary Caliph of the Abbasid Dynasty. The madrasa was rebuilt by the order of Saladin after it was destroyed by the Fatimid Caliphate. It is a well-received establishment among the people, with many scholars teaching words of old to local folk alongside basic education.

One of the scholars, Zehra El-Kelam (@UUID[Actor.EcikReeMMNMXkAUy]{Scholar of Cairo}), is there to greet newcomers and teach those who don’t know how to read and write. She is a peaceful character who doesn’t believe in folktales. Imam Samir (@UUID[Actor.kDX72EozbFjhaiYT]{Local Priest}), however, is a strong believer in those tales and encourages people to go to the Madrasa, saying that there is a chance that they might see Harun al-Rashid’s spirit among them and be blessed. Players visiting the Madrasa are under the effects of comprehend languages spell as long as they are inside. If players attend a lesson, they witness students believing the spirit of Harun al-Rashid is among them due to a breeze moving curtains and candlelights. Player characters are inspired by the scene and gain advantage on their next Wisdom check.

Garden of Serenity

The Garden of Serenity is a place to shelter from the heat of the summer sun. Often visited by the students of Harun Madrasa, these tall trees rise in the middle of the city, creating a cool moment for passers to stop by. The fruit vendor Farid (@UUID[Actor.ZNy2IXH6DjXJsE9k]{Traveling Merchant}), who is well-known among locals for his delicious grapes, parks his cart in the shades of this garden. Grapes bought from his inventory bear the effects of goodberry spell, and 10 pieces of them cost 5 silver dirhams.

The Pyramids of Giza & The Great Sphinx.name: The Pyramids of Giza & The Great Sphinx
The Pyramids of Giza & The Great Sphinx.text: The Pyramids of Giza and the Great Sphinx are detailed in the Sigil of Jerusalem, Act II: We Become What We Behold.

Bayt al-Hiwar - The House of Chatter.name: Bayt al-Hiwar - The House of Chatter
Bayt al-Hiwar - The House of Chatter.text:
The House of Chatter thrives with an unceasing vitality, its interior consistently bustling to the point where observers might question whether the patrons are devoid of other obligations throughout the day. Every table is claimed by animated customers engaged in spirited conversations spanning the gamut from global affairs to familial anecdotes. Amidst the joviality, nuggets of wisdom about horse grooming are generously exchanged, hookahs are indulged in, and hearty laughter reverberates through the air. Within these walls, the burdens of daily existence assume the role of mere conversational fodder, momentarily sidelined as individuals converge to socialize and unwind.

However, one element stands apart – a mysterious door discreetly positioned at the rear of the venue. Its presence appears incongruous, defying expectations that the building’s dimensions mirror the expansiveness of the establishment itself. Strangely, this portal appears to eschew a connection to the world outside, its formidable bolted frame suggesting a deliberate effort to ward off something unseen.

The House of Chatter is an immensely popular coffee house located on one of Cairo’s busiest streets. Due to its limited space, the coffee house is always bustling with customers. Typically, men spend their leisure time here, engaging in discussions about politics, playing games, and enjoying the company of friends.

The history of the House of Chatter dates back further than the memories of most Cairo residents. It has been handed down through generations within the same family, and selling it to outsiders is strictly forbidden. The family managing the establishment guards a deep-seated secret that they never share with anyone outside their kin.

Originally, the House of Chatter was part of a much larger building that the first owner stumbled upon, abandoned and mysterious. Unfamiliar carvings adorned the walls, written in an incomprehensible language (DC 15 Intelligence check reveals that these scrawlings are indeed gibberish. Random letters and signs have been borrowed from different cultures). One particular section of the building contained a hallway with six enigmatic doors, impervious to all attempts at opening them. Despite trying everything in his power, the first owner could not unlock these doors, even with the assistance of his friends.

On one occasion, he convinced his friends to help force open the doors so they could utilize the space for living while continuing the coffee house business at the front. Their efforts were in vain, and they left the coffee house disappointed. The following morning, the first owner discovered the remnants of their presence: leftover food scattered in the hallway. His friends had vanished without a trace, never to be seen again.

After this strange incident, the first owner decided to abandon any attempts at unlocking the mysterious doors. Some years later, when his son took over the business, the locked hallway became a target for squatters, the homeless seeking refuge. Despite being locked, they managed to find a way in, only leaving behind a haunting scene of blood and torn clothes.

They demolished the section containing these six rooms. From the exterior, the building appeared significantly smaller, accommodating only one spacious salon, a kitchen, and a toilet. However, upon entering through the old door, it revealed that the hidden hallway that had been kept a secret for generations was still there waiting for its next prey.

In truth, the floor tilings in the hidden chamber were a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.hx240PG5r5qpRet3]{mimic}.

Adnan (@UUID[Actor.1JK80RxGJvsa6UG4]{Artisan}, CN): Adnan’s family has been residing in Cairo for generations, establishing themselves as a prominent presence within their community due to their successful business venture, the House of Chatter. Adnan is frequently sought after for his guidance and advice. His imposing and commanding demeanor often compels individuals to be forthright in their interactions with him. Despite his formidable presence, he is renowned for his kindness and altruistic nature. However, he harbors a clandestine enterprise.

Upon inheriting the coffeehouse and uncovering the secret of the concealed passageway, Adnan’s mind conceived a unique notion – the passageway was the perfect instrument for committing a crime, an opportunity for an untraceable demise. Importantly, the individuals responsible wouldn’t need to carry out the act themselves. Functioning akin to a professional hitman, Adnan assists clients in maneuvering their adversaries into the concealed hallway, a service for which he charges a substantial fee. This process effectively eliminates all evidence.

Behind the seemingly innocuous façade of a locked hallway, appearing to be nothing more than a bolted rear entrance, lies an ingenious scheme – the ultimate crime, executed flawlessly.

Dhabab Kauket - Kauket’s Haze.name: Dhabab Kauket -  Kauket’s Haze
Dhabab Kauket - Kauket’s Haze.text:
You stand before an abandoned edifice that appears untouched by human presence for years. However, appearances are deceptive, for within these forsaken walls lies one of Cairo’s most bustling and enigmatic establishments. Alongside fellow seekers, some cloaked in capes and others masked to protect their identities, you approach the stairs leading down to the heart of this captivating venue. The distant echo of music filters through the door, now guarded by two imposing men. A couple ahead of you, hailing from a notable family, are questioned briefly before being granted passage without further inquiry. Entering this establishment requires little effort, but patrons must demonstrate their capacity to afford the experience and conduct themselves discreetly, as the majority of visitors belong to influential families.

Crossing the threshold, you find yourself in the dimly lit tavern, where a kaleidoscope of candlelight casts vibrant hues throughout the expansive hall. The sight is more extensive than anticipated, teeming with elegantly attired individuals. Every inch exudes an ancient Egyptian motif, from the adorned walls to the themed tables and waitstaff. The renowned belly dancers, enchanting and captivating, perform amidst the merriment. Guests are engrossed in delight, as a melodious female voice fills the air with enchanting songs, and dancers engage in rhythmic entertainment.

As you observe, some guests are drawn to the exclusive fare, indulging in delicacies not commonly found elsewhere. The mingling aromas create a heady, enticing ambiance. Conversations intermingle, forging an atmosphere of enjoyment and camaraderie. Here, business concerns are left far behind, and everyone revels in the moment.

Kauket’s Haze is a clandestine tavern nestled in Cairo, shrouded in secrecy, intrigue, and opulence. In bygone times, this establishment was once a humble temple, but the sands of time left it abandoned and forgotten. Now, under new ownership, it has been transformed into a captivating tavern.

Though well-known to locals, few dare to admit having set foot in this enigmatic place. Conversations about its existence are hushed, and those who recognize familiar faces within its walls maintain utmost discretion. The tavern is renowned for its mesmerizing belly dancers, each gracefully attired as ancient Egyptian deities, enabling patrons to immerse themselves in a realm of whimsical fantasy.

To gain access to this extraordinary venue, one must venture through the desolate floors of the temple, seemingly untouched for years. Descending a foreboding staircase, visitors are met by imposing bodyguards. DC12 Intelligence (Arcana or Investigation) Check reveals that the bodyguards are of Half-Orcish descent. Only those deemed presentable and affluent enough are granted passage.

Within these concealed confines, many Egyptians find solace in enjoying alcoholic beverages, a liberty often denied by religious beliefs. This is a place where they can momentarily cast aside social restrictions and surrender to indulgence. The tavern boasts an eclectic array of delicacies from around the world, featuring delectable dishes ranging from succulent beef to pork. Yet, in Kauket’s Haze, discretion is paramount, and what transpires behind the veiled curtains remains a closely guarded secret.

Zaria (Traveling Artist, CN): Zaria, an exquisite woman now in her late forties, stands as the proprietress of Kauket’s Haze. Her earlier years were colored by a life marked by its complexities, initially finding herself engaged in a profession of entertainment for an elite clientele. However, her enchanting allure set her apart, rendering her one of the most coveted confidants across Cairo. A multitude of influential men were drawn to her, either desiring an evening in her company or simply seeking her companionship. This attention from the powerful elite translated into substantial earnings.

Inhabiting a sphere where connections thrived, Zaria counted among her acquaintances an array of influential individuals, her services commanding a premium. Her wealth multiplied at a rapid pace, facilitated by her network of associations. Leveraging these resources, she founded Kauket’s Haze, an establishment that would signal the culmination of her past endeavors and pave the way for a new chapter in her life.

In this new role, Zaria not only succeeded in embracing retirement but also extended a lifeline to other women who sought liberation from similar circumstances. The heart of Kauket’s Haze, a haven she created, offers refuge to those aspiring to break free from their former lives. The establishment employs them as handsomely paid dancers and waitresses, providing them with an avenue to transition away from their previous employers.

Nazrat Ra - Gaze of Ra.name: Nazrat Ra - Gaze of Ra
Nazrat Ra - Gaze of Ra.text:
The Gaze of Ra is an enigmatic place that challenges one’s perception and understanding. Upon entering, the complexity of the interior becomes apparent. The doors open up to a spacious lounge, with a counter at the back, behind which is a seemingly empty small door. However, the lounge itself appears to be teeming with a crowd of people engaged in various activities – dining, conversing, and enjoying themselves. Curiously, though, as you scan the room, you notice a peculiar repetition of tables and patrons, as if you have seen the same scene multiple times.

Upon closer examination, you realize that the illusion is created by numerous mirrors placed throughout the lounge, reflecting each other and generating an illusion of a larger and more crowded space. Moreover, columns scattered across the room add to the maze-like atmosphere, further complicating navigation and decision-making due to the confusing arrangement of mirrors and walls.

As you stand there, a man emerges from the small door behind the counter. His eyes are obscured by a black cloth tied around them, yet he greets you warmly and seems to look directly at you. He offers his assistance, guiding you to the appropriate room. Following him upstairs, you encounter a winding hallway that appears to stretch indefinitely, taking unexpected turns and angles that defy comprehension. Countless rooms branch off from the hallway, creating an intricate network that could easily confuse even a sober individual, let alone someone under the influence.

Gaze of Ra is an immensely popular spot in Cairo, renowned for its vast and intricate structure resembling a maze. The supporting walls, perplexing hallways, and overall design make it quite challenging for ordinary visitors to navigate. If unaccompanied by the owner, the party must pass a DC 15 Wisdom (Survival) check to not accidentally bump into a patron of the establishment and make a mess.

The inn’s unique allure lies in its blind owner’s extraordinary ability to traverse the labyrinthine premises effortlessly. This phenomenon fascinates many, prompting some to stay just to witness his seamless movements. Remarkably, he navigates the tables and pathways with an uncanny precision, defying any expectations of mishaps, as if possessing superior vision compared to everyone else in the room.

The inn features a single type of cozy room, accommodating two to three people each, ensuring a comfortable stay for its guests. Additionally, there are prayer rooms within the establishment, catering to those who may not have time to visit a mosque for their prayers. Surprisingly, the inn operates without any helpers or waiters, with the owner being the sole presence tending to the guests’ needs.

Curiously, there is a small door located at the back of the counter, but access to this area is strictly prohibited to everyone except “personnel.” Peculiarly, no other personnel can be found on the premises besides the owner himself, raising intrigue about the purpose of that restricted space. The door is locked, but it can be unlocked with a DC 18 Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) check, revealing a scene of gruesome murder and a bound Succubus feasting on human flesh.

Mahmud (@UUID[Actor.1JK80RxGJvsa6UG4]{Artisan} with a Level 1 Warlock - The Fiend Patron abilities, CN): Mahmud’s formative years were marked by clumsiness and an inability to hold down jobs due to a lingering head injury sustained in his childhood. The lingering effects of his injury led to severe bouts of vertigo, confining him to his home on occasion. However, as the responsibilities of taking care of himself grew more pressing with his father’s advancing age, Mahmud recognized the urgency of addressing his ailment. Despite his exhaustive efforts, which encompassed attempting every remedy and prayer, a cure remained elusive. Faced with mounting challenges, Mahmud took a drastic step – he decided to strike a bargain with a devil.

In the village, whispers circulated about a man who had purportedly entered into such a pact and amassed immense wealth as a result. Encouraged by this notion, Mahmud embarked on a ritual to summon an infernal entity from Al Ghaib. During their encounter, the Succubus presented him with a tantalizing proposition: the gift of heightened senses, which would eradicate his propensity for collisions and vertigo-induced spells. There was, however, a sinister stipulation – Mahmud was required to provide the demon with eyes, beginning with his own. After careful contemplation, he acquiesced, reasoning that forfeiting his eyes was a small price to pay for liberation from his debilitating condition.

Empowered by his newfound abilities, Mahmud seized control of his father’s inn. Within its confines, he erected a modest shrine dedicated to the fiend, serving as a repository for the eyes of inebriated patrons who overstayed their welcome. He pledged to extract eyes exclusively from those who had displayed malevolent inclinations, determined to uphold a semblance of moral integrity even in his macabre arrangement.

Afsun al-Jannah - The Enchanted Gardens.name: Afsun al-Jannah - The Enchanted Gardens
Afsun al-Jannah - The Enchanted Gardens.text:
A refreshing feeling takes you to the greatest places in your mind while you approach the Enchanted Gardens. A feeling of celestial serenity fills your heart and you feel this place must be the heaven on earth with this beauty and aura.

Enchanted Gardens of Cairo offer special cures and remedies for the wounded alongside a modest tavern for dining. The atrium, with a lounge next to it that is almost large enough to be called a tavern, attracts people from around Cairo not with its food and drinks, but with its spiritual connection and the healing it provides. The owner of the place and the guide of the gardens Ahmed Al-Shifa (Commoner) and his daughter Rania Al-Shifa (Commoner), besides serving customers in the tavern, lead them around the garden to their inner peace as well. Inheriting this place from his father, Ahmed doesn’t have any knowledge about the source of this healing power. He only knows how it works and guides people to benefit from it, earning money as he helps. It costs 5 gold dinars to use his guiding services.

The atrium inside the walls has a distinct separation made with floor tiles that present four sections of different healing areas. In the middle, a fountain splashes water and creates a pleasant sound in harmony with the birds calling among the trees. This peaceful garden offers four kinds of healing, one for each area as shown in the list.

Healing Area

Effect

Tear

Prayer of Healing, Lesser Restoration

Wear

Aid, Enhance Ability

Peace

Silence, Calm Emotions

Time

Silent Image, Zone of Truth

Deep inside the fountain, an old celestial being stretches out its roots. Providing the healing, it aspires to keep the balance of both the garden and the living upon it. Players succeeding at a DC 18 Intelligence (Arcana) check are aware that these blessings are the work of a supernatural being, subtly. When a creature lies inside the atrium, it must succeed on a DC 10 Wisdom saving throw or be marked with “Mark of Dishonesty.” When a fiend or undead strikes a creature with the mark, it has advantage on the attack roll. If Rania notices the creature lying, she warns stating the gardens wouldn’t like it.

The gardens, separated into four chambers, offer a different kind of healing for each. The first chamber “Tear” has a pond in it that heals the cuts and injuries of the wounded. The second chamber “Wear” has a mighty tree that stands upright in the middle, benefitting those who suffer problems of old age, strengthening their bones. Third chamber is called “Peace”. It has colorful flowers around it and on its wall a covered mirror lies still. This chamber is for those troubled within, relaxing and providing inner peace. The last chamber is “Time”, helping with grief, acceptance, and the passage of time. In this chamber, people face their haunted memories, their traumas, and when they finally accept their past they are moved by Ahmed to the Peace Chamber in order to reveal the mirror and face themselves.

Sandan al-Jamar - Ember’s Anvil.name: Sandan al-Jamar - Ember’s Anvil
Sandan al-Jamar - Ember’s Anvil.text:
As you step into the shop, your attention is drawn to a young boy seated behind the counter. The front area, designated for customers, showcases an array of available weaponry for purchase. With a slight grin, the child rises from his seat and warmly addresses you, “Greetings. How may I assist you?” His smile carries a unique charm. “My father is presently occupied within, and I shall act as his intermediary today. Please feel free to convey your orders to me. Should any inquiries arise, I shall venture inside to consult him directly. Is this arrangement suitable? He isn’t particularly inclined towards social interactions, I assure you. Allow me to be of aid.”

Swiftly, the boy ventures into the depths of the forgery to converse with his father. In the fleeting moment, you catch a glimpse of a hand gripping an imposing hammer, poised for crafting. The hands are adorned with burgundy scales, boasting claw-like appendages in lieu of conventional fingernails. This peculiar trait might well explain the blacksmith’s reserved nature.

You then realize that some parts of the young boy’s body are also covered with layer upon layer of fabric.

Ember’s Anvil holds a distinguished reputation as a renowned forge nestled within Cairo’s bustling streets. Orchestrating its operations is a figure known as Amar, a name widely recognized yet mysteriously unseen. Despite earnest endeavors, Amar remains an enigmatic presence, his elusive nature akin to a well-kept secret. Instead, the forge’s interface with the world is orchestrated by a diminutive yet remarkably capable young lad, Faisal. Faisal stands as the sole point of contact for all who seek the forge’s craftsmanship.

Ember’s Anvil produces blades honed to perfection; pieces of armor that are imposing, stern, and sturdy; and horseshoes crafted with meticulous care.

Amar (Artisan, NG): Amar, a dragonborn blacksmith, has dwelled in the shadows throughout his existence, seeking refuge from the watchful gazes of humans. He and his kin have concealed themselves within caverns, seldom venturing into the sunlight. Amidst this reclusive life, a serendipitous encounter with a human shattered the barriers of fear. This intrepid blacksmith recognized Amar’s potential and extended an offer to share his craft, envisioning a prosperous future for them both. Together, they masterminded an underground passage linking Amar’s secluded abode to the heart of the city, where the blacksmith’s workshop thrived.

Through the passage of time, Amar underwent rigorous tutelage under his human mentor, honing his skills and absorbing the intricacies of the trade. Regrettably, the mentor eventually passed away, leaving behind a legacy for Amar to inherit. Yet, Amar found himself in need of a representative for the shop – a bridge between the enigmatic blacksmith and the world beyond. In a twist of fate, he encountered a destitute, yet undaunted, young boy affected by Spell Rebound named Faisal, whose fearless demeanor resonated with Amar’s compassionate heart.

In a gesture that mirrored the mentorship Amar had received, he took Faisal under his wing, assuming the role of a paternal figure. As their lives became intricately woven, Faisal became an integral part of Amar’s life and business. With Amar’s assistance, Faisal managed the daily operations of the shop while Amar himself remained veiled from the public eye. The symbiotic relationship they nurtured was one of trust, companionship, and shared ambitions.

Faisal (@UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.O3ABqI55Ir1du1Xa]{Scout}j, N): Faisal’s early life unfolded in a quaint village nestled on the outskirts of Cairo, where the days held a sense of promise and contentment. Yet destiny took a heart-wrenching turn when a calamitous event shattered his idyllic world. Amidst a playful escapade in the forest, an unforgiving blaze consumed his home and family, leaving him grappling with loss and uncertainty. The young boy’s tragedy was not born out of a natural fire, but from an arcane explosion which also scarred parts of Faisal’s body. Young Faisal had to carry a memory of the blaze that reduced his life to ashes on himself as burnt tissue that will never heal.

The compassionate villagers rallied to his aid, offering fleeting refuge, but their resources proved inadequate to sustain his well-being. Faisal, bereft of options, embarked on a harrowing journey for survival, navigating the treacherous path of begging and petty thievery as he wandered the streets of Cairo.

Stricken by hunger and desperation, Faisal’s plight took an unexpected twist when he crossed paths with Amar, a figure both astonishing and approachable. It was an encounter that challenged his perception of humanity, as he bore the scars of fear from his past experiences. However, Amar’s benevolent demeanor provided a beacon of hope amidst the darkness that had cloaked Faisal’s existence. The kind-hearted blacksmith extended his hand, defying Faisal’s apprehensions and granting him a chance for solace and security.

Jar’at w’al-Nabatat - Hulya’s Hut of Pot.name: Jar’at w’al-Nabatat - Hulya’s Hut of Potions and Botanics
Jar’at w’al-Nabatat - Hulya’s Hut of Pot.text:
Hulya’s charming hut is all that’s left of what was once an ambitious plan for a housing complex. It was supposed to be a grand home, but now it stands as a symbol of dreams that were abruptly put on hold. A few years back, a devastating fire forced the entire neighborhood to find safety elsewhere. After the fire, Hulya found this hut, which had miraculously been spared. Though it needed a lot of work, Hulya had just the right touch to bring it back to life.

When you see it, you’re looking at a building with a solid stone base and a patchwork of makeshift repairs. Tarps are draped here and there, covering holes and cracks in the roof and walls.

As you step inside, you’re greeted by the sight of straw bags filled with various spices and dried herbs, neatly arranged. Then, a woman who appears to be in her middle years comes forward with a warm smile. “Welcome,” she says. “How can I assist you today?”

Tucked away on the outskirts of Cairo, Hulya’s small hut offers a peaceful escape from the never-ending buzz of the city, becoming a rare haven for those few adventurers who stumble upon it. This place holds a charm hidden in secret moments spent with the mysterious Hulya. Pushed away by a society that looks down on her, she finds herself living on the edge, known for her dealings with the mystical.

Yet in the silence of being outcast, something unexpected happens. The very people who whisper about her in disdain can’t help but be pulled back by a silent longing, driven to seek her skills. In her simple home, Hulya creates magic, blending a mix of herbs and spices she gathers on her walks through the wild, crafting her enchantments from the bounty of nature.

Hulya sells a wide assortment of potions and concoctions. However, some of the potions are useless. When purchasing a DC15 Intelligence (Arcana or Nature) check is needed to determine whether the potion sold actually does what Hulya says it does. If the skill check fails, the GM can roll a d20 in secret - on a roll of 8 or lower, the GM can secretly note that the potion is useless.

Istrahat al-Fuhūl - Stallions’ Rest.name: Istrahat al-Fuhūl - Stallions’ Rest
Istrahat al-Fuhūl - Stallions’ Rest.text:
Stallion’s Rest is more than just your average stables; it’s a significant establishment located just outside the city’s hustle and bustle, resembling a large horse farm rather than a simple stable. The facility includes three stable blocks and a generous open area where horses can freely roam and stretch their legs.

Interestingly, it’s also a place where wealthy parents bring their children for their very first horseback riding lessons.

Two of the buildings look like your typical stables, with cozy stalls for the horses. There, a dedicated caretaker looks after the horses, making sure they’re healthy and well-maintained. The third building is something else entirely—a larger, more imposing structure reserved for the most prestigious horses owned by distinguished clients. Around the clock, a specialized team works hard to care for these valued horses.

These horses enjoy regular baths and grooming sessions with special products that make their coats shine. They’re fed top-quality hay, ensuring they receive the best nutrition. A devoted woman visits this upscale stable several times a day, talking to the horses, offering them companionship and attention to keep their spirits high.

Stallion’s Rest is widely celebrated as a sanctuary for both adventurers and tourists. Here, guests find not only the opportunity to purchase exceptional horses but also to arrange for their own horses’ lodging. The establishment is well-known for its impressive selection of Arabian horses, catering to the tastes of even the most discerning customers.

Many who visit Cairo choose Stallion’s Rest for its outstanding care and attention to detail, attributes that the owner takes great pride in. This place has also become a gathering spot for well-known international personalities. While locals can rent space for their horses, there are exclusive areas within Stallion’s Rest designed for those who can afford such luxury. It’s the go-to place for the city’s elite and their distinguished visitors, making it a key location to run into these prominent figures or their representatives.

The owner, Vahid, is a shrewd businessman who enjoys cultivating professional and personal relationships. If you can convince Vahid that the adventurers are people that he would do well to befriend, he can offer many services and even horses free of charge - depending on how well he is convinced.

Vahid (Traveling Merchant, LN): Vahid’s father was a devoted caretaker of the royal stables, dedicating his life to the majestic horses that lived there. This deep commitment to equine care was a legacy he could have passed down to Vahid, offering him a ready-made path in life. Yet Vahid chose to blaze his own trail. Instead of following directly in his father’s footsteps, he decided to innovate, creating a stable unlike any other, aimed at providing an unparalleled equestrian experience for the wealthiest of clients.

Vahid’s venture was about more than just luxury; it was about creating an exclusive haven that caught the eye of discerning customers looking for something truly special. His choice to focus on luxury and exclusivity built a network of connections that reached well beyond local borders, attracting influential figures from around the world. With his naturally cheerful and welcoming nature, Vahid turned professional relationships into personal friendships, which only helped his business to thrive. Thanks to his vision and approach, Vahid’s reputation and success soared.

Bayt al-Khuyot - House of Threads.name: Bayt al-Khuyot - House of Threads
Bayt al-Khuyot - House of Threads.text:
The House of Threads is a magnificent shopping hall located right in the heart of Cairo, drawing in people from all over the world who are in search of the unmatched skill of its seamstresses. The ground floor buzzes with activity, acting as a marketplace filled with an extensive selection of fabrics and sewing tools. Vibrant colors of fabric rolls that beckon to the discerning shoppers as they meander through, picking out just the right materials for their craft.

Climbing up to the higher floors, you’ll find two levels dedicated to private rooms. These spaces are set aside for one-on-one meetings between customers and their chosen designers or seamstresses. Each room features a secluded area with curtains for trying on garments in privacy and comfort, alongside a cozy diwan for sitting down to hash out design details or simply to enjoy the company of friends while decisions are made.

At the very top of the mansion lies the atelier, a creative sanctuary where dedicated seamstresses invest their heart, soul, and occasionally magic into bringing the designers’ visions to life. This is where all their hard work comes together, resulting in the exquisite pieces that make the House of Threads a symbol of luxury and innovation in the world of 12th Century fashion.

The House of Threads enjoys considerable popularity among the women of Cairo. It serves as a haven where they can acquire a variety of fabrics for personal sewing projects at home, or collaborate with skilled tailors to fashion bespoke dresses, often reserved for special occasions. Prominent families typically benefit from dedicated tailors, providing personalized service, whereas regular patrons may exercise patience for their turn.

The array of attire available for purchase encompasses a diverse spectrum, spanning opulent silk gowns to durable splint mail, spanning from everyday wear to more protective armor and magical trinkets, sold in hushed voices.

Within the establishment, discreet chambers are set aside for esteemed guests, affording them privacy to engage in detailed discussions about their attire preferences, undertake measurements, and engage in outfit changes. These distinguished guests often reserve these exclusive rooms for an entire day, emerging from the House of Threads with a handful of meticulously designed garments.

Şilan (@UUID[Actor.1JK80RxGJvsa6UG4]{Artisan}, N): Şilan stands as the preeminent tailor and jewelmaker within the esteemed House of Threads. Renowned for her remarkable design prowess, she possesses an innate sense of color and style that remains unparalleled. The elite of Cairo’s affluent clans favor her services unequivocally, consistently choosing her over any alternative. A testament to her popularity, she conducts regular house calls. Her presence becomes an ever-present thread in the lives of the influential, affording her the opportunity to traverse the threshold of significance effortlessly.

However, she is more than just a popular garment maker. She also finds, forges, enchants, and studies arcane trinkets. Adventurers can resort to her services to identify, track, or purchase items of magical power.

It is due to her talent with arcane relics and exceptional access to the high ranking members of Cairo’s society that Saladin recruited her as his agent. Şilan shares her insights with the Avenging General, and acts as his eyes and ears within the city.

Tuhaf Khalil al-’Alf wa Wāhid - Khalil’s.name: Tuhaf Khalil al-’Alf wa Wāhid - Khalil’s One Thousand and One Knick Knacks
Tuhaf Khalil al-’Alf wa Wāhid - Khalil’s.text:
This quaint shop has the feel of a collector’s paradise, with its layout reminding one of a treasure-filled maze. It’s packed with an eclectic mix of items that spill into every available space, challenging any attempt to sort them into categories. This collection forms a patchwork that only the keen eyes of the owner, Khalil, can make sense of. Mysterious numbers mark the shelves, serving as a cryptic guide to their contents. The air is thick with a sense of stories and past lives embedded in each piece.

As you step inside, Khalil appears from behind the counter, his face breaking into a welcoming smile. “Welcome to my little treasure trove,” he says, his eyes twinkling with the excitement of sharing his world. “What are you in search of today? Feel free to look around at your leisure. In this place, the unexpected awaits around every corner, ready to surprise those who come looking. You might just find something you didn’t even know you needed.”

Tucked away in Cairo’s bustling streets, Khalil’s quaint shop, One Thousand and One Knick Knacks, is more than just a store; it’s a piece of history with layers of stories from different times. It began as his father’s labor of love, a place where the beauty of calligraphy was celebrated, and pages and books were lovingly crafted for thinkers and spiritual leaders alike.

When his father passed, Khalil took over, but with a twist. The fine art of calligraphy, so natural to his father, felt foreign in Khalil’s hands. Instead, Khalil was drawn to the world of knick-knacks — those odd, enchanting items that can’t quite be categorized. From a young age, Khalil had a soft spot for collecting these tiny treasures, often hiding them from his mother’s curious eyes. As years went by, his collection grew, spilling out of every corner of their home.

Seeing the growing clutter, his mother suggested Khalil use his passion to reinvent the shop. Taking her advice to heart, Khalil transformed the space. It went from a calligraphy hub to a collector’s paradise, where visitors now wander through a maze of the mundane and the extraordinary, each piece echoing tales from the past.

Today, Khalil’s shop is a cozy nook for curiosity seekers, a place where history meets whimsy, and every visit promises a journey into the heart of Cairo’s hidden treasures.

If the players seek to purchase anything from this shop, they need to roll a DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) check or a Wisdom (Perception or Insight) check. If the skill check succeeds, these items (each costs 10 Gd) will be available:

@UUID[Macro.Py3JqVhYCqUFTGPT]{Roll Item Table}

1

A glass jar filled with whispers

Each whisper, collected from the bustling streets of Cairo at dawn, is preserved with a magic that silences them forever. They say Khalil captured them to keep the city's secrets safe, or some fairies may have collected them in the jar – who knows?

2

Invisible ink quills

Crafted from the feathers of mythical birds, these quills are perfect for writing secrets that you never intend to share. The ink permanently disappears as soon as it touches any surface. Only a specially made light (with at least a 2nd-level spell) reveals the ink.

3

A clock that only tells time in dreams

This ornate clock, adorned with symbols only visible in the dream world, refuses to move its hands in the waking world. It’s said to work perfectly in dreams, aligning with the realm’s elusive time.

4

A compass that points to yesterday

A curious navigational device that doesn’t direct you North but to where you were exactly at dawn. It’s beautifully useless, as it leads you to a past that’s already gone. The compass realigns itself each dawn.

5

A Mirror of Future

A mirror that lets you see what you will look like in your sixties. However, sometimes the mirror looks blank and the viewer can’t see themselves. It is said to be a bad omen: that the viewer will never grow old.

6

A teapot that brews fog

When heated, this delicate porcelain teapot whistles quietly, filling cups not with tea but with the soft, thick fog of early Cairo mornings. It’s perfect for those who wish to sip on the essence of a cloudy day.

7

A book of unwritten poems

Bound in leather, this book contains pages that seem to always turn blank no matter how many times they’re flipped. It’s said that the poems appear only to those whose hearts are ready to understand their meaning or the poems that are left unfinished by their poets.

8

A set of keys to doors long vanished

These keys, each unique and intricately designed, open doors to buildings and homes that no longer exist in Cairo. Holding them, you can almost hear the echoes of doorways opening to places that time has forgotten.

If the skill check fails, the party must convince the shopkeeper to reveal their unique items or “the ones touched with a little mystery.”

Hashashin Presence.name: Hashashin Presence
Hashashin Presence.text: Since the death of Hasan Sabbah (check out Historica Arcanum: Herald of Rain for further information), the legendary Hashashin, the Order of the Hashashins has been quiet but still deadly. Saladin has been their fiercest enemy since his ascension and led many campaigns against them in Syria. In Cairo, a strong member of the order lurks in one of the most obvious places: in the center of the city, as a beggar: Sabah ad-Din al-Bahriye (for the Hashashin Fedayee statblock, check out the Appendix section). His nickname, al-Bahriye, means “marine” in Arabic. He was raised in a pirate ship sailing in the East Mediterranean. After the captain was assassinated by a close fedayee of Hasan Sabbah, al-Bahriye was taken into training and brainwashed in the Castle Alamut.

Al-Hakim Mosque.name: Al-Hakim Mosque
Al-Hakim Mosque.text:
A feeling of serenity washes over you. A mighty building stands proudly before you, but instead of might, you feel peace and kindness filling your body. You notice all kinds of inscriptions from the Quran embedded on the stones everywhere, and the golden light of the sun makes the mosque shine brighter than most adequate mosques.

Al-Hakim Mosque is also known as “Al-Anwar,” meaning “the Illuminated One” in Arabic. It has a courtyard and interior quarters suitable for Islamic prayers. On Fridays, most of the people of Cairo come here to join the Friday Prayers, which holds a significant place in Islamic tradition. The leading persons of this mosque are actually twins with celestial blood in them: Layla Shirin (@UUID[Actor.nW8Aj5aNHyswBvNs]{Traveling Artist} with Level 3 Life Domain Cleric abilities) (her name means “the sweet night”) and Asrin Basim (@UUID[Actor.OksiTzyq7R5pinZR]{Warrior Priest of Levant}). Layla Shirin is a devoted Muslim who usually disguises herself at night to walk the streets, in order to take care and heal the ones in need. She also brings food and supplies for the downtrodden and shelters the non-humanoids from dangers, ensuring their safety by erasing their tracks, and overcoming obstacles with her talents.

Asrin Basim is a kind man who is experienced in warfare. He fought for many years with his sister by his side and gained many divine abilities along the way. He never killed anyone and never took a life. He believes that through his faith, these abilities are bestowed upon him, and he only uses them for good, never turning anyone away. Through their celestial blood, they appear beautiful to those around them, and both seem to be young, in their early twenties. They are actually much older than that, having arrived in Cairo only a few years ago with plans to leave when people start asking questions.

They both can understand lies when they hear, they are always under the effects of the detect evil and good and the protection from evil and good spells.

Kalat el Maks - The Port.name: Kalat el Maks - The Port
Kalat el Maks - The Port.text:
Many ships come through the Port of Cairo. Kalat el Maks (meaning the Castle of Customs) is the name given to the tower that protects it, and most people refer to the port by the name of the tower. The tower is guarded by a @UUID[Actor.FJUpeOJhezl3A3Un]{Mamluk Veteran} called Qutuz Bagatur. He is an elderly man who spent decades in the seas as a captive and later as a captain of pirate ships. He appears to be a strict man to those around him, especially regarding taxes and port rules, yet he has a hidden sense of humor. Secretly, he is the source of many jokes and pranks around the tower and the port, as he enjoys messing with people greatly. For example, he prepares a raid party and sends them on a goose chase, and later rewards them with a feast. Sometimes, he casually prepares a fake treasure map to send them on a futile quest.

The port is not comparable to those open to the Gulf of Suez or the Mediterranean Sea, but still holds importance as being close to the heart of Egypt and ensuring trade along the Nile. There are many merchants, fishermen, sailors, workers, navigators, researchers, oarsmen, and people of other occupations passing by or working at this port.

A prominent merchant of the area is Hazal Seher (@UUID[Actor.ZNy2IXH6DjXJsE9k]{Traveling Merchant}, 18 CHA, 16 DEX with the abilities of a Level 2 Rogue and a Level 2 Bard). She has a keen eye for treasure and excels at finding valuable magic items. If she spends the night making at least ten people happy with her songs or tales, she usually wakes up knowing the place of a useful item. This innate ability helped her to gain fortune. She typically sold information about the locations of valuable items at a reasonable price, and made herself rich slowly. She doesn’t let anyone know about this ability of hers. In time, people started to bring treasure maps, rumors, locations, and legends about items to her. She is known for her talents, loyal twenty men (mostly uses @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.13K3XK2A3wwxVKLD]{Spy}j, @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.O3ABqI55Ir1du1Xa]{Scout}j, @UUID[Actor.XiG03vgMTRXPTmh9]{Wilderness Commoner}, or @UUID[Actor.1JK80RxGJvsa6UG4]{Artisan} stat blocks), and her captivating beauty.

Quests.name: Quests
Quests.text:
Quests

These quests can take place within the adventure module The Sigil of Jerusalem or can be treated as standalone stories.

The Egyptian Prometheus.name: The Egyptian Prometheus
The Egyptian Prometheus.text:
Recommended Level: 4-5

Quest Summary: Exiled scholars from the University create a monstrous robot with human-like intelligence. This construct is eventually shunned by humans and desires to kill its creators.

Possible Rewards: 200 gd, uncommon magic items for each party member

There are many rumors and sightings near the River Nile and down south that there’s a giant roaming around. Many merchants, pilgrims and civilians claim to see such a monster from afar. However, most of the incidents happened at night and the description of the creature varies from “hellish eyes like the fire” to “giant tail like a dragon’s” and most of them seem unreliable.

One of the days, a few bodies begin to surface along the Nile in a frozen state which alerts many of the locals nearby. They are closely tied to the Al-Azhar University, usually scholars or their relatives, with the only exceptions being a fishing family that lived down south.

The creature is actually a Madd-Jazir, The Frozen Tide, with enhanced Intelligence (INT 13) due to experiments some of the scholars conducted. Madd-Jazir gained consciousness, and when it woke up lonely at the laboratory, it immediately ran away. It had a few encounters with the locals but due to its appearance, it was shunned and forced to retreat to the wilderness. Its appearance resembled that of a frozen robot with distinct human-like features, such as dark veins, visible organs, and rotten flesh.

Madd-Jazir encountered the fishing family and stayed away from them, although it grew fond of them. Their oldest member was a blind man, “the grandfather” of the family. Madd-Jazir often sought windows to speak with the old man, who also grew fond of the creature, mostly because he couldn’t see it. Eventually, Madd-Jazir’s visits to the man were discovered by the sons, who eventually hurt the monster and shoved him away. Madd-Jazir felt that it could no longer connect with the people and blamed it on its creators. Madd-Jazir ran away from the family but he was chased by the sons. In a moment of anger, it killed them all. Their bodies went to the Nile as frozen corpses due to its abilities (further explained in its statblock in the Book of Ingenious Monsters section)

Its creators, a few students at the University and exiled members of the Banu Musa Society, eventually found the Madd-Jazir’s trail and tried to kill it. Due to frenzy, Madd-Jazir killed them all, too, and their bodies also vanished in the Nile. He took refuge in a cavern inhabited by @UUID[Actor.ImPKgYQeXgaRfM5f]{El-Naddaha} (three of them) and @UUID[Actor.HDpJhuR6O6h25tiU]{El-Rafiq} (six of them). The monster threatens them if they do not let him hide in here. Some nights, Madd-Jazir looks for its last creator and the main disciple responsible for its existence: Muzaffer (Banu Musa Disciple).

Muzaffer is aware that the monster is looking for him. He usually hides in different places each night to avoid it and he knows that the monster can’t get close to the city’s crowded places. He constantly seeks help from seemingly adventurous figures or local powers, but no one takes him seriously. If the adventuring party takes an interest in the matter, he will ask for their help in return for a handsome reward: 250 gd.

Muzaffer’s main goal is to stay alive and ensure the monster’s death. He is ready to sacrifice his possessions for this endeavor.

Madd-Jazir wants Muzaffer dead; however, if reasoned with, it may ask for a counterpart, another construct like itself and promise to venture into the Saharan desert or even further south. Muzaffer can be convinced (with a DC 15 Charisma check, proper skill proficiencies may apply) to build such a construct. In the end, he fears the new construct may not like Madd-Jazir, or be more vile than it should be.

The three El-Naddaha living in the cavern with the Madd-Jazir want it gone; however, they are terrified of its power. They can be persuaded (DC 13) or intimidated (DC 16) to cooperate with the adventurers. The cavern is about 50 ft. wide and 80 ft. long; most of the surface is filled with water that is almost 3-foot high, which is considered difficult terrain. Additionally, if a fight occurs against the El Naddaha, their servants, the El-Rafiq, may attempt to drown their enemies in the water.

The Old Gods.name: The Old Gods
The Old Gods.text:
Recommended Level 4

Quest Summary:An ancient Egyptian religious movement gathers the attention of the locals, while their leader (possessed by a demon) attempts to steal a powerful arcane artifact. In order to do that, he must conduct a ritual where blood sacrifice of innocents is a necessity.

Possible Rewards:Ring of Muawiya, consumable uncommon/rare magic items

Near the Sphinx and the Pyramids, there are reports of interesting sights. People, apparently wearing colorful clothes and masks of gods from the ancient Egyptian religion, are conducting small rituals on the site, especially at midday. The ritual involves a series of prayers and chants in the Ancient Egyptian tongue and usually ends with cultists running towards the desert. The most interesting part is, almost always a sandstorm accompanies their escape and covers their trails. A local trader named Djamal (@UUID[Actor.ZNy2IXH6DjXJsE9k]{Traveling Merchant}) personally informed authorities and said that the locals are afraid of these activities. Although no one has been hurt, it has been requested that this matter be investigated.

A cult named Light of Men-nefer, which was taking shelter in the Saharan desert for centuries, returns to the city. Their leader, Senusret (possessed by a Gloombound), aims to enter a building near the Sphinx with an obelisk at the top. He believes there’s a magic ring (@UUID[Item.Kf6QhgmN0MdjECp3]{Ring of Muawiya}) inside it and covets its powers. However, the gate to the building is sealed with a strong ritual and the seal can only be broken by a 6th-level dispel magic (an identify spell reveals this information). The walls are also enchanted; it is impossible to cross the walls with incorporeal movement or spells like dimension door.

Senusret uses the cult to create distractions and has a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.K15Yl8JmB5iPircc]{Druid}j friend named Nimlot (N, @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.races.Item.K4DNDcR6vngbp0pf]{dragonborn}), who creates sandstorms for the cultists to escape.

There are many merchants and notable people living around the Sphinx and Pyramids, as this place is a huge point of interest for the city.

Sumbul (@UUID[Actor.ZNy2IXH6DjXJsE9k]{Traveling Merchant}): An eccentric, talkative and middle-aged man who is known to travel to the Sahara to find interesting objects to sell at his table. He has interesting objects to sell, usually common or uncommon magic items which are 50% more expensive than the usual fees. Sumbul says that he put his life on the line, and it is the most precious thing he ever had.

Sumbul’s cheapest item is a compass that does not point towards the north, which he will sell for only 10 gd. A DC 10 Intelligence (Arcana) check reveals that it is a magical compass that was designed to find a specific location. DC 10 Wisdom (Perception) check reveals it has Ptah’s hieroglyphs on it. Ptah is the Egyptian god of craftsmen.

If followed, the compass leads them to a place between two giant rocks, four miles away. Between the rocks, a narrow gate is hidden and can be spotted with a passive Perception of 13 or an active DC 11 Wisdom (Perception) check.

Wisdom of the Sphinx: A small ruin near the Sphinx attracts orphans, street kids and other people for relative safety. A @UUID[Actor.kDX72EozbFjhaiYT]{Local Priest} named Faisal and three of his subordinates (all @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.CHEUjiYrVM9X0vIT]{Acolytes}j) run the place. It is an open-air mosque that provides daily meals for those in need. Faisal usually tells stories about the days of the Prophet and preaches about helping other people. If the adventurers help for a few hours or contribute in other ways (such as offering coins, goods, tending to the ill ones, or similar ways), Faisal will talk about the suspicious man frequently appearing around the Sphinx, Senusret.

Vault of Banu Musa: The vault consists of two rooms. The first room is for living quarters, and the second is a workshop. Check out the earlier Society of Banu Musa for further information on the faction. In this vault, two sages conduct experiments on sand and study for a potential sand golem. Both men have the Scholar of Cairo statblock. Their names are Bakr and Abdullah. Bakr has an item called Moonfall Ritual on him.

Moonfall Ritual

This magic tome must be read aloud during a night with a visible moon for 10 minutes. As ingredients, the blood of three believers is needed, which the spell of the tome will consume; all believers must be killed by the caster. Once the ritual is done, the caster gains the ability to suspend spells on objects for the next 24 hours.

If not interrupted these events will happen:

  • Senusret will learn the location of the Vault of Banu Musa by purchasing the compass.
  • At the Vault of Banu Musa, Senusret will kill two researchers there and obtain the Moonfall Ritual.
  • Senusret will hunt down three people for the Moonfall Ritual. These people will be three teachers at the Wisdom of the Sphinx. He will take the fourth one hostage.
  • He will conduct the ritual and enter the building with Nimlot by putting guards (4 Cultists) at the gate and then advancing to steal the Ring of Muawiya.
  • They will fight 2 @UUID[Actor.aU677PxVz1ThU7hS]{Animals of Set} and if intervened will use the hostage as leverage to get out of the situation.
  • If intervened Senusret may attempt to possess an adventurer.
  • If Nimlot is convinced that Senusret is possessed, he may switch sides.

The Building with the Obelisk: It is a 20 x 20 foot room with an altar at the center with the Ring of Muawiya. If someone enters, two Animals of Set will fight the intruders. The fight will trigger the altar’s magic: the ring’s abilities are limited. Each spell mentioned in the description can be cast once a day only.

The Binding in the Library.name: The Binding in the Library
The Binding in the Library.text:
Recommended Level: 4-5

Quest Summary:The acting headmaster of the University needs strong and capable experts to deal with a monster, a djinni, kept hidden at the bottom of the library.

Possible Rewards: 2 rare magic items, uncommon magic items for each party member, 250 gd

*This quest can be treated as a lighthearted or a monster-fighting quest depending on the type of game you play. Abu-Kahil can be treated as a mischievous monster with weird and interesting requests or as a cosmic horror waiting in slumber within the depths to pose a serious threat to the adventurers.*

The acting headmistress Sitara is in need of adventurers with proven knowledge on arcane matters and capable of fighting dangerous monsters. She sends out pupils into the city to discreetly search for a proper group. If the adventurers are already in touch with the University, their contact can recommend them to the headmistress.

Al-Jazari and Sitara discovered a rift in the underground floors of the university’s library after some otherworldly creatures were seen. The rift was a result of spell rebound and some powerful monsters were summoned. Al-Jazari and Sitara assembled a team to defeat them, but some of them caused huge problems. They summoned Abu-Kahil, Djinn of Slumber, through the rift and made a deal with it: The protection of the library.

Abu-Kahil’s agreement of 5 years is over and Sitara fears its powers; thus, she does not want to venture in alone, especially while Al-Jazari is away.

The rift is in a room 50 feet high, 60 feet wide and 90 feet long with the rift in the middle. The only entrance is 45 ft. away from the rift. The rift is 10 feet wide and 5 feet long.

There are possible solutions to this:

In a lighthearted quest:

  • Convincing Abu-Kahil to extend their current deal further. Abu-Kahil demands a thousand leaves of tea. The djinni likes tea very much.
  • Forcing or blackmailing Abu-Kahil into staying by using methods to intimidate it. For example, Sitara will inform the party that Abu-Kahil hates staying awake for more than it should, loud noises, constant company and similar problems that would disturb its peace.
  • Convincing Abu-Kahil into staying and guarding by using a new method to persuade it. For example, Abu-Kahil may want a new deal to secure its peace under the library further.

In a monster-fighting quest:

  • Binding Abu-Kahil to its place with the magic circle or a similar spell and with the help of Sitara, makes the binding last for a long time.
  • Abu-Kahil could be killed and a new one may be summoned. This may result in a spell rebound effect, as Sitara herself stated.
  • Freeing Abu-Kahil and closing the rift forever. In order for the rift to be closed, Sitara must conduct a ritual that lasts for 10 rounds. At the start of each round, at the Initiative count 20, a random monster is summoned within 30 ft. of the rift. Once the rift is closed, the summoned monsters are banished automatically and won’t return. Sitara must be within 15 ft. of the rift to be able to conduct the ritual. She is concentrating on the ritual and must maintain it for 1 minute. It works as if concentrating on a spell.

The Voice of Sphinx.name: The Voice of Sphinx
The Voice of Sphinx.text:
Recommended Level: 4-5

Quest Summary: There are rumors about a stone that drives people mad. Most of the locals shun the users and those who seek it. The stone is believed to have been excavated from the pyramids and some believe it may bring power to those who want it. It actually belongs to the Sphinx, Aspect of Bestet, but cursed by an ancient magician. To lift the curse, the stone must be brought to the Sphinx, in the ancient site of Memphis.

Possible Rewards: A rare magic item, 300 gd

There is a rumor about a magic stone in the streets of Cairo. This magic stone supposedly gives amazing power to those who control it. Whoever has it immediately feels good themselves and the rumor is that the stone gives arcane powers, such as invisibility or superhuman strength to its owner. Eventually, the owner of the stone disappears and the stone finds itself a new owner.

The Stone of Sphinx

Wondrous item, rare

Originally there were many of these stones during the ancient times of Egypt. Sphinx would bless some soldiers with this stone, and they would fight with gracious glory in battles in the name of Pharaohs. Any stone can give the same effect, as long as the sphinx breathes on it.

While held, the stone gives these benefits for 1 day:

  • Increases Strength score to 23 if it’s not higher already.
  • The user can cast each of the invisibility, heroism and expeditious retreat spells once per day. This ability recharges at dawn.
  • If the user dies, it turns into an @UUID[Actor.aU677PxVz1ThU7hS]{Animal of Set}.

Once a day passes, the same creature can’t benefit from the stone for a week.

Curse: This item is cursed. Anyone holding it for more than 1 minute must succeed on a DC 10 Charisma saving throw each hour. On a failed save, the creature is cursed and driven to madness. The cursed creature acts weirder than usual and gains overconfidence due to its newfound strength. After spending at least 6 hours with the stone the madness conditions the target to find the Well of Ikaros located near Memphis, where Magus Jambres Sneferu lies dead. The creature lets itself fall to the well to its eventual death. The creature is magically drawn to its place and knows what direction the well lies.

After each long rest passes without reaching the Well, the saving throw is repeated. Each failed save gives 1 Level of Corruption.

Magus Jambres Sneferu is a dead magician defeated and killed by a Satrap (Check out the Characters section in Historica Arcanum: Herald of Rain for further information about the Satraps, the ones that fight against otherworldly threats) a long time ago. He names himself after Jambres, a magician mentioned in the Book of Exodus and Sneferu, the name of a wondrous sorcerer from the Egyptian legends: Djed-Sneferu or, in his other name, Dedi.

The Magus cursed the stone before his downfall and his burial place was built by his followers in a way that would ensure his eventual return. If a hundred souls were brought to the well, the Magus would live again. However, the Satrap realized this threat and destroyed each member of his cult. He hid the stone in the pyramids, a place that was safe until now.

The stone was found by a @UUID[Actor.EcikReeMMNMXkAUy]{Scholar of Cairo}, a member of the University, named Abbas. Since Abbas, the stone had seven previous owners, all of whom ultimately vanished into thin air. The Well of Ikaros needs four more souls. If the Well succeeds in receiving four more souls, the Magus will be born again.

The stone is in the possession of a @UUID[Actor.ZNy2IXH6DjXJsE9k]{Traveling Merchant} called Humeyra. If the adventurers do not intervene, these events will happen:

  • Humeyra will pick a fight in Al-Madina, wounding two Mamluk officers, and escape the scene unnoticed.
  • She will kill two Mamluk soldiers at night and will drop the stone on them. Her trail can be found by a DC 15 Wisdom (Survival) check.
  • A @UUID[Actor.FJUpeOJhezl3A3Un]{Mamluk Veteran} named Sadik Ahmad will gain possession of the stone.
  • Sadik Ahmad will keep quiet about having the stone and will challenge a superior officer to combat: Bunyamin (@UUID[Actor.xgNOVmJC7PrjTZ7l]{Mamluk Cavalry}). Bunyamin is a student of Nadim-lank and a close friend of his.
  • Sadik Ahmad will kill Bunyamin and flee the city. His trail can be found with a DC 16 Wisdom (Survival) check. He will drop the stone at the Pearl Palace courtyard.
  • Nadim-lank will be careful about the stone, but one Mamluk Ghazi named Koray Arif will be interested in its magic and attempt to steal the stone and catch Nadim-lank off guard. If he is the last one to travel to Well of Ikaros he will take the stone with him.

If the adventurers find the stone, a DC 15 Intelligence (Arcana) check will reveal a certain ability of the stone: A magical and very tiny light appears on the stone and points towards a direction. If followed, it will take them to Memphis and eventually in the presence of the Sphinx, Aspect of Bastet.

In the open field, the tail of a statue can be spotted thanks to the magic. It will reveal an 8-meter by 4-meter sphinx statue. With the magic of the stone, a gate will be revealed and in an underground pool, the mighty creature awaits.

Bestet is a mighty creature and as legends foretell, she is very intrigued by asking riddles and will act friendly towards the creatures. Bestet is very dependent on her charisma and charm. When told about the danger and presented with the stone, the sphinx will lift its curse altogether and enchant it with new magic: If it is thrown into the well, it will end the days of the magus and his resurrection will not be possible.

If the adventurers are willing, she will ask them riddles and say that she will award them with a rare magic item: @UUID[Item.lDHacDxELbj4NEXv]{Book of Coming Forth by Day}, the famous Egyptian Book of Dead.

When asked about Oedipus, she will state that, of course she will not attack the adventurers or attempt to strangle them; those are just stories.

The riddles can be of the following or some new ones entirely:

  • What goes on four feet in the morning, two feet in midday, and three feet in the evening? | A man.
  • What has roots as nobody sees, is taller than trees, up, up, up it goes, and yet, never grows? | A mountain.
  • Thirty white horses on a red hill. First they champ, then they stamp, then they stand still. | Teeth
  • Voiceless it cries, wingless flutters, toothless bites, mouthless mutters. | The wind.
  • This thing devours all things: birds, beasts, trees, flowers; gnaws iron, bites steel; grinds hard stones to meal; slays king, ruins town, and beats high mountain down | Time
  • What can bring back the dead; make you cry, make you laugh, make you young; is born in an instant, yet lasts a lifetime. | Memory
  • I’m alive, but without breath; I’m as cold in life as in death; I’m never thirsty, though I always drink. | A fish

Well of Ikaros: The well is also in the Memphis ruins and can be tracked by the trails of those who ventured here. It is guarded by two @UUID[Actor.KB0O8Ij9TLkoqs4T]{Ruznara}. The magus will realize the comings of the adventurers, and he will offer them power, wealth and many other things to turn them to his side.

If the adventurers fail to stop the sacrifices, the magus will be born again as a @UUID[Compendium.dnd5e.monsters.Actor.bfh29vIEoGzI240e]{Lich} (without spells of 6th level or higher, legendary actions, its phylactery and with 20 hit points fewer and a proficiency bonus of +5).
